column2: That (prince) who will coerce both his (disloyal) subjects and the army of the foe, let him ever serve with every effort like a Guru.

column1: yadi tatrāpi saṃpaśyed doṣaṃ saṃśrayakāritam / suyuddham eva tatrāpi nirviśaṅkaḥ samācaret //
column2: When, even in that (condition), he sees (that) evil is caused by (such) protection, let him without hesitation have recourse to war.

column1: sarvopāyais tathā kuryān nītijñaḥ pṛthivīpatiḥ / yathāsyābhyadhikā na syur mitrodāsīnaśatravaḥ //
column2: By all (the four) expedients a politic prince must arrange (matters so) that neither friends, nor neutrals, nor foes are superior to himself.

column1: āyatiṃ sarvakāryāṇāṃ tadātvaṃ ca vicārayet / atītānāṃ ca sarveṣāṃ guṇadoṣau ca tattvataḥ //
column2: Let him fully consider the future and the immediate results of all undertakings, and the good and bad sides of all past (actions).

column1: āyatyāṃ guṇadoṣajñas tadātve kṣipraniścayaḥ / atīte kāryaśeṣajñaḥ śatrubhir nābhibhūyate //
column2: He who knows the good and the evil (which will result from his acts) in the future, is quick in forming resolutions for the present, and understands the consequences of past (actions), will not be conquered.

column1: yathainaṃ nābhisaṃdadhyur mitrodāsīnaśatravaḥ / tathā sarvaṃ saṃvidadhyād eṣa sāmāsiko nayaḥ //
column2: Let him arrange everything in such a manner that no ally, no neutral or foe may injure him; that is the sum of political wisdom.

column1: tadā tu yānam ātiṣṭhed arirāṣṭraṃ prati prabhuḥ / tadānena vidhānena yāyād aripuraṃ śanaiḥ //
column2: But if the king undertakes an expedition against a hostile kingdom, then let him gradually advance, in the following manner, against his foe's capital.

column1: mārgaśīrṣe śubhe māsi yāyād yātrāṃ mahīpatiḥ / phālgunaṃ vātha caitraṃ vā māsau prati yathābalam //
column2: Let the king undertake his march in the fine month Margasirsha, or towards the months of Phalguna and Kaitra, according to the (condition of his) army.

column1: anyeṣv api tu kāleṣu yadā paśyed dhruvaṃ jayam / tadā yāyād vigṛhyaiva vyasane cotthite ripoḥ //
column2: Even at other times, when he has a certain prospect of victory, or when a disaster has befallen his foe, he may advance to attack him.

column1: kṛtvā vidhānaṃ mūle tu yātrikaṃ ca yathāvidhi / upagṛhyāspadaṃ caiva cārān samyag vidhāya ca //
column2: But having duly arranged (all affairs) in his original (kingdom) and what relates to the expedition, having secured a basis (for his operations) and having duly dispatched his spies;

column1: saṃśodhya trividhaṃ mārgaṃ ṣaḍvidhaṃ ca balaṃ svakam / sāṃparāyikakalpena yāyād aripuraṃ prati //
column2: Having cleared the three kinds of roads, and (having made) his sixfold army (efficient), let him leisurely proceed in the manner prescribed for warfare against the enemy's capital.

column1: śatrusevini mitre ca gūḍhe yuktataro bhavet / gatapratyāgate caiva sa hi kaṣṭataro ripuḥ //
column2: Let him be very much on his guard against a friend who secretly serves the enemy and against (deserters) who return (from the enemy's camp); for such (men are) the most dangerous foes.

column1: daṇḍavyūhena tan mārgaṃ yāyāt tu śakaṭena vā / varāhamakarābhyāṃ vā sūcyā vā garuḍena vā //
column2: Let him march on his road, arraying (his troops) like a staff (i.e. in an oblong), or like a waggon (i.e. in a wedge), or like a boar (i.e. in a rhombus), or like a Makara (i.e. in two triangles, with the apices joined), or like a pin (i.e. in a long line), or like a Garuda (i.e. in a rhomboid with far-extended wings).

column1: yataś ca bhayam āśaṅket tato vistārayed balam / padmena caiva vyūhena niviśeta sadā svayam //
column2: From whatever (side) he apprehends danger, in that (direction) let him extend his troops, and let him always himself encamp in an array, shaped like a lotus.

column1: senāpatibalādhyakṣau sarvadikṣu niveśayet / yataś ca bhayam āśaṅket prācīṃ tāṃ kalpayed diśam //
column2: Let him allot to the commander-in-chief, to the (subordinate) general, (and to the superior officers) places in all directions, and let him turn his front in that direction whence he fears danger.

column1: gulmāṃś ca sthāpayed āptān kṛtasaṃjñān samantataḥ / sthāne yuddhe ca kuśalān abhīrūn avikāriṇaḥ //
column2: On all sides let him place troops of soldiers, on whom he can rely, with whom signals have been arranged, who are expert both in sustaining a charge and in charging, fearless and loyal.

column1: saṃhatān yodhayed alpān kāmaṃ vistārayed bahūn / sūcyā vajreṇa caivaitān vyūhena vyūhya yodhayet //
column2: Let him make a small number of soldiers fight in close order, at his pleasure let him extend a large number in loose ranks; or let him make them fight, arranging (a small number) in the needle-array, (and a large number) in the thunderbolt-array.

column1: syandanāśvaiḥ same yudhyed anūpe nau dvipais tathā / vṛkṣagulmāvṛte cāpair asicarmāyudhaiḥ sthale //
column2: On even ground let him fight with chariots and horses, in water-bound places with boats and elephants, on (ground) covered with trees and shrubs with bows, on hilly ground with swords, targets, (and other) weapons.

column1: kurukṣetrāṃś ca matsyāṃś ca pañcālāñ śūrasenajān / dīrghāṃl laghūṃś caiva narān agrānīkeṣu yojayet //
column2: (Men born in) Kurukshetra, Matsyas, Pankalas, and those born in Surasena, let him cause to fight in the van of the battle, as well as (others who are) tall and light.

column1: praharṣayed balaṃ vyūhya tāṃś ca samyak parīkṣayet / ceṣṭāś caiva vijānīyād arīn yodhayatām api //
column2: After arranging his troops, he should encourage them (by an address) and carefully inspect them; he should also mark the behaviour (of the soldiers) when they engage the enemy.

column1: uparudhyārim āsīta rāṣṭraṃ cāsyopapīḍayet / dūṣayec cāsya satataṃ yavasānnodakendhanam // bhindyāc caiva taḍāgāni prākāraparikhās tathā / samavaskandayec cainaṃ rātrau vitrāsayet tathā //
column2: When he has shut up his foe (in a town), let him sit encamped, harass his kingdom, and continually spoil his grass, food, fuel, and water. Likewise let him destroy the tanks, ramparts, and ditches, and let him assail the (foe unawares) and alarm him at night.

column1: upajapyān upajaped budhyetaiva ca tatkṛtam / yukte ca daive yudhyeta jayaprepsur apetabhīḥ //
column2: Let him instigate to rebellion those who are open to such instigations, let him be informed of his (foe's) doings, and, when fate is propitious, let him fight without fear, trying to conquer.

column1: sāmnā dānena bhedena samastair atha vā pṛthak / vijetuṃ prayatetārīn na yuddhena kadā cana //
column2: He should (however) try to conquer his foes by conciliation, by (well-applied) gifts, and by creating dissension, used either separately or conjointly, never by fighting, (if it can be avoided.)

column1: anityo vijayo yasmād dṛśyate yudhyamānayoḥ / parājayaś ca saṃgrāme tasmād yuddhaṃ vivarjayet //
column2: For when two (princes) fight, victory and defeat in the battle are, as experience teaches, uncertain; let him therefore avoid an engagement.

column1: trayāṇām apy upāyānāṃ pūrvoktānām asaṃbhave / tathā yudhyeta saṃpanno vijayeta ripūn yathā //
column2: (But) if even those three before-mentioned expedients fail, then let him, duly exerting himself, fight in such a manner that he may completely conquer his enemies.

column1: jitvā saṃpūjayed devān brāhmaṇāṃś caiva dhārmikān / pradadyāt parihārārthaṃ khyāpayed abhayāni ca //
column2: When he has gained victory, let him duly worship the gods and honour righteous Brahmanas, let him grant exemptions, and let him cause promises of safety to be proclaimed.

column1: sarveṣāṃ tu viditvaiṣāṃ samāsena cikīrṣitam / sthāpayet tatra tadvaṃśyaṃ kuryāc ca samayakriyām //
column2: But having fully ascertained the wishes of all the (conquered), let him place there a relative of the (vanquished ruler on the throne), and let him impose his conditions.

column1: pramāṇāni ca kurvīta teṣāṃ dharmān yathoditān / ratnaiś ca pūjayed enaṃ pradhānapuruṣaiḥ saha //
column2: Let him make authoritative the lawful (customs) of the (inhabitants), just as they are stated (to be), and let him honour the (new king) and his chief servants with precious gifts.

column1: ādānam apriyakaraṃ dānaṃ ca priyakārakam / abhīpsitānām arthānāṃ kāle yuktaṃ praśasyate //
column2: The seizure of desirable property which causes displeasure, and its distribution which causes pleasure, are both recommendable, (if they are) resorted to at the proper time.

column1: sarvaṃ karmedam āyattaṃ vidhāne daivamānuṣe / tayor daivam acintyaṃ tu mānuṣe vidyate kriyā //
column2: All undertakings (in) this (world) depend both on the ordering of fate and on human exertion; but among these two (the ways of) fate are unfathomable; in the case of man's work action is possible.

column1: saha vāpi vrajed yuktaḥ saṃdhiṃ kṛtvā prayatnataḥ / mitraṃ hiraṇyaṃ bhūmiṃ vā saṃpaśyaṃs trividhaṃ phalam // pārṣṇigrāhaṃ ca saṃprekṣya tathākrandaṃ ca maṇḍale / mitrād athāpy amitrād vā yātrāphalam avāpnuyāt //
column2: Or (the king, bent on conquest), considering a friend, gold, and land (to be) the triple result (of an expedition), may, using diligent care, make peace with (his foe) and return (to his realm). Having paid due attention to any king in the circle (of neighbouring states) who might attack him in the rear, and to his supporter who opposes the latter, let (the conqueror) secure the fruit of the expedition from (the prince whom he attacks), whether (he may have become) friendly or (remained) hostile.

column1: hiraṇyabhūmisaṃprāptyā pārthivo na tathaidhate / yathā mitraṃ dhruvaṃ labdhvā kṛśam apy āyatikṣamam //
column2: By gaining gold and land a king grows not so much in strength as by obtaining a firm friend, (who), though weak, (may become) powerful in the future.

column1: dharmajñaṃ ca kṛtajñaṃ ca tuṣṭaprakṛtim eva ca / anuraktaṃ sthirārambhaṃ laghumitraṃ praśasyate // prājñaṃ kulīnaṃ śūraṃ ca dakṣaṃ dātāram eva ca / kṛtajñaṃ dhṛtimantaṃ ca kaṣṭam āhur ariṃ budhāḥ //
column2: A weak friend (even) is greatly commended, who is righteous (and) grateful, whose people are contented, who is attached and persevering in his undertakings. The wise declare him (to be) a most dangerous foe, who is wise, of noble race, brave, clever, liberal, grateful, and firm.

column1: āryatā puruṣajñānaṃ śauryaṃ karuṇaveditā / sthaulalakṣyaṃ ca satatam udāsīnaguṇodayaḥ //
column2: Behaviour worthy of an Aryan, knowledge of men, bravery, a compassionate disposition, and great liberality are the virtues of a neutral (who may be courted).

column1: ksemyāṃ sasyapradāṃ nityaṃ paśuvṛddhikarīm api / parityajen nṛpo bhūmim ātmārtham avicārayan //
column2: Let the king, without hesitation, quit for his own sake even a country (which is) salubrious, fertile, and causing an increase of cattle.

column1: āpadarthaṃ dhanaṃ rakṣed dārān rakṣed dhanair api / ātmānaṃ satataṃ rakṣed dārair api dhanair api //
column2: For times of need let him preserve his wealth; at the expense of his wealth let him preserve his wife; let him at all events preserve himself even by (giving up) his wife and his wealth.

column1: saha sarvāḥ samutpannāḥ prasamīkṣyāpado bhṛśam / saṃyuktāṃś ca viyuktāṃś ca sarvopāyān sṛjed budhaḥ //
column2: A wise (king), seeing that all kinds of misfortunes violently assail him at the same time, should try all (the four) expedients, be it together or separately, (in order to save himself.)

column1: upetāram upeyaṃ ca sarvopāyāṃś ca kṛtsnaśaḥ / etat trayaṃ samāśritya prayatetārthasiddhaye //
column2: On the person who employs the expedients, on the business to be accomplished, and on all the expedients collectively, on these three let him ponder and strive to accomplish his ends.

column1: evaṃ sarvam idaṃ rājā saha sammantrya mantribhiḥ / vyāyamyāplutya madhyāhne bhoktum antaḥpuraṃ viśet //
column2: Having thus consulted with his ministers on all these (matters), having taken exercise, and having bathed afterwards, the king may enter the harem at midday in order to dine.

column1: tatrātmabhūtaiḥ kālajñair ahāryaiḥ paricārakaiḥ / suparīkṣitam annādyam adyān mantrair viṣāpahaiḥ //
column2: There he may eat food, (which has been prepared) by faithful, incorruptible (servants) who know the (proper) time (for dining), which has been well examined (and hallowed) by sacred texts that destroy poison.

column1: viṣaghnair agadaiś cāsya sarvadravyāṇi yojayet / viṣaghnāni ca ratnāni niyato dhārayet sadā //
column2: Let him mix all his food with medicines (that are) antidotes against poison, and let him always be careful to wear gems which destroy poison.

column1: parīkṣitāḥ striyaś cainaṃ vyajanodakadhūpanaiḥ / veṣābharaṇasaṃśuddhāḥ spṛśeyuḥ susamāhitāḥ //
column2: Well-tried females whose toilet and ornaments have been examined, shall attentively serve him with fans, water, and perfumes.

column1: evaṃ prayatnaṃ kurvīta yānaśayyāsanāśane / snāne prasādhane caiva sarvālaṅkārakeṣu ca //
column2: In like manner let him be careful about his carriages, bed, seat, bath, toilet, and all his ornaments.

column1: bhuktavān viharec caiva strībhir antaḥpure saha / vihṛtya tu yathākālaṃ punaḥ kāryāṇi cintayet //
column2: When he has dined, he may divert himself with his wives in the harem; but when he has diverted himself, he must, in due time, again think of the affairs of state.

column1: alaṃkṛtaś ca saṃpaśyed āyudhīyaṃ punar janam / vāhanāni ca sarvāṇi śastrāṇy ābharaṇāni ca //
column2: Adorned (with his robes of state), let him again inspect his fighting men, all his chariots and beasts of burden, the weapons and accoutrements.

column1: saṃdhyāṃ copāsya śṛṇuyād antarveśmani śastrabhṛt / rahasyākhyāyināṃ caiva praṇidhīnāṃ ca ceṣṭitam //
column2: Having performed his twilight-devotions, let him, well armed, hear in an inner apartment the doings of those who make secret reports and of his spies.

column1: gatvā kakṣāntaraṃ tv anyat samanujñāpya taṃ janam / praviśed bhojanārthaṃ ca strīvṛto 'ntaḥpuraṃ punaḥ //
column2: But going to another secret apartment and dismissing those people, he may enter the harem, surrounded by female (servants), in order to dine again.

column1: tatra bhuktvā punaḥ kiṃ cit tūryaghoṣaiḥ praharṣitaḥ / saṃviśet taṃ yathākālam uttiṣṭhec ca gataklamaḥ //
column2: Having eaten there something for the second time, and having been recreated by the sound of music, let him go to rest and rise at the proper time free from fatigue.

column1: etadvidhānam ātiṣṭhed arogaḥ pṛthivīpatiḥ / asvasthaḥ sarvam etat tu bhṛtyeṣu viniyojayet //
column2: A king who is in good health must observe these rules; but, if he is indisposed, he may entrust all this (business) to his servants.

column1: vyavahārān didṛkṣus tu brāhmaṇaiḥ saha pārthivaḥ / mantrajñair mantribhiś caiva vinītaḥ praviśet sabhām //
column2: A king, desirous of investigating law cases, must enter his court of justice, preserving a dignified demeanour, together with Brahmanas and with experienced councillors.

column1: tatrāsīnaḥ sthito vāpi pāṇim udyamya dakṣiṇam / vinītaveṣābharaṇaḥ paśyet kāryāṇi kāryiṇām //
column2: There, either seated or standing, raising his right arm, without ostentation in his dress and ornaments, let him examine the business of suitors,

column1: pratyahaṃ deśadṛṣṭaiś ca śāstradṛṣṭaiś ca hetubhiḥ / aṣṭādaśasu mārgeṣu nibaddhāni pṛthak pṛthak //
column2: Daily (deciding) one after another (all cases) which fall under the eighteen titles (of the law) according to principles drawn from local usages. and from the Institutes of the sacred law.

column1: teṣām ādyam ṛṇādānaṃ nikṣepo 'svāmivikrayaḥ / saṃbhūya ca samutthānaṃ dattasyānapakarma ca //
column2: Of those (titles) the first is the non-payment of debts, (then follow), (2) deposit and pledge, (3) sale without ownership, (4) concerns among partners, and (5) resumption of gifts,

column1: vetanasyaiva cādānaṃ saṃvidaś ca vyatikramaḥ / krayavikrayānuśayo vivādaḥ svāmipālayoḥ // sīmāvivādadharmaś ca pāruṣye daṇḍavācike / steyaṃ ca sāhasaṃ caiva strīsaṃgrahaṇam eva ca //
column2: (6) Non-payment of wages, (7) non-performance of agreements, (8) rescission of sale and purchase, (9) disputes between the owner (of cattle) and his servants, (10) Disputes regarding boundaries, (11) assault and (12) defamation, (13) theft, (14) robbery and violence, (15) adultery,

column1: strīpuṃdharmo vibhāgaś ca dyūtam āhvaya eva ca / padāny aṣṭādaśaitāni vyavahārasthitāv iha //
column2: (16) Duties of man and wife, (17) partition (of inheritance), (18) gambling and betting; these are in this world the eighteen topics which give rise to lawsuits.

column1: eṣu sthāneṣu bhūyiṣṭhaṃ vivādaṃ caratāṃ nṛṇām / dharmaṃ śāśvatam āśritya kuryāt kāryavinirṇayam //
column2: Depending on the eternal law, let him decide the suits of men who mostly contend on the titles just mentioned.

column1: yadā svayaṃ na kuryāt tu nṛpatiḥ kāryadarśanam / tadā niyuñjyād vidvāṃsaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ kāryadarśane //
column2: But if the king does not personally investigate the suits, then let him appoint a learned Brahmana to try them.

column1: so 'sya kāryāṇi saṃpaśyet sabhyair eva tribhir vṛtaḥ / sabhām eva praviśyāgryām āsīnaḥ sthita eva vā //
column2: That (man) shall enter that most excellent court, accompanied by three assessors, and fully consider (all) causes (brought) before the (king), either sitting down or standing.

column1: yasmin deśe niṣīdanti viprā vedavidas trayaḥ / rājñaś cādhikṛto vidvān brahmaṇas tāṃ sabhāṃ viduḥ //
column2: Where three Brahmanas versed in the Vedas and the learned (judge) appointed by the king sit down, they call that the court of (four-faced) Brahman.

column1: dharmo viddhas tv adharmeṇa sabhāṃ yatropatiṣṭhate / śalyaṃ cāsya na kṛntanti viddhās tatra sabhāsadaḥ //
column2: But where justice, wounded by injustice, approaches and the judges do not extract the dart, there (they also) are wounded (by that dart of injustice).

column1: sabhāṃ vā na praveṣṭavyaṃ vaktavyaṃ vā samañjasam / abruvan vibruvan vāpi naro bhavati kilbiṣī //
column2: Either the court must not be entered, or the truth must be spoken; a man who either says nothing or speaks falsely, becomes sinful.

column1: yatra dharmo hy adharmeṇa satyaṃ yatrānṛtena ca / hanyate prekṣamāṇānāṃ hatās tatra sabhāsadaḥ //
column2: Where justice is destroyed by injustice, or truth by falsehood, while the judges look on, there they shall also be destroyed.

column1: dharma eva hato hanti dharmo rakṣati rakṣitaḥ / tasmād dharmo na hantavyo mā no dharmo hato 'vadhīt //
column2: 'Justice, being violated, destroys; justice, being preserved, preserves: therefore justice must not be violated, lest violated justice destroy us.'

column1: vṛṣo hi bhagavān dharmas tasya yaḥ kurute hy alam / vṛṣalaṃ taṃ vidur devās tasmād dharmaṃ na lopayet //
column2: For divine justice (is said to be) a bull (vrisha); that (man) who violates it (kurute 'lam) the gods consider to be (a man despicable like) a Sudra (vrishala); let him, therefore, beware of violating justice.

column1: eka eva suhṛd dharmo nidhāne 'py anuyāti yaḥ / śarīreṇa samaṃ nāśaṃ sarvam anyad dhi gacchati //
column2: The only friend who follows men even after death is justice; for everything else is lost at the same time when the body (perishes).

column1: pādo 'dharmasya kartāraṃ pādaḥ sākṣiṇam ṛcchati / pādaḥ sabhāsadaḥ sarvān pādo rājānam ṛcchati //
column2: One quarter of (the guilt of) an unjust (decision) falls on him who committed (the crime), one quarter on the (false) witness, one quarter on all the judges, one quarter on the king.

column1: rājā bhavaty anenās tu mucyante ca sabhāsadaḥ / eno gacchati kartāraṃ nindārho yatra nindyate //
column2: But where he who is worthy of condemnation is condemned, the king is free from guilt, and the judges are saved (from sin); the guilt falls on the perpetrator (of the crime alone).

column1: jātimātropajīvī vā kāmaṃ syād brāhmaṇabruvaḥ / dharmapravaktā nṛpater na tu śūdraḥ kathaṃ cana //
column2: A Brahmana who subsists only by the name of his caste (gati), or one who merely calls himself a Brahmana (though his origin be uncertain), may, at the king's pleasure, interpret the law to him, but never a Sudra.

column1: yasya śūdras tu kurute rājño dharmavivecanam / tasya sīdati tad rāṣṭraṃ paṅke gaur iva paśyataḥ //
column2: The kingdom of that monarch, who looks on while a Sudra settles the law, will sink (low), like a cow in a morass.

column1: yad rāṣṭraṃ śūdrabhūyiṣṭhaṃ nāstikākrāntam advijam / vinaśyaty āśu tat kṛtsnaṃ durbhikṣavyādhipīḍitam //
column2: That kingdom where Sudras are very numerous, which is infested by atheists and destitute of twice-born (inhabitants), soon entirely perishes, afflicted by famine and disease.

column1: dharmāsanam adhiṣṭhāya saṃvītāṅgaḥ samāhitaḥ / praṇamya lokapālebhyaḥ kāryadarśanam ārabhet //
column2: Having occupied the seat of justice, having covered his body, and having worshipped the guardian deities of the world, let him, with a collected mind, begin the trial of causes.

column1: arthānarthāv ubhau buddhvā dharmādharmau ca kevalau / varṇakrameṇa sarvāṇi paśyet kāryāṇi kāryiṇām //
column2: Knowing what is expedient or inexpedient, what is pure justice or injustice, let him examine the causes of suitors according to the order of the castes (varna).

column1: bāhyair vibhāvayel liṅgair bhāvam antargataṃ nṛṇām / svaravarṇeṅgitākāraiś cakṣuṣā ceṣṭitena ca //
column2: By external signs let him discover the internal disposition of men, by their voice, their colour, their motions, their aspect, their eyes, and their gestures.

column1: ākārair iṅgitair gatyā ceṣṭayā bhāṣitena ca / netravaktravikāraiś ca gṛhyate 'ntargataṃ manaḥ //
column2: The internal (working of the) mind is perceived through the aspect, the motions, the gait, the gestures, the speech, and the changes in the eye and of the face.

column1: bāladāyādikaṃ rikthaṃ tāvad rājānupālayet / yāvat sa syāt samāvṛtto yāvac cātītaśaiśavaḥ //
column2: The king shall protect the inherited (and other) property of a minor, until he has returned (from his teacher's house) or until he has passed his minority.

column1: vaśāputrāsu caivaṃ syād rakṣaṇaṃ niṣkulāsu ca / pativratāsu ca strīṣu vidhavāsv āturāsu ca //
column2: In like manner care must be taken of barren women, of those who have no sons, of those whose family is extinct, of wives and widows faithful to their lords, and of women afflicted with diseases.

column1: jīvantīnāṃ tu tāsāṃ ye tad dhareyuḥ svabāndhavāḥ / tāñ śiṣyāc cauradaṇḍena dhārmikaḥ pṛthivīpatiḥ //
column2: A righteous king must punish like thieves those relatives who appropriate the property of such females during their lifetime.

column1: praṇaṣṭasvāmikaṃ rikthaṃ rājā tryabdaṃ nidhāpayet / arvāk tryabdād dharet svāmī pareṇa nṛpatir haret //
column2: Property, the owner of which has disappeared, the king shall cause to be kept as a deposit during three years; within the period of three years the owner may claim it, after (that term) the king may take it.

column1: mamedam iti yo brūyāt so 'nuyojyo yathāvidhi / saṃvādya rūpasaṃkhyādīn svāmī tad dravyam arhati //
column2: He who says, 'This belongs to me,' must be examined according to the rule; if he accurately describes the shape, and the number (of the articles found) and so forth, (he is) the owner, (and) ought (to receive) that property.

column1: avedayāno naṣṭasya deśaṃ kālaṃ ca tattvataḥ / varṇaṃ rūpaṃ pramāṇaṃ ca tatsamaṃ daṇḍam arhati //
column2: But if he does not really know the time and the place (where it was) lost, its colour, shape, and size, he is worthy of a fine equal (in value) to the (object claimed).

column1: ādadītātha ṣaḍbhāgaṃ pranaṣṭādhigatān nṛpaḥ / daśamaṃ dvādaśaṃ vāpi satāṃ dharmam anusmaran //
column2: Now the king, remembering the duty of good men, may take one-sixth part of property lost and afterwards found, or one-tenth, or at least one-twelfth.

column1: pranaṣṭādhigataṃ dravyaṃ tiṣṭhed yuktair adhiṣṭhitam / yāṃs tatra caurān gṛhṇīyāt tān rājebhena ghātayet //
column2: Property lost and afterwards found (by the king's servants) shall remain in the keeping of (special) officials; those whom the king may convict of stealing it, he shall cause to be slain by an elephant.

column1: mamāyam iti yo brūyān nidhiṃ satyena mānavaḥ / tasyādadīta ṣaḍbhāgaṃ rājā dvādaśam eva vā //
column2: From that man who shall truly say with respect to treasure-trove, 'This belongs to me,' the king may take one-sixth or one-twelfth part.

column1: anṛtaṃ tu vadan daṇḍyaḥ svavittasyāṃśam aṣṭamam / tasyaiva vā nidhānasya saṃkhyayālpīyasīṃ kalām //
column2: But he who falsely says (so), shall be fined in one-eighth of his property, or, a calculation of (the value of) the treasure having been made, in some smaller portion (of that).

column1: vidvāṃs tu brāhmaṇo dṛṣṭvā pūrvopanihitaṃ nidhim / aśeṣato 'py ādadīta sarvasyādhipatir hi saḥ //
column2: When a learned Brahmana has found treasure, deposited in former (times), he may take even the whole (of it); for he is master of everything.

column1: yaṃ tu paśyen nidhiṃ rājā purāṇaṃ nihitaṃ kṣitau / tasmād dvijebhyo dattvārdham ardhaṃ kośe praveśayet //
column2: When the king finds treasure of old concealed in the ground let him give one half to Brahmanas and place the (other) half in his treasury.

column1: nidhīnāṃ tu purāṇānāṃ dhātūnām eva ca kṣitau / ardhabhāg rakṣaṇād rājā bhūmer adhipatir hi saḥ // dātavyaṃ sarvavarṇebhyo rājñā caurair hṛtaṃ dhanam / rājā tad upayuñjānaś caurasyāpnoti kilbiṣam //
column2: The king obtains one half of ancient hoards and metals (found) in the ground, by reason of (his giving) protection, (and) because he is the lord of the soil. Property stolen by thieves must be restored by the king to (men of) all castes (varna); a king who uses such (property) for himself incurs the guilt of a thief.

column1: jātijānapadān dharmān śreṇīdharmāṃś ca dharmavit / samīkṣya kuladharmāṃś ca svadharmaṃ pratipādayet //
column2: (A king) who knows the sacred law, must inquire into the laws of castes (gati), of districts, of guilds, and of families, and (thus) settle the peculiar law of each.

column1: svāni karmāṇi kurvāṇā dūre santo 'pi mānavāḥ / priyā bhavanti lokasya sve sve karmaṇy avasthitāḥ //
column2: For men who follow their particular occupations and abide by their particular duty, become dear to people, though they may live at a distance.

column1: notpādayet svayaṃ kāryaṃ rājā nāpy asya puruṣaḥ / na ca prāpitam anyena grased arthaṃ kathaṃ cana //
column2: Neither the king nor any servant of his shall themselves cause a lawsuit to be begun, or hush up one that has been brought (before them) by (some) other (man).

column1: yathā nayaty asṛkpātair mṛgasya mṛgayuḥ padam / nayet tathānumānena dharmasya nṛpatiḥ padam //
column2: As a hunter traces the lair of a (wounded) deer by the drops of blood, even so the king shall discover on which side the right lies, by inferences (from the facts).

column1: satyam arthaṃ ca saṃpaśyed ātmānam atha sākṣiṇaḥ / deśaṃ rūpaṃ ca kālaṃ ca vyavahāravidhau sthitaḥ //
column2: When engaged in judicial proceedings he must pay full attention to the truth, to the object (of the dispute), (and) to himself, next to the witnesses, to the place, to the time, and to the aspect.

column1: sadbhir ācaritaṃ yat syād dhārmikaiś ca dvijātibhiḥ / tad deśakulajātīnām aviruddhaṃ prakalpayet //
column2: What may have been practised by the virtuous, by such twice-born men as are devoted to the law, that he shall establish as law, if it be not opposed to the (customs of) countries, families, and castes (gati).

column1: adhamarṇārthasiddhyartham uttamarṇena coditaḥ / dāpayed dhanikasyārtham adhamarṇād vibhāvitam //
column2: When a creditor sues (before the king) for the recovery of money from a debtor, let him make the debtor pay the sum which the creditor proves (to be due).

column1: yair yair upāyair arthaṃ svaṃ prāpnuyād uttamarṇikaḥ / tair tair upāyaiḥ saṃgṛhya dāpayed adhamarṇikam //
column2: By whatever means a creditor may be able to obtain possession of his property, even by those means may he force the debtor and make him pay.

column1: dharmeṇa vyavahāreṇa chalenācaritena ca / prayuktaṃ sādhayed arthaṃ pañcamena balena ca //
column2: By moral suasion, by suit of law, by artful management, or by the customary proceeding, a creditor may recover property lent; and fifthly, by force.

column1: yaḥ svayaṃ sādhayed artham uttamarṇo 'dhamarṇikāt / na sa rājñābhiyoktavyaḥ svakaṃ saṃsādhayan dhanam //
column2: A creditor who himself recovers his property from his debtor, must not be blamed by the king for retaking what is his own.

column1: arthe 'pavyayamānaṃ tu karaṇena vibhāvitam / dāpayed dhanikasyārthaṃ daṇḍaleśaṃ ca śaktitaḥ // apahnave 'dhamarṇasya dehīty uktasya saṃsadi / abhiyoktā diśed deśyaṃ karaṇaṃ vānyad uddiśet //
column2: But him who denies a debt which is proved by good evidence, he shall order to pay that debt to the creditor and a small fine according to his circumstances. On the denial (of a debt) by a debtor who has been required in court to pay it, the complainant must call (a witness) who was present (when the loan was made), or adduce other evidence.

column1: adeśyaṃ yaś ca diśati nirdiśyāpahnute ca yaḥ / yaś cādharottarān arthān vigītān nāvabudhyate //
column2: (The plaintiff) who calls a witness not present at the transaction, who retracts his statements, or does not perceive that his statements (are) confused or contradictory;

column1: apadiśyāpadeśyaṃ ca punar yas tv apadhāvati / samyak praṇihitaṃ cārthaṃ pṛṣṭaḥ san nābhinandati //
column2: Or who having stated what he means to prove afterwards varies (his case), or who being questioned on a fact duly stated by himself does not abide by it;

column1: asaṃbhāṣye sākṣibhiś ca deśe saṃbhāṣate mithaḥ / nirucyamānaṃ praśnaṃ ca necched yaś cāpi niṣpatet //
column2: Or who converses with the witnesses in a place improper for such conversation; or who declines to answer a question, properly put, or leaves (the court);

column1: brūhīty uktaś ca na brūyād uktaṃ ca na vibhāvayet / na ca pūrvāparaṃ vidyāt tasmād arthāt sa hīyate //
column2: Or who, being ordered to speak, does not answer, or does not prove what he has alleged; or who does not know what is the first (point), and what the second, fails in his suit.

column1: sākṣiṇaḥ santi mety uktvā diśety ukto diśen na yaḥ / dharmasthaḥ kāraṇair etair hīnaṃ tam api nirdiśet //
column2: Him also who says 'I have witnesses,' and, being ordered to produce them, produces them not, the judge must on these (same) grounds declare to be non-suited.

column1: abhiyoktā na ced brūyād badhyo daṇḍyaś ca dharmataḥ / na cet tripakṣāt prabrūyād dharmaṃ prati parājitaḥ //
column2: If a plaintiff does not speak, he may be punished corporally or fined according to the law; if (a defendant) does not plead within three fortnights, he has lost his cause.

column1: yo yāvan nihnuvītārthaṃ mithyā yāvati vā vadet / tau nṛpeṇa hy adharmajñau dāpyo taddviguṇaṃ damam //
column2: In the double of that sum which (a defendant) falsely denies or on which (the plaintiff) falsely declares, shall those two (men) offending against justice be fined by the king.

column1: pṛṣṭo 'pavyayamānas tu kṛtāvastho dhanaiṣiṇā / tryavaraiḥ sākṣibhir bhāvyo nṛpabrāhmaṇasaṃnidhau //
column2: (A defendant) who, being brought (into court) by the creditor, (and) being questioned, denies (the debt), shall be convicted (of his falsehood) by at least three witnesses (who must depose) in the presence of the Brahmana (appointed by) the king.

column1: yādṛśā dhanibhiḥ kāryā vyavahāreṣu sākṣiṇaḥ / tādṛśān saṃpravakṣyāmi yathā vācyam ṛtaṃ ca taiḥ //
column2: I will fully declare what kind of men may be made witnesses in suits by creditors, and in what manner those (witnesses) must give true (evidence).

column1: gṛhiṇaḥ putriṇo maulāḥ kṣatraviśśūdrayonayaḥ / arthyuktāḥ sākṣyam arhanti na ye ke cid anāpadi //
column2: Householders, men with male issue, and indigenous (inhabitants of the country, be they) Kshatriyas, Vaisyas, or Sudras, are competent, when called by a suitor, to give evidence, not any persons whatever (their condition may be) except in cases of urgency.

column1: āptāḥ sarveṣu varṇeṣu kāryāḥ kāryeṣu sākṣiṇaḥ / sarvadharmavido 'lubdhā viparītāṃs tu varjayet //
column2: Trustworthy men of all the (four) castes (varna) may be made witnesses in lawsuits, (men) who know (their) whole duty, and are free from covetousness; but let him reject those (of an) opposite (character).

column1: nārthasaṃbandhino nāptā na sahāyā na vairiṇaḥ / na dṛṣṭadoṣāḥ kartavyā na vyādhyārtā na dūṣitāḥ //
column2: Those must not be made (witnesses) who have an interest in the suit, nor familiar (friends), companions, and enemies (of the parties), nor (men) formerly convicted (of perjury), nor (persons) suffering under (severe) illness, nor (those) tainted (by mortal sin).

column1: na sākṣī nṛpatiḥ kāryo na kārukakuśīlavau / na śrotriyo na liṅgastho na saṅgebhyo vinirgataḥ // nādhyadhīno na vaktavyo na dasyur na vikarmakṛt / na vṛddho na śiśur naiko nāntyo na vikalendriyaḥ //
column2: The king cannot be made a witness, nor mechanics and actors, nor a: Srotriya, nor a student of the Veda, nor (an ascetic) who has given up (all) connexion (with the world), Nor one wholly dependent, nor one of bad fame, nor a Dasyu, nor one who follows forbidden occupations, nor an aged (man), nor an infant, nor one (man alone), nor a man of the lowest castes, nor one deficient in organs of sense,

column1: nārto na matto nonmatto na kṣuttṛṣṇopapīḍitaḥ / na śramārto na kāmārto na kruddho nāpi taskaraḥ //
column2: Nor one extremely grieved, nor one intoxicated, nor a madman, nor one tormented by hunger or thirst, nor one oppressed by fatigue, nor one tormented by desire, nor a wrathful man, nor a thief.

column1: strīṇāṃ sākṣyaṃ striyaḥ kuryur dvijānāṃ sadṛśā dvijāḥ / śūdrāś ca santaḥ śūdrāṇām antyānām antyayonayaḥ //
column2: Women should give evidence for women, and for twice-born men twice-born men (of the) same (kind), virtuous Sudras for Sudras, and men of the lowest castes for the lowest.

column1: anubhāvī tu yaḥ kaś cit kuryāt sākṣyaṃ vivādinām / antarveśmany araṇye vā śarīrasyāpi cātyaye //
column2: But any person whatsoever, who has personal knowledge (of an act committed) in the interior apartments (of a house), or in a forest, or of (a crime causing) loss of life, may give evidence between the parties.

column1: striyāpy asaṃbhāve kāryaṃ bālena sthavireṇa vā / śiṣyeṇa bandhunā vāpi dāsena bhṛtakena vā //
column2: On failure (of qualified witnesses, evidence) may given (in such cases) by a woman, by an infant, by an aged man, by a pupil, by a relative, by a slave, or by a hired servant.

column1: bālavṛddhāturāṇāṃ ca sākṣyeṣu vadatāṃ mṛṣā / jānīyād asthirāṃ vācam utsiktamanasāṃ tathā //
column2: But the (judge) should consider the evidence of infants, aged and diseased men, who (are apt to) speak untruly, as untrustworthy, likewise that of men with disordered minds.

column1: sāhaseṣu ca sarveṣu steyasaṃgrahaṇeṣu ca / vāgdaṇḍayoś ca pāruṣye na parīkṣeta sākṣiṇaḥ //
column2: In all cases of violence, of theft and adultery, of defamation and assault, he must not examine the (competence of) witnesses (too strictly).

column1: bahutvaṃ parigṛhṇīyāt sākṣidvaidhe narādhipaḥ / sameṣu tu guṇotkṛṣṭān guṇidvaidhe dvijottamān //
column2: On a conflict of the witnesses the king shall accept (as true) the evidence of the) majority; if (the conflicting parties are) equal in number, (that of) those distinguished by good qualities; on a difference between (equally) distinguished (witnesses, that of) the best among the twice-born.

column1: samakṣadarśanāt sākṣyaṃ śravaṇāc caiva sidhyati / tatra satyaṃ bruvan sākṣī dharmārthābhyāṃ na hīyate //
column2: Evidence in accordance with what has actually been seen or heard, is admissible; a witness who speaks truth in those (cases), neither loses spiritual merit nor wealth.

column1: sākṣī dṛṣṭaśrutād anyad vibruvann āryasaṃsadi / avāṅ narakam abhyeti pretya svargāc ca hīyate //
column2: A witness who deposes in an assembly of honourable men (Arya) anything else but what he has seen or heard, falls after death headlong into hell and loses heaven.

column1: yatrānibaddho 'pīkṣeta śṛṇuyād vāpi kiṃ cana / pṛṣṭas tatrāpi tad brūyād yathādṛṣṭaṃ yathāśrutam //
column2: When a man (originally) not appointed to be a witness sees or hears anything and is (afterwards) examined regarding it, he must declare it (exactly) as he saw or heard it.

column1: eko 'lubdhas tu sākṣī syād bahvyaḥ śucyo 'pi na striyaḥ / strībuddher asthiratvāt tu doṣaiś cānye 'pi ye vṛtāḥ //
column2: One man who is free from covetousness may be (accepted as) witness; but not even many pure women, because the understanding of females is apt to waver, nor even many other men, who are tainted with sin.

column1: svabhāvenaiva yad brūyus tad grāhyaṃ vyāvahārikam / ato yad anyad vibrūyur dharmārthaṃ tad apārthakam //
column2: What witnesses declare quite naturally, that must be received on trials; (depositions) differing from that, which they make improperly, are worthless for (the purposes of) justice.

column1: sabhāntaḥ sākṣiṇaḥ prāptān arthipratyarthisaṃnidhau / prāḍvivāko 'nuyuñjīta vidhinānena sāntvayan //
column2: The witnesses being assembled in the court in the presence of the plaintiff and of the defendant, let the judge examine them, kindly exhorting them in the following manner:

column1: yad dvayor anayor vettha kārye 'smiṃś ceṣṭitaṃ mithaḥ / tad brūta sarvaṃ satyena yuṣmākaṃ hy atra sākṣitā //
column2: 'What ye know to have been mutually transacted in this matter between the two men before us, declare all that in accordance with the truth; for ye are witnesses in this (cause).

column1: satyaṃ sākṣye bruvan sākṣī lokān āpnoti puṣkalān / iha cānuttamāṃ kīrtiṃ vāg eṣā brahmapūjitā //
column2: 'A witness who speaks the truth in his evidence, gains (after death) the most excellent regions (of bliss) and here (below) unsurpassable fame; such testimony is revered by Brahman (himself).

column1: sākṣye 'nṛtaṃ vadan pāśair badhyate vāruṇair bhṛśam / vivaśaḥ śatam ājātīs tasmāt sākṣyaṃ vaded ṛtam //
column2: 'He who gives false evidence is firmly bound by Varuna's fetters, helpless during one hundred existences; let (men therefore) give true evidence.

column1: satyena pūyate sākṣī dharmaḥ satyena vardhate / tasmāt satyaṃ hi vaktavyaṃ sarvavarṇeṣu sākṣibhiḥ //
column2: 'By truthfulness a witness is purified, through truthfulness his merit grows, truth must, therefore, be spoken by witnesses of all castes (varna).

column1: ātmaiva hy ātmanaḥ sākṣī gatir ātmā tathātmanaḥ / māvamaṃsthāḥ svam ātmānaṃ nṛṇāṃ sākṣiṇam uttamam //
column2: 'The Soul itself is the witness of the Soul, and the Soul is the refuge of the Soul; despise not thy own Soul, the supreme witness of men.

column1: manyante vai pāpakṛto na kaś cit paśyatīti naḥ / tāṃs tu devāḥ prapaśyanti svasyaivāntarapūruṣaḥ //
column2: 'The wicked, indeed, say in their hearts, "Nobody sees us;" but the gods distinctly see them and the male within their own breasts.

column1: dyaur bhūmir āpo hṛdayaṃ candrārkāgniyamānilāḥ / rātriḥ saṃdhye ca dharmaś ca vṛttajñāḥ sarvadehinām //
column2: 'The sky, the earth, the waters, (the male in) the heart, the moon, the sun, the fire, Yama and the wind, the night, the two twilights, and justice know the conduct of all corporeal beings.'

column1: devabrāhmaṇasāṃnidhye sākṣyaṃ pṛcched ṛtaṃ dvijān / udaṅmukhān prāṅmukhān vā pūrvāhṇe vai śuciḥ śucīn //
column2: The (judge), being purified, shall ask in the forenoon the twice-born (witnesses) who (also have been) purified, (and stand) facing the north or the east, to give true evidence in the presence of (images of) the gods and of Brahmanas.

column1: brūhīti brāhmaṇaṃ pṛcchet satyaṃ brūhīti pārthivam / gobījakāñcanair vaiśyaṃ śūdraṃ sarvais tu pātakaiḥ //
column2: Let him examine a Brahmana (beginning with) 'Speak,' a Kshatriya (beginning with) 'Speak the truth,' a Vaisya (admonishing him) by (mentioning) his kine, grain, and gold, a Sudra (threatening him) with (the guilt of) every crime that causes loss of caste;

column1: brahmaghno ye smṛtā lokā ye ca strībālaghātinaḥ / mitradruhaḥ kṛtaghnasya te te syur bruvato mṛṣā //
column2: (Saying), 'Whatever places (of torment) are assigned (by the sages) to the slayer of a Brahmana, to the murderer of women and children, to him who betrays a friend, and to an ungrateful man, those shall be thy (portion), if thou speakest falsely.

column1: janmaprabhṛti yat kiṃ cit puṇyaṃ bhadra tvayā kṛtam / tat te sarvaṃ śuno gacched yadi brūyās tvam anyathā //
column2: '(The reward) of all meritorious deeds which thou, good man, hast done since thy birth, shall become the share of the dogs, if in thy speech thou departest from the truth.

column1: eko 'ham asmīty ātmānaṃ yas tvaṃ kalyāṇa manyase / nityaṃ sthitas te hṛdy eṣa puṇyapāpekṣitā muniḥ //
column2: 'If thou thinkest, O friend of virtue, with respect to thyself, "I am alone," (know that) that sage who witnesses all virtuous acts and all crimes, ever resides in thy heart.

column1: yamo vaivasvato devo yas tavaiṣa hṛdi sthitaḥ / tena ced avivādas te mā gaṅgāṃ mā kurūn gamaḥ //
column2: 'If thou art not at variance with that divine Yama, the son of Vivasvat, who dwells in thy heart, thou needest neither visit the Ganges nor the (land of the) Kurus.

column1: nagno muṇḍaḥ kapālena ca bhikṣārthī kṣutpipāsitaḥ / andhaḥ śatrukulaṃ gacched yaḥ sākṣyam anṛtaṃ vadet // avākśirās tamasy andhe kilbiṣī narakaṃ vrajet / yaḥ praśnaṃ vitathaṃ brūyāt pṛṣṭaḥ san dharmaniścaye // andho matsyān ivāśnāti sa naraḥ kaṇṭakaiḥ saha / yo bhāṣate 'rthavaikalyam apratyakṣaṃ sabhāṃ gataḥ //
column2: 'Naked and shorn, tormented with hunger and thirst, and deprived of sight, shall the man who gives false evidence, go with a potsherd to beg food at the door of his enemy. 'Headlong, in utter darkness shall the sinful man tumble into hell, who being interrogated in a judicial inquiry answers one question falsely. 'That man who in a court (of justice) gives an untrue account of a transaction (or asserts a fact) of which he was not an eye-witness, resembles a blind man who swallows fish with the bones.

column1: yasya vidvān hi vadataḥ kṣetrajño nābhiśaṅkate / tasmān na devāḥ śreyāṃsaṃ loke 'nyaṃ puruṣaṃ viduḥ //
column2: 'The gods are acquainted with no better man in this world than him, of whom his conscious Soul has no distrust, when he gives evidence.

column1: yāvato bāndhavān yasmin hanti sākṣye 'nṛtaṃ vadan / tāvataḥ saṃkhyayā tasmin śṛṇu saumyānupūrvaśaḥ //
column2: 'Learn now, O friend, from an enumeration in due order, how many relatives he destroys who gives false evidence in several particular cases.

column1: pañca paśvanṛte hanti daśa hanti gavānṛte / śatam aśvānṛte hanti sahasraṃ puruṣānṛte //
column2: 'He kills five by false Testimony regarding (small) cattle, he kills ten by false testimony regarding kine, he kills a hundred by false evidence concerning horses, and a thousand by false evidence concerning men.

column1: hanti jātān ajātāṃś ca hiraṇyārthe 'nṛtaṃ vadan / sarvaṃ bhūmyanṛte hanti mā sma bhūmyanṛtaṃ vadīḥ //
column2: 'By speaking falsely in a cause regarding gold, he kills the born and the unborn; by false evidence concerning land, he kills everything; beware, therefore, of false evidence concerning land.

column1: apsu bhūmivad ity āhuḥ strīṇāṃ bhoge ca maithune / abjeṣu caiva ratneṣu sarveṣv aśmamayeṣu ca //
column2: 'They declare (false evidence) concerning water, concerning the carnal enjoyment of women, and concerning all gems, produced in water, or consisting of stones (to be) equally (wicked) as a lie concerning land.

column1: etān doṣān avekṣya tvaṃ sarvān anṛtabhāṣaṇe / yathāśrutaṃ yathādṛṣṭaṃ sarvam evāñjasā vada //
column2: 'Marking well all the evils (which are produced) by perjury, declare thou openly everything as (thou hast) heard or seen (it).'

column1: gorakṣakān vāṇijikāṃs tathā kārukuśīlavān / preṣyān vārdhuṣikāṃś caiva viprān śūdravad ācaret //
column2: Brahmanas who tend cattle, who trade, who are mechanics, actors (or singers), menial servants or usurers, the (judge) shall treat like Sudras.

column1: tad vadan dharmato 'rtheṣu jānann apy anythā naraḥ / na svargāc cyavate lokād daivīṃ vācaṃ vadanti tām //
column2: In (some) cases a man who, though knowing (the facts to be) different, gives such (false evidence) from a pious motive, does not lose heaven; such (evidence) they call the speech of the gods.

column1: śūdraviṭkṣatraviprāṇāṃ yatra rtoktau bhaved vadhaḥ / tatra vaktavyam anṛtaṃ tad dhi satyād viśiṣyate //
column2: Whenever the death of a Sudra, of a Vaisya, of a Kshatriya, or of a Brahmana would be (caused) by a declaration of the truth, a falsehood may be spoken; for such (falsehood) is preferable to the truth.

column1: vāggaivatyaiś ca carubhir yajeraṃs te sarasvatīm / anṛtasyainasas tasya kurvāṇā niṣkṛtiṃ parām //
column2: Such (witnesses) must offer to Sarasvati oblations of boiled rice (karu) which are sacred to the goddess of speech, (thus) performing the best penance in order to expiate the guilt of that falsehood.

column1: kūṣmāṇḍair vāpi juhuyād ghṛtam agnau yathāvidhi / ud ity ṛcā vā vāruṇyā tṛcenābdaivatena vā //
column2: Or such (a witness) may offer according to the rule, clarified butter in the fire, reciting the Kushmanda texts, or the Rik, sacred to Varuna, 'Untie, O Varuna, the uppermost fetter,' or the three verses addressed to the Waters.

column1: tripakṣād abruvan sākṣyam ṛṇādiṣu naro 'gadaḥ / tadṛṇaṃ prāpnuyāt sarvaṃ daśabandhaṃ ca sarvataḥ //
column2: A man who, without being ill, does not give evidence in (cases of) loans and the like within three fortnights (after the summons), shall become responsible for the whole debt and (pay) a tenth part of the whole (as a fine to the king).

column1: yasya dṛśyeta saptāhād uktavākyasya sākṣiṇaḥ / rogo 'gnir jñātimaraṇam ṛṇaṃ dāpyo damaṃ ca saḥ //
column2: The witness to whom, within seven days after he has given evidence, happens (a misfortune through) sickness, a fire, or the death of a relative, shall be made to pay the debt and a fine.

column1: asākṣikeṣu tv artheṣu mitho vivādamānayoḥ / avindaṃs tattvataḥ satyaṃ śapathenāpi lambhayet //
column2: If two (parties) dispute about matters for which no witnesses are available, and the (judge) is unable to really ascertain the truth, he may cause it to be discovered even by an oath.

column1: maharṣibhiś ca devaiś ca kāryārthaṃ śapathāḥ kṛtāḥ / vasiṣṭhaś cāpi śapathaṃ śepe paijavane nṛpe //
column2: Both by the great sages and the gods oaths have been taken for the purpose of (deciding doubtful) matters; and Vasishtha even swore an oath before king (Sudas), the son of Pigavana.

column1: na vṛthā śapathaṃ kuryāt svalpe 'py arthe naro budhaḥ / vṛthā hi śapathaṃ kurvan pretya ceha ca naśyati //
column2: Let no wise man swear an oath falsely, even in a trifling matter; for he who swears an oath falsely is lost in this (world) and after death.

column1: kāminīṣu vivāheṣu gavāṃ bhakṣye tathendhane / brāhmaṇābhyupapattau ca śapathe nāsti pātakam //
column2: No crime, causing loss of caste, is committed by swearing (falsely) to women, the objects of one's desire, at marriages, for the sake of fodder for a cow, or of fuel, and in (order to show) favour to a Brahmana.

column1: satyena śāpayed vipraṃ kṣatriyaṃ vāhanāyudhaiḥ / gobījakāñcanair vaiśyaṃ śūdraṃ sarvais tu pātakaiḥ //
column2: Let the (judge) cause a Brahmana to swear by his veracity, a Kshatriya by his chariot or the animal he rides on and by his weapons, a Vaisya by his kine, grain, and gold, and a Sudra by (imprecating on his own head the guilt) of all grievous offences (pataka).

column1: agniṃ vāhārayed enam apsu cainaṃ nimajjayet / putradārasya vāpy enaṃ śirāṃsi sparśayet pṛthak //
column2: Or the (judge) may cause the (party) to carry fire or to dive under water, or severally to touch the heads of his wives and children.

column1: yam iddho na dahaty agnir āpo nonmajjayanti ca / na cārtim ṛcchati kṣipraṃ sa jñeyaḥ śapathe śuciḥ //
column2: He whom the blazing fire burns not, whom the water forces not to come (quickly) up, who meets with no speedy misfortune, must be held innocent on (the strength of) his oath.

column1: vatsasya hy abhiśastasya purā bhrātrā yavīyasā / nāgnir dadāha romāpi satyena jagataḥ spaśaḥ //
column2: For formerly when Vatsa was accused by his younger brother, the fire, the spy of the world, burned not even a hair (of his) by reason of his veracity.

column1: yasmin yasmin vivāde tu kauṭasākṣyaṃ kṛtaṃ bhavet / tat tat kāryaṃ nivarteta kṛtaṃ cāpy akṛtaṃ bhavet //
column2: Whenever false evidence has been given in any suit, let the (judge) reverse the judgment, and whatever has been done must be (considered as) undone.

column1: lobhān mohād bhayān maitrāt kāmāt krodhāt tathaiva ca / ajñānād bālabhāvāc ca sākṣyaṃ vitatham ucyate //
column2: Evidence (given) from covetousness, distraction, terror, friendship, lust, wrath, ignorance, and childishness is declared (to be) invalid.

column1: eṣām anyatame sthāne yaḥ sākṣyam anṛtaṃ vadet / tasya daṇḍaviśeṣāṃs tu pravakṣyāmy anupūrvaśaḥ //
column2: I will propound in (due) order the particular punishments for him who gives false evidence from any one of these motives.

column1: lobhāt sahasraṃ daṇḍyas tu mohāt pūrvaṃ tu sāhasam / bhayād dvau madhyamau daṇḍau maitrāt pūrvaṃ caturguṇam //
column2: (He who commits perjury) through covetousness shall be fined one thousand (panas), (he who does it) through distraction, in the lowest amercement; (if a man does it) through fear, two middling amercements shall be paid as a fine, (if he does it) through friendship, four times the amount of the lowest (amercement).

column1: kāmād daśaguṇaṃ pūrvaṃ krodhāt tu triguṇaṃ param / ajñānād dve śate pūrṇe bāliśyāc chatam eva tu //
column2: (He who does it) through lust, (shall pay) ten times the lowest amercement, but (he who does it) through wrath, three times the next (or second amercement); (he who does it) through ignorance, two full hundreds, but (he who does it) through childishness, one hundred (panas).

column1: etān āhuḥ kauṭasākṣye proktān daṇḍān manīṣibhiḥ / dharmasyāvyabhicārārtham adharmaniyamāya ca //
column2: They declare that the wise have prescribed these fines for perjury, in order to prevent a failure of justice, and in order to restrain injustice.

column1: kauṭasākṣyaṃ tu kurvāṇāṃs trīn varṇān dhārmiko nṛpaḥ / pravāsayed daṇḍayitvā brāhmaṇaṃ tu vivāsayet //
column2: But a just king shall fine and banish (men of) the three (lower) castes (varna) who have given false evidence, but a Brahmana he shall (only) banish.

column1: daśa sthānāni daṇḍasya manuḥ svayaṃbhuvo 'bravīt / triṣu varṇeṣu yāni syur akṣato brāhmaṇo vrajet //
column2: Manu, the son of the Self-existent (Svayambhu), has named ten places on which punishment may be (made to fall) in the cases of the three (lower) castes (varna); but a Brahmana shall depart unhurt (from the country).

column1: upastham udaraṃ jihvā hastau pādau ca pañcamam / cakṣur nāsā ca karṇau ca dhanaṃ dehas tathaiva ca //
column2: (These are) the organ, the belly, the tongue, the two hands, and fifthly the two feet, the eye, the nose, the two ears, likewise the (whole) body.

column1: anubandhaṃ parijñāya deśakālau ca tattvataḥ / sārāparādho cālokya daṇḍaṃ daṇḍyeṣu pātayet //
column2: Let the (king), having fully ascertained the motive, the time and place (of the offence), and having considered the ability (of the criminal to suffer) and the (nature of the) crime, cause punishment to fall on those who deserve it.

column1: adharmadaṇḍanaṃ loke yaśoghnaṃ kīrtināśanam / asvargyaṃ ca paratrāpi tasmāt tat parivarjayet //
column2: Unjust punishment destroys reputation among men, and fame (after death), and causes even in the next world the loss of heaven; let him, therefore, beware of (inflicting) it.

column1: adaṇḍyān daṇḍayan rājā daṇḍyāṃś caivāpy adaṇḍayan / ayaśo mahad āpnoti narakaṃ caiva gacchati //
column2: A king who punishes those who do not deserve it, and punishes not those who deserve it, brings great infamy on himself and (after death) sinks into hell.

column1: vāgdaṇḍaṃ prathamaṃ kuryād dhigdaṇḍaṃ tadanantaram / tṛtīyaṃ dhanadaṇḍaṃ tu vadhadaṇḍam ataḥ param //
column2: Let him punish first by (gentle) admonition, afterwards by (harsh) reproof, thirdly by a fine, after that by corporal chastisement.

column1: vadhenāpi yadā tv etān nigrahītuṃ na śaknuyāt / tadaiṣu sarvam apy etat prayuñjīta catuṣṭayam //
column2: But when he cannot restrain such (offenders) even by corporal punishment, then let him apply to them even all the four (modes cojointly).

column1: lokasaṃvyavahārārthaṃ yāḥ saṃjñāḥ prathitā bhuvi / tāmrarūpyasuvarṇānāṃ tāḥ pravakṣyāmy aśeṣataḥ //
column2: Those technical names of (certain quantities of) copper, silver, and gold, which are generally used on earth for the purpose of business transactions among men, I will fully declare.

column1: jālāntaragate bhānau yat sūkṣmaṃ dṛśyate rajaḥ / prathamaṃ tat pramāṇānāṃ trasareṇuṃ pracakṣate //
column2: The very small mote which is seen when the sun shines through a lattice, they declare (to be) the least of (all) quantities and (to be called) a trasarenu (a floating particle of dust).

column1: trasareṇavo 'ṣṭau vijñeyā likṣaikā parimāṇataḥ / tā rājasarṣapas tisras te trayo gaurasarṣapaḥ //
column2: Know (that) eight trasarenus (are equal) in bulk (to) a liksha (the egg of a louse), three of those to one grain of black mustard (ragasarshapa), and three of the latter to a white mustard-seed.

column1: sarṣapāḥ ṣaḍ yavo madhyas triyavaṃ tv ekakṛṣṇalam / pañcakṛṣṇalako māṣas te suvarṇas tu ṣoḍaśa //
column2: Six grains of white mustard are one middle-sized barley-corn, and three barley-corns one krishnala (raktika, or gunga-berry); five krishnalas are one masha (bean), and sixteen of those one suvarna.

column1: palaṃ suvarṇāś catvāraḥ palāni dharaṇaṃ daśa / dve kṛṣṇale samadhṛte vijñeyo raupyamāṣakaḥ //
column2: Four suvarnas are one pala, and ten palas one dharana; two krishnalas (of silver), weighed together, must be considered one mashaka of silver.

column1: te ṣoḍaśa syād dharaṇaṃ purāṇaś caiva rājataḥ / kārṣāpaṇas tu vijñeyas tāmrikaḥ kārṣikaḥ paṇaḥ //
column2: Sixteen of those make a silver dharana, or purana; but know (that) a karsha of copper is a karshapana, or pana.

column1: dharaṇāni daśa jñeyaḥ śatamānas tu rājataḥ / catuḥsauvarṇiko niṣko vijñeyas tu pramāṇataḥ //
column2: Know (that) ten dharanas of silver make one satamana; four suvarnas must be considered (equal) in weight to a nishka.

column1: paṇānāṃ dve śate sārdhe prathamaḥ sāhasaḥ smṛtaḥ / madhyamaḥ pañca vijñeyaḥ sahasraṃ tv eva cottamaḥ //
column2: Two hundred and fifty panas are declared (to be) the first (or lowest) amercement, five (hundred) are considered as the mean (or middlemost), but one thousand as the highest.

column1: ṛṇe deye pratijñāte pañcakaṃ śatam arhati / apahnave taddviguṇaṃ tan manor anuśāsanam //
column2: A debt being admitted as due, (the defendant) shall pay five in the hundred (as a fine), if it be denied (and proved) twice as much; that is the teaching of Manu.

column1: vasiṣṭhavihitāṃ vṛddhiṃ sṛjed vittavivardhinīm / aśītibhāgaṃ gṛhṇīyān māsād vārdhuṣikaḥ śate //
column2: A money-lender may stipulate as an increase of his capital, for the interest, allowed by Vasishtha, and take monthly the eightieth part of a hundred.

column1: dvikaṃ śataṃ vā gṛhṇīyāt satāṃ dharmam anusmaran / dvikaṃ śataṃ hi gṛhṇāno na bhavaty arthakilbiṣī //
column2: Or, remembering the duty of good men, he may take two in the hundred (by the month), for he who takes two in the hundred becomes not a sinner for gain.

column1: dvikaṃ trikaṃ catuṣkaṃ ca pañcakaṃ ca śataṃ samam / māsasya vṛddhiṃ gṛhṇīyād varṇānām anupūrvaśaḥ //
column2: Just two in the hundred, three, four, and five (and not more), he may take as monthly interest according to the order of the castes (varna).

column1: na tv evādhau sopakāre kausīdīṃ vṛddhim āpnuyāt / na cādheḥ kālasaṃrodhān nisargo 'sti na vikrayaḥ // na bhoktavyo balād ādhir bhuñjāno vṛddhim utsṛjet / mūlyena toṣayec cainam ādhisteno 'nyathā bhavet //
column2: But if a beneficial pledge (i.e. one from which profit accrues, has been given), he shall receive no interest on the loan; nor can he, after keeping (such) a pledge for a very long time, give or sell it. A pledge (to be kept only) must not be used by force, (the creditor), so using it, shall give up his (whole) interest, or, (if it has been spoilt by use) he shall satisfy the (owner) by (paying its) original price; else he commits a theft of the pledge.

column1: ādhiś copanidhiś cobhau na kālātyayam arhataḥ / avahāryau bhavetāṃ tau dīrghakālam avasthitau // saṃprītyā bhujyamānāni na naśyanti kadā cana / dhenur uṣṭro vahann aśvo yaś ca damyaḥ prayujyate //
column2: Neither a pledge nor a deposit can be lost by lapse of time; they are both recoverable, though they have remained long (with the bailee). Things used with friendly assent, a cow, a camel, a riding-horse, and (a beast) made over for breaking in, are never lost (to the owner).

column1: yat kiṃ cid daśavarṣāṇi saṃnidhau prekṣate dhanī / bhujyamānaṃ parais tūṣṇīṃ na sa tal labdhum arhati //
column2: (But in general) whatever (chattel) an owner sees enjoyed by others during ten years, while, though present, he says nothing, that (chattel) he shall not recover.

column1: ajaḍaś ced apogaṇḍo viṣaye cāsya bhujyate / bhagnaṃ tad vyavahāreṇa bhoktā tad dravyam arhati //
column2: If (the owner is) neither an idiot nor a minor and if (his chattel) is enjoyed (by another) before his eyes, it is lost to him by law; the adverse possessor shall retain that property.

column1: ādhiḥ sīmā bāladhanaṃ nikṣepopanidhiḥ striyaḥ / rājasvaṃ śrotriyasvaṃ ca na bhogena praṇaśyati //
column2: A pledge, a boundary, the property of infants, an (open) deposit, a sealed deposit, women, the property of the king and the wealth of a Srotriya are not lost in consequence of (adverse) enjoyment.

column1: yaḥ svāminānanujñātam ādhiṃ bhūṅkte 'vicakṣaṇaḥ / tenārdhavṛddhir moktavyā tasya bhogasya niṣkṛtiḥ //
column2: The fool who uses a pledge without the permission of the owner, shall remit half of his interest, as a compensation for (such) use.

column1: kusīdavṛddhir dvaiguṇyaṃ nātyeti sakṛd āhṛtā / dhānye sade lave vāhye nātikrāmati pañcatām //
column2: In money transactions interest paid at one time (not by instalments) shall never exceed the double (of the principal); on grain, fruit, wool or hair, (and) beasts of burden it must not be more than five times (the original amount).

column1: kṛtānusārād adhikā vyatiriktā na sidhyati / kusīdapatham āhus taṃ pañcakaṃ śatam arhati //
column2: Stipulated interest beyond the legal rate, being against (the law), cannot be recovered; they call that a usurious way (of lending); (the lender) is (in no case) entitled to (more than) five in the hundred.

column1: nātisāṃvatsarīṃ vṛddhiṃ na cādṛṣṭāṃ punar haret / cakravṛddhiḥ kālavṛddhiḥ kāritā kāyikā ca yā //
column2: Let him not take interest beyond the year, nor such as is unapproved, nor compound interest, periodical interest, stipulated interest, and corporal interest.

column1: ṛṇaṃ dātum aśakto yaḥ kartum icchet punaḥ kriyām / sa dattvā nirjitāṃ vṛddhiṃ karaṇaṃ parivartayet //
column2: He who, unable to pay a debt (at the fixed time), wishes to make a new contract, may renew the agreement, after paying the interest which is due.

column1: adarśayitvā tatraiva hiraṇyaṃ parivartayet / yāvatī saṃbhaved vṛddhis tāvatīṃ dātum arhati //
column2: If he cannot pay the money (due as interest), he may insert it in the renewed (agreement); he must pay as much interest as may be due.

column1: cakravṛddhiṃ samārūḍho deśakālavyavasthitaḥ / atikrāman deśakālau na tatphalam avāpnuyāt //
column2: He who has made a contract to carry goods by a wheeled carriage for money and has agreed to a certain place or time, shall not reap that reward, if he does not keep to the place and the time (stipulated).

column1: samudrayānakuśalā deśakālārthadarśinaḥ / sthāpayanti tu yāṃ vṛddhiṃ sā tatrādhigamaṃ prati //
column2: Whatever rate men fix, who are expert in sea-voyages and able to calculate (the profit) according to the place, the time, and the objects (carried), that (has legal force) in such cases with respect to the payment (to be made).

column1: yo yasya pratibhūs tiṣṭhed darśanāyeha mānavaḥ / adarśayan sa taṃ tasya prayacchet svadhanād ṛṇam //
column2: The man who becomes a surety in this (world) for the appearance of a (debtor), and produces him not, shall pay the debt out of his own property.

column1: prātibhāvyaṃ vṛthādānam ākṣikaṃ saurikāṃ ca yat / daṇḍaśulkāvaśeṣaṃ ca na putro dātum arhati //
column2: But money due by a surety, or idly promised, or lost at play, or due for spirituous liquor, or what remains unpaid of a fine and a tax or duty, the son (of the party owing it) shall not be obliged to pay.

column1: darśanaprātibhāvye tu vidhiḥ syāt pūrvacoditaḥ / dānapratibhuvi prete dāyādān api dāpayet //
column2: This just mentioned rule shall apply to the case of a surety for appearance (only); if a surety for payment should die, the (judge) may compel even his heirs to discharge the debt.

column1: adātari punar dātā vijñātaprakṛtāv ṛṇam / paścāt pratibhuvi prete parīpset kena hetunā //
column2: On what account then is it that after the death of a surety other than for payment, whose affairs are fully known, the creditor may (in some cases) afterwards demand the debt (of the heirs)?

column1: nirādiṣṭadhanaś cet tu pratibhūḥ syād alaṃdhanaḥ / svadhanād eva tad dadyān nirādiṣṭa iti sthitiḥ //
column2: If the surety had received money (from him for whom he stood bail) and had money enough (to pay), then (the heir of him) who received it, shall pay (the debt) out of his property; that is the settled rule.

column1: mattonmattārtādhyadhīnair bālena sthavireṇa vā / asaṃbaddhakṛtaś caiva vyāvahāro na sidhyati //
column2: A contract made by a person intoxicated, or insane, or grievously disordered (by disease and so forth), or wholly dependent, by an infant or very aged man, or by an unauthorised (party) is invalid.

column1: satyā na bhāṣā bhavati yady api syāt pratiṣṭhitā / bahiś ced bhāṣyate dharmān niyatād vyavahārikāt //
column2: That agreement which has been made contrary to the law or to the settled usage (of the virtuous), can have no legal force, though it be established (by proofs).

column1: yogādhamanavikrītaṃ yogadānapratigraham / yatra vāpy upadhiṃ paśyet tat sarvaṃ vinivartayet //
column2: A fraudulent mortgage or sale, a fraudulent gift or acceptance, and (any transaction) where he detects fraud, the (judge) shall declare null and void.

column1: grahītā yadi naṣṭaḥ syāt kuṭumbārthe kṛto vyayaḥ / dātavyaṃ bāndhavais tat syāt pravibhaktair api svataḥ //
column2: If the debtor be dead and (the money borrowed) was expended for the family, it must be paid by the relatives out of their own estate even if they are divided.

column1: kuṭumbārthe 'dhyadhīno 'pi vyavahāraṃ yam ācaret / svadeśe vā videśe vā taṃ jyāyān na vicālayet //
column2: Should even a person wholly dependent make a contract for the behoof of the family, the master (of the house), whether (living) in his own country or abroad, shall not rescind it.

column1: balād dattaṃ balād bhuktaṃ balād yac cāpi lekhitam / sarvān balakṛtān arthān akṛtān manur abravīt //
column2: What is given by force, what is enjoyed by force, also what has been caused to be written by force, and all other transactions done by force, Manu has declared void.

column1: trayaḥ parārthe kliśyanti sākṣiṇaḥ pratibhūḥ kulam / catvāras tūpacīyante vipra āḍhyo vaṇiṅ nṛpaḥ //
column2: Three suffer for the sake of others, witnesses, a surety, and judges; but four enrich themselves (through others), a Brahmana, a money-lender, a merchant, and a king.

column1: anādeyaṃ nādadīta parikṣīṇo 'pi pārthivaḥ / na cādeyaṃ samṛddho 'pi sūkṣmam apy artham utsṛjet //
column2: No king, however indigent, shall take anything that ought not to be taken, nor shall he, however wealthy, decline taking that which he ought to take, be it ever so small.

column1: anādeyasya cādānād ādeyasya ca varjanāt / daurbalyaṃ khyāpyate rājñaḥ sa pretyeha ca naśyati // svādānād varṇasaṃsargāt tv abalānāṃ ca rakṣaṇāt / balaṃ saṃjāyate rājñaḥ sa pretyeha ca vardhate //
column2: In consequence of his taking what ought not to be taken, or of his refusing what ought to be received, a king will be accused of weakness and perish in this (world) and after death. By taking his due, by preventing the confusion of the castes (varna), and by protecting the weak, the power of the king grows, and he prospers in this (world) and after death.

column1: tasmād yama iva svāmī svayaṃ hitvā priyāpriye / varteta yāmyayā vṛttyā jitakrodho jitendriyaḥ //
column2: Let the prince, therefore, like Yama, not heeding his own likings and dislikings, behave exactly like Yama, suppressing his anger and controlling himself.

column1: yas tv adharmeṇa kāryāṇi mohāt kuryān narādhipaḥ / acirāt taṃ durātmānaṃ vaśe kurvanti śatravaḥ //
column2: But that evil-minded king who in his folly decides causes unjustly, his enemies soon subjugate.

column1: kāmakrodhau tu saṃyamya yo 'rthān dharmeṇa paśyati / prajās tam anuvartante samudram iva sindhavaḥ //
column2: If, subduing love and hatred, he decides the causes according to the law, (the hearts of) his subjects turn towards him as the rivers (run) towards the ocean.

column1: yaḥ sādhayantaṃ chandena vedayed dhanikaṃ nṛpe / sa rājñā tac caturbhāgaṃ dāpyas tasya ca tad dhanam //
column2: (The debtor) who complains to the king that his creditor recovers (the debt) independently (of the court), shall be compelled by the king to pay (as a fine) one quarter (of the sum) and to his (creditor) the money (due).

column1: karmaṇāpi samaṃ kuryād dhanikāyādhamarṇikaḥ / samo 'vakṛṣṭajātis tu dadyāc chreyāṃs tu tac chanaiḥ //
column2: Even by (personal) labour shall the debtor make good (what he owes) to his creditor, if he be of the same caste or of a lower one; but a (debtor) of a higher caste shall pay it gradually (when he earns something).

column1: anena vidhinā rājā mitho vivadatāṃ nṛṇām / sākṣipratyayasiddhāni kāryāṇi samatāṃ nayet //
column2: According to these rules let the king equitably decide between men, who dispute with each other the matters, which are proved by witnesses and (other) evidence.

column1: kulaje vṛttasaṃpanne dharmajñe satyavādini / mahāpakṣe dhaniny ārye nikṣepaṃ nikṣiped budhaḥ //
column2: A sensible man should make a deposit (only) with a person of (good) family, of good conduct, well acquainted with the law, veracious, having many relatives, wealthy, and honourable (arya).

column1: yo yathā nikṣiped dhaste yam arthaṃ yasya mānavaḥ / sa tathaiva grahītavyo yathā dāyas tathā grahaḥ //
column2: In whatever manner a person shall deposit anything in the hands of another, in the same manner ought the same thing to be received back (by the owner); as the delivery (was, so must be) the re-delivery.

column1: yo nikṣepaṃ yācyamāno nikṣeptur na prayacchati / sa yācyaḥ prāḍvivākena tan nikṣeptur asaṃnidhau //
column2: He who restores not his deposit to the depositor at his request, may be tried by the judge in the depositor's absence.

column1: sākṣyabhāve praṇidhibhir vayorūpasamanvitaiḥ / apadeśaiś ca saṃnyasya hiraṇyaṃ tasya tattvataḥ //
column2: On failure of witnesses let the (judge) actually deposit gold with that (defendant) under some pretext or other through spies of suitable age and appearance (and afterwards demand it back).

column1: sa yadi pratipadyeta yathānyastaṃ yathākṛtam / na tatra vidyate kiṃ cid yat parair abhiyujyate //
column2: If the (defendant) restores it in the manner and shape in which it was bailed, there is nothing (of that description) in his hands, for which others accuse him.

column1: teṣāṃ na dadyād yadi tu tad dhiraṇyaṃ yathāvidhi / ubhau nigṛhya dāpyaḥ syād iti dharmasya dhāraṇā //
column2: But if he restores not that gold, as be ought, to those (spies), then he shall be compelled by force to restore both (deposits); that is a settled rule of law.

column1: nikṣepopanidhī nityaṃ na deyau pratyanantare / naśyato vinipāte tāv anipāte tv anāśinau // svayam eva tu yau dadyān mṛtasya pratyanantare / na sa rājñābhiyoktavyo na nikṣeptuś ca bandhubhiḥ //
column2: An open or a sealed deposit must never be returned to a near relative (of the depositor during the latter's lifetime); for if (the recipient) dies (without delivering them), they are lost, but if he does not die, they are not lost. But (a depositary) who of his own accord returns them to a near relative of a deceased (depositor), must not be harassed (about them) by the king or by the depositor's relatives.

column1: acchalenaiva cānvicchet tam arthaṃ prītipūrvakam / vicārya tasya vā vṛttaṃ sāmnaiva parisādhayet //
column2: And (in doubtful cases) he should try to obtain that object by friendly means, without (having recourse to) artifice, or having inquired into (depositary's) conduct, he should settle (the matter) with gentle means.

column1: nikṣepeṣv eṣu sarveṣu vidhiḥ syāt parisādhane / samudre nāpnuyāt kiṃ cid yadi tasmān na saṃharet //
column2: Such is the rule for obtaining back all those open deposits; in the case of a sealed deposit (the depositary) shall incur no (censure), unless he has taken out something.

column1: caurair hṛtaṃ jalenoḍham agninā dagdham eva vā / na dadyād yadi tasmāt sa na saṃharati kiṃ cana //
column2: (A deposit) which has been stolen by thieves or washed away by water or burned by fire, (the bailee) shall not make it good, unless he took part of it (for himself).

column1: nikṣepasyāpahartāram anikṣeptāram eva ca / sarvair upāyair anvicchec chapathaiś caiva vaidikaiḥ //
column2: Him who appropriates a deposit and him (who asks for it) without having made it, (the judge) shall try by all (sorts of) means, and by the oaths prescribed in the Veda.

column1: yo nikṣepaṃ nārpayati yaś cānikṣipya yācate / tāv ubhau cauravac chāsyau dāpyau vā tatsamaṃ damam //
column2: He who does not return a deposit and he who demands what he never bailed shall both be punished like thieves, or be compelled to pay a fine equal (to the value of the object retained or claimed).

column1: nikṣepasyāpahartāraṃ tatsamaṃ dāpayed damam / tathopanidhihartāram aviśeṣeṇa pārthivaḥ //
column2: The king should compel him who does not restore an open deposit, and in like manner him who retains a sealed deposit, to pay a fine equal (to its value).

column1: upadhābhiś ca yaḥ kaś cit paradravyaṃ haren naraḥ / sasahāyaḥ sa hantavyaḥ prakāśaṃ vividhair vadhaiḥ //
column2: That man who by false pretences may possess himself of another's property, shall be publicly punished by various (modes of) corporal (or capital) chastisement, together with his accomplices.

column1: nikṣepo yaḥ kṛto yena yāvāṃś ca kulasaṃnidhau / tāvān eva sa vijñeyo vibruvan daṇḍam arhati //
column2: If a deposit of a particular description or quantity is bailed by anybody in the presence of a number (of witnesses), it must be known to be of that particular (description and quantity; the depositary) who makes a false statement (regarding it) is liable to a fine.

column1: mitho dāyaḥ kṛto yena gṛhīto mitha eva vā / mitha eva pradātavyo yathā dāyas tathā grahaḥ //
column2: But if anything is delivered or received privately, it must be privately returned; as the bailment (was, so should be) the re-delivery.

column1: nikṣiptasya dhanasyaivaṃ prītyopanihitasya ca / rājā vinirṇayaṃ kuryād akṣiṇvan nyāsadhāriṇam //
column2: Thus let the king decide (causes) concerning a deposit and a friendly loan (for use) without showing (undue) rigour to the depositary.

column1: vikrīṇīte parasya svaṃ yo 'svāmī svāmyasammataḥ / na taṃ nayeta sākṣyaṃ tu stenam astenamāninam //
column2: If anybody sells the property of another man, without being the owner and without the assent of the owner, the (judge) shall not admit him who is a thief, though he may not consider himself as a thief, as a witness (in any case).

column1: avahāryo bhavec caiva sānvayaḥ ṣaṭśataṃ damam / niranvayo 'napasaraḥ prāptaḥ syāc caurakilbiṣam //
column2: If the (offender) is a kinsman (of the owner), he shall be fined six hundred panas; if he is not a kinsman, nor has any excuse, he shall be guilty of theft.

column1: asvāminā kṛto yas tu dāyo vikraya eva vā / akṛtaḥ sa tu vijñeyo vyavahāre yathā sthitiḥ //
column2: A gift or sale, made by anybody else but the owner, must be considered as null and void, according to the rule in judicial proceedings.

column1: saṃbhogo dṛśyate yatra na dṛśyetāgamaḥ kva cit / āgamaḥ kāraṇaṃ tatra na saṃbhoga iti sthitiḥ //
column2: Where possession is evident, but no title is perceived, there the title (shall be) a proof (of ownership), not possession; such is the settled rule.

column1: vikrayād yo dhanaṃ kiṃ cid gṛhṇīyat kulasaṃnidhau / krayeṇa sa viśuddhaṃ hi nyāyato labhate dhanam // atha mūlam anāhāryaṃ prakāśakrayaśodhitaḥ / adaṇḍyo mucyate rājñā nāṣṭiko labhate dhanam //
column2: He who obtains a chattel in the market before a number (of witnesses), acquires that chattel with a clear legal title by purchase. If the original (seller) be not producible, (the buyer) being exculpated by a public sale, must be dismissed by the king without punishment, but (the former owner) who lost the chattel shall receive it (back from the buyer).

column1: nānyad anyena saṃsṛṣṭa- rūpaṃ vikrayam arhati / na cāsāraṃ na ca nyūnaṃ na dūreṇa tirohitam //
column2: One commodity mixed with another must not be sold (as pure), nor a bad one (as good), nor less (than the proper quantity or weight), nor anything that is not at hand or that is concealed.

column1: anyāṃ ced darśayitvānyā voḍhuḥ kanyā pradīyate / ubhe ta ekaśulkena vahed ity abravīn manuḥ //
column2: If, after one damsel has been shown, another be given to the bridegroom, he may marry them both for the same price; that Manu ordained.

column1: nonmattāyā na kuṣṭhinyā na ca yā spṛṣṭamaithunā / pūrvaṃ doṣān abhikhyāpya pradātā daṇḍam arhati //
column2: He who gives (a damsel in marriage), having first openly declared her blemishes, whether she be insane, or afflicted with leprosy, or have lost her virginity, is not liable to punishment.

column1: ṛtvig yadi vṛto yajñe svakarma parihāpayet / tasya karmānurūpeṇa deyo 'ṃśaḥ sahakartṛbhiḥ //
column2: If an officiating priest, chosen to perform a sacrifice, abandons his work, a share only (of the fee) in proportion to the work (done) shall be given to him by those who work with him.

column1: dakṣiṇāsu ca dattāsu svakarma parihāpayan / kṛtsnam eva labhetāṃśam anyenaiva ca kārayet //
column2: But he who abandons his work after the sacrificial fees have been given, shall obtain his full share and cause to be performed (what remains) by another (priest).

column1: yasmin karmaṇi yās tu syur uktāḥ pratyaṅgadakṣiṇāḥ / sa eva tā ādidīta bhajeran sarva eva vā //
column2: But if (specific) fees are ordained for the several parts of a rite, shall he (who performs the part) receive them, or shall they all share them?

column1: rathaṃ haret cādhvaryur brahmādhāne ca vājinam / hotā vāpi hared aśvam udgātā cāpy anaḥ kraye //
column2: The Adhvaryu priest shall take the chariot, and the Brahman at the kindling of the fires (Agnyadhana) a horse, the Hotri priest shall also take a horse, and the Udgatri the cart, (used) when (the Soma) is purchased.

column1: sarveṣām ardhino mukhyās tadardhenārdhino 'pare / tṛtīyinas tṛtīyāṃśāś caturthāṃśāś ca pādinaḥ //
column2: The (four) chief priests among all (the sixteen), who are entitled to one half, shall receive a moiety (of the fee), the next (four) one half of that, the set entitled to a third share, one third, and those entitled to a fourth a quarter.

column1: saṃbhūya svāni karmāṇi kurvadbhir iha mānavaiḥ / anena vidhiyogena kartavyāṃśaprakalpanā //
column2: By the application of these principles the allotment of shares must be made among those men who here (below) perform their work conjointly.

column1: dharmārthaṃ yena dattaṃ syāt kasmai cid yācate dhanam / paścāc ca na tathā tat syān na deyaṃ tasya tad bhavet //
column2: Should money be given (or promised) for a pious purpose by one man to another who asks for it, the gift shall be void, if the (money is) afterwards not (used) in the manner (stated).

column1: yadi saṃsādhayet tat tu darpāl lobhena vā punaḥ / rājñā dāpyaḥ suvarṇaṃ syāt tasya steyasya niṣkṛtiḥ //
column2: But if the (recipient) through pride or greed tries to enforce (the fulfilment of the promise), he shall be compelled by the king to pay one suvarna as an expiation for his theft.

column1: dattasyaiṣoditā dharmyā yathāvad anapakriyā / ata ūrdhvaṃ pravakṣyāmi vetanasyānapakriyām //
column2: Thus the lawful subtraction of a gift has been fully explained; I will next propound (the law for) the non-payment of wages.

column1: bhṛto nārto na kuryād yo darpāt karma yathoditam / sa daṇḍyaḥ kṛṣṇalāny aṣṭau na deyaṃ cāsya vetanam //
column2: A hired (servant or workman) who, without being ill, out of pride fails to perform his work according to the agreement, shall be fined eight krishnalas and no wages shall be paid to him.

column1: ārtas tu kuryāt svasthaḥ san yathābhāṣitam āditaḥ / sa dīrghasyāpi kālasya tal labhetaiva vetanam //
column2: But (if he is really) ill, (and) after recovery performs (his work) according to the original agreement, he shall receive his wages even after (the lapse of) a very long time.

column1: yathoktam ārtaḥ sustho vā yas tat karma na kārayet / na tasya vetanaṃ deyam alponasyāpi karmaṇaḥ //
column2: But if he, whether sick or well, does not (perform or) cause to be performed (by others) his work according to his agreement, the wages for that work shall not be given to him, even (if it be only) slightly incomplete.

column1: eṣa dharmo 'khilenokto vetanādānakarmaṇaḥ / ata ūrdhvaṃ pravakṣyāmi dharmaṃ samayabhedinām //
column2: Thus the law for the non-payment of wages has been completely stated; I will next explain the law concerning men who break an agreement.

column1: yo grāmadeśasaṃghānāṃ kṛtvā satyena saṃvidam / visaṃvaden naro lobhāt taṃ rāṣṭrād vipravāsayet //
column2: If a man belonging to a corporation inhabiting a village or a district, after swearing to an agreement, breaks it through avarice, (the king) shall banish him from his realm,

column1: nigṛhya dāpayec cainaṃ samayavyabhicāriṇam / catuḥsuvarṇān ṣaṇniṣkāṃś chatamānaṃ ca rājakam //
column2: And having imprisoned such a breaker of an agreement, he shall compel him to pay six nishkas, (each of) four suvarnas, and one satamana of silver.

column1: etad daṇḍavidhiṃ kuryād dhārmikaḥ pṛthivīpatiḥ / grāmajātisamūheṣu samayavyabhicāriṇām //
column2: A righteous king shall apply this law of fines in villages and castes (gati) to those who break an agreement.

column1: krītvā vikrīya vā kiṃ cid yasyehānuśayo bhavet / so 'ntar daśāhāt tad dravyaṃ dadyāc caivādadīta vā //
column2: If anybody in this (world), after buying or selling anything, repent (of his bargain), he may return or take (back) that chattel within ten days.

column1: pareṇa tu daśāhasya na dadyān nāpi dāpayet / ādadāno dadat caiva rājñā daṇḍyau śatāni ṣaṭ // yas tu doṣavatīṃ kanyām anākhyāya prayacchati / tasya kuryān nṛpo daṇḍaṃ svayaṃ ṣaṇṇavatiṃ paṇān //
column2: But after (the lapse of) ten days he may neither give nor cause it to be given (back); both he who takes it (back) and he who gives it (back, except by consent) shall be fined by the king six hundred (panas). But the king himself shall impose a fine of ninety-six panas on him who gives a blemished damsel (to a suitor) without informing (him of the blemish).
