column1: akanyeti tu yaḥ kanyāṃ brūyād dveṣeṇa mānavaḥ / sa śataṃ prāpnuyād daṇḍaṃ tasyā doṣam adarśayan //
column2: But that man who, out of malice, says of a maiden, 'She is not a maiden,' shall be fined one hundred (panas), if he cannot prove her blemish.

column1: pāṇigrahaṇikā mantrāḥ kanyāsv eva pratiṣṭhitāḥ / nākanyāsu kva cin nṝṇāṃ luptadharmakriyā hi tāḥ //
column2: The nuptial texts are applied solely to virgins, (and) nowhere among men to females who have lost their virginity, for such (females) are excluded from religious ceremonies.

column1: pāṇigrahaṇikā mantrā niyataṃ dāralakṣaṇam / teṣāṃ niṣṭhā tu vijñeyā vidvadbhiḥ saptame pade //
column2: The nuptial texts are a certain proof (that a maiden has been made a lawful) wife; but the learned should know that they (and the marriage ceremony are complete with the seventh step (of the bride around the sacred fire).

column1: yasmin yasmin kṛte kārye yasyehānuśayo bhavet / tam anena vidhānena dharmye pathi niveśayet //
column2: If anybody in this (world) repent of any completed transaction, (the king) shall keep him on the road of rectitude in accordance with the rules given above.

column1: paśuṣu svāmināṃ caiva pālānāṃ ca vyatikrame / vivādaṃ saṃpravakṣyāmi yathāvad dharmatattvataḥ //
column2: I will fully declare in accordance with the true law (the rules concerning) the disputes, (arising) from the transgressions of owners of cattle and of herdsmen.

column1: divā vaktavyatā pāle rātrau svāmini tadgṛhe / yogakṣeme 'nyathā cet tu pālo vaktavyatām iyāt //
column2: During the day the responsibility for the safety (of the cattle rests) on the herdsman, during the night on the owner, (provided they are) in his house; (if it be) otherwise, the herdsman will be responsible (for them also during the night).

column1: gopaḥ kṣīrabhṛto yas tu sa duhyād daśato varām / gosvāmyanumate bhṛtyaḥ sā syāt pāle 'bhṛte bhṛtiḥ // naṣṭaṃ vinaṣṭaṃ kṛmibhiḥ śvahataṃ viṣame mṛtam / hīnaṃ puruṣakāreṇa pradadyāt pāla eva tu //
column2: A hired herdsman who is paid with milk, may milk with the consent of the owner the best (cow) out of ten; such shall be his hire if no (other) wages (are paid). The herdsman alone shall make good (the loss of a beast) strayed, destroyed by worms, killed by dogs or (by falling) into a pit, if he did not duly exert himself (to prevent it).

column1: vighuṣya tu hṛtaṃ caurair na pālo dātum arhati / yadi deśe ca kāle ca svāminaḥ svasya śaṃsati //
column2: But for (an animal) stolen by thieves, though he raised an alarm, the herdsman shall not pay, provided he gives notice to his master at the proper place and time.

column1: karṇau carma ca vālāṃś ca bastiṃ snāyuṃ ca rocanām / paśuṣu svāmināṃ dadyān mṛteṣv aṅkāni darśayet //
column2: If cattle die, let him carry to his master their ears, skin, tails, bladders, tendons, and the yellow concrete bile, and let him point out their particular. marks.

column1: ajāvike tu saṃruddhe vṛkaiḥ pāle tv anāyati / yāṃ prasahya vṛko hanyāt pāle tat kilbiṣaṃ bhavet // tāsāṃ ced avaruddhānāṃ carantīnāṃ mitho vane / yām utplutya vṛko hanyān na pālas tatra kilbiṣī //
column2: But if goats or sheep are surrounded by wolves and the herdsman does not hasten (to their assistance), lie shall be responsible for any (animal) which a wolf may attack and kill. But if they, kept in (proper) order, graze together in the forest, and a wolf, suddenly jumping on one of them, kills it, the herdsman shall bear in that case no responsibility.

column1: dhanuḥśataṃ parīhāro grāmasya syāt samantataḥ / śamyāpātās trayo vāpi triguṇo nagarasya tu //
column2: On all sides of a village a space, one hundred dhanus or three samya-throws (in breadth), shall be reserved (for pasture), and thrice (that space) round a town.

column1: tatrāparivṛtaṃ dhānyaṃ vihiṃsyuḥ paśavo yadi / na tatra praṇayed daṇḍaṃ nṛpatiḥ paśurakṣiṇām //
column2: If the cattle do damage to unfenced crops on that (common), the king shall in that case not punish the herdsmen.

column1: vṛtiṃ tatra prakurvīta yām uṣṭro na vilokayet / chidraṃ ca vārayet sarvaṃ śvasūkaramukhānugam //
column2: (The owner of the field) shall make there a hedge over which a camel cannot look, and stop every gap through which a dog or a boar can thrust his head.

column1: pathi kṣetre parivṛte grāmāntīye 'tha vā punaḥ / sapālaḥ śatadaṇḍārho vipālān vārayet paśūn //
column2: (If cattle do mischief) in an enclosed field near a highway or near a village, the herdsman shall be fined one hundred (panas);(but cattle), unattended by a herdsman, (the watchman in the field) shall drive away.

column1: kṣetreṣv anyeṣu tu paśuḥ sapādaṃ paṇam arhati / sarvatra tu sado deyaḥ kṣetrikasyeti dhāraṇā //
column2: (For damage) in other fields (each head of) cattle shall (pay a fine of one (pana) and a quarter, and in all (cases the value of) the crop (destroyed) shall be made good to the owner of the field; that is the settled rule.

column1: anirdaśāhāṃ gāṃ sūtāṃ vṛṣān devapaśūṃs tathā / sapālān vā vipālān vā na daṇḍyān manur abravīt //
column2: But Manu has declared that no fine shall be paid for (damage done by) a cow within ten days after her calving, by bulls and by cattle sacred to the gods, whether they are attended by a herdsman or not.

column1: kṣetriyasyātyaye daṇḍo bhāgād daśaguṇo bhavet / tato 'rdhadaṇḍo bhṛtyānām ajñānāt kṣetrikasya tu //
column2: If (the crops are destroyed by) the husbandman's (own) fault, the fine shall amount to ten times as much as (the king's) share; but the fine (shall be) only half that amount if (the fault lay) with the servants and the farmer had no knowledge of it.

column1: etad vidhānam ātiṣṭhed dhārmikaḥ pṛthivīpatiḥ / svāmināṃ ca paśūnāṃ ca pālānāṃ ca vyatikrame //
column2: To these rules a righteous king shall keep in (all cases of) transgressions by masters, their cattle, and herdsmen.

column1: sīmāṃ prati samutpanne vivāde grāmayor dvayoḥ / jyeṣṭhe māsi nayet sīmāṃ suprakāśeṣu setuṣu //
column2: If a dispute has arisen between two villages concerning a boundary, the king shall settle the limits in the month of Gyaishtha, when the landmarks are most distinctly visible.

column1: sīṃāvṛkṣāṃś ca kurvīta nyagrodhāśvatthakiṃśukān / śālmalīn sālatālāṃś ca kṣīriṇaś caiva pādapān // gulmān veṇūṃś ca vividhān śamīvallīsthalāni ca / śarān kubjakagulmāṃś ca tathā sīmā na naśyati //
column2: Let him mark the boundaries (by) trees, (e.g.) Nyagrodhas, Asvatthas, Kimsukas, cotton-trees, Salas, Palmyra palms, and trees with milky juice, By clustering shrubs, bamboos of different kinds, Samis, creepers and raised mounds, reeds, thickets of Kubgaka; thus the boundary will not be forgotten.

column1: taḍāgāny udapānāni vāpyaḥ prasravaṇāni ca //
column2: Tanks, wells, cisterns, and fountains should be built where boundaries meet, as well as temples,

column1: upachannāni cānyāni sīmāliṅgāni kārayet / sīmājñāne nṛṇāṃ vīkṣya nityaṃ loke viparyayam //
column2: And as he will see that through men's ignorance of the boundaries trespasses constantly occur in the world, let him cause to be made other hidden marks for boundaries,

column1: aśmano 'sthīni govālāṃs tuṣān bhasma kapālikāḥ / karīṣam iṣṭakāṅgārāṃś śarkarā vālukās tathā //
column2: Stones, bones, cow's hair, chaff, ashes, potsherds, dry cowdung, bricks, cinders, pebbles, and sand,

column1: yāni caivaṃprakārāṇi kālād bhūmir na bhakṣayet / tāni saṃdhiṣu sīmāyām aprakāśāni kārayet //
column2: And whatever other things of a similar kind the earth does not corrode even after a long time, those he should cause to be buried where one boundary joins (the other).

column1: etair liṅgair nayet sīmāṃ rājā vivadamānayoḥ / pūrvabhuktyā ca satatam udakasyāgamena ca //
column2: By these signs, by long continued possession, and by constantly flowing streams of water the king shall ascertain the boundary (of the land) of two disputing parties.

column1: yadi sṃśaya eva syāl liṅgānām api darśane / sākṣipratyaya eva syāt sīmāvādavinirṇayaḥ //
column2: If there be a doubt even on inspection of the marks, the settlement of a dispute regarding boundaries shall depend on witnesses.

column1: grāmīyakakulānāṃ ca samakṣaṃ sīmni sākṣiṇaḥ / praṣṭavyāḥ sīmaliṅgāni tayoś caiva vivādinoḥ //
column2: The witnesses, (giving evidence) regarding a boundary, shall be examined concerning the landmarks in the presence of the crowd of the villagers and also of the two litigants.

column1: te pṛṣṭās tu yathā brūyuḥ samastāḥ sīmni niścayam / nibadhnīyāt tathā sīmāṃ sarvāṃs tāṃś caiva nāmataḥ //
column2: As they, being questioned, unanimously decide, even so he shall record the boundary (in writing), together with their names.

column1: śirobhis te gṛhītvorvīṃ sragviṇo raktavāsasaḥ / sukṛtaiḥ śāpithāḥ svaiḥ svair nayeyus te samañjasam //
column2: Let them, putting earth on their heads, wearing chaplets (of red flowers) and red dresses, being sworn each by (the rewards for) his meritorious deeds, settle (the boundary) in accordance with the truth.

column1: yathoktena nayantas te pūyante satyasākṣiṇaḥ / viparītaṃ nayantas tu dāpyāḥ syur dviśataṃ damam //
column2: If they determine (the boundary) in the manner stated, they are guiltless (being) veracious witnesses; but if they determine it unjustly, they shall be compelled to pay a fine of two hundred (panas).

column1: sākṣyabhāve tu catvāro grāmāḥ sāmantavāsinaḥ / sīmāvinirṇayaṃ kuryuḥ prayatā rājasaṃnidhau //
column2: On failure of witnesses (from the two villages, men of) the four neighbouring villages, who are pure, shall make (as witnesses) a decision concerning the boundary in the presence of the king.

column1: sāmantānām abhāve tu maulānāṃ sīmni sākṣiṇām / imān apy anuyuñjīta puruṣān vanagocarān //
column2: On failure of neighbours (who are) original inhabitants (of the country and can be) witnesses with respect to the boundary, (the king) may hear the evidence even of the following inhabitants of the forest.

column1: vyādhāñ śākunikān gopān kaivartān mūlakhānakān / vyālagrāhān uñchavṛttīn anyāṃś ca vanacāriṇaḥ //
column2: (Viz.) hunters, fowlers, herdsmen, fishermen, root-diggers, snake-catchers, gleaners, and other foresters.

column1: te pṛṣṭās tu yathā brūyuḥ sīmāsaṃdhiṣu lakṣaṇam / tat tathā sthāpayed rājā dharmeṇa grāmayor dvayoḥ //
column2: As they, being examined, declare the marks for the meeting of the boundaries (to be), even so the king shall justly cause them to be fixed between the two villages.

column1: kṣetrakūpataḍāgānām ārāmasya gṛhasya ca / sāmantapratyayo jñeyaḥ sīmāsetuvinirṇayaḥ //
column2: The decision concerning the boundary-marks of fields, wells, tanks, of gardens and houses depends upon (the evidence of) the neighbours.

column1: sāmantāś cen mṛṣā brūyuḥ setau vivādatāṃ nṛṇām / sarve pṛthak pṛthag daṇḍyā rājñā madhyamasāhasam //
column2: Should the neighbours give false evidence, when men dispute about a boundary-mark, the king shall make each of them pay the middlemost amercement as a fine.

column1: gṛhaṃ taḍāgam ārāmaṃ kṣetraṃ vā bhīṣayā haran / śatāni pañca daṇḍyaḥ syād ajñānād dviśato damaḥ //
column2: He who by intimidation possesses himself of a house, a tank, a garden, or a field, shall be fined five hundred (panas); (if he trespassed) through ignorance, the fine (shall be) two hundred (panas).

column1: sīmāyām aviṣahyāyāṃ svayaṃ rājaiva dharmavit / pradiśed bhūmim ekeṣām upakārād iti sthitiḥ //
column2: If the boundary cannot be ascertained (by any evidence), let a righteous king with (the intention of) benefiting them (all), himself assign (his) land (to each); that is the settled rule.

column1: eṣo 'khilenābhihito dharmaḥ sīmāvinirṇaye / ata ūrdhvaṃ pravakṣyāmi vākpāruṣyavinirṇayam //
column2: Thus the law for deciding boundary (disputes) has been fully declared, I will next propound the (manner of) deciding (cases of) defamation.

column1: śataṃ brāhmaṇam ākruśya kṣatriyo daṇḍam arhati / vaiśyo 'py ardhaśataṃ dve vā śūdras tu vadham arhati //
column2: A Kshatriya, having defamed a Brahmana, shall be fined one hundred (panas); a Vaisya one hundred and fifty or two hundred; a Sudra shall suffer corporal punishment.

column1: pañcāśad brāhmaṇo daṇḍyaḥ kṣatriyasyābhiśaṃsane / vaiśye syād ardhapañcāśac chūdre dvādaśako damaḥ //
column2: A Brahmana shall be fined fifty (panas) for defaming a Kshatriya; in (the case of) a Vaisya the fine shall be twenty-five (panas); in (the case of) a Sudra twelve.

column1: samavarṇe dvijātīnāṃ dvādaśaiva vyatikrame / vādeṣv avacanīyeṣu tad eva dviguṇaṃ bhavet //
column2: For offences of twice-born men against those of equal caste (varna, the fine shall be) also twelve (panas); for speeches which ought not to be uttered, that (and every fine shall be) double.

column1: ekajātir dvijātīṃs tu vācā dāruṇayā kṣipan / jihvāyāḥ prāpnuyāc chedaṃ jaghanyaprabhavo hi saḥ //
column2: A once-born man (a Sudra), who insults a twice-born man with gross invective, shall have his tongue cut out; for he is of low origin.

column1: nāmajātigrahaṃ tv eṣām abhidroheṇa kurvataḥ / nikṣepyo 'yomayaḥ śaṅkur jvalann āsye daśāṅgulaḥ //
column2: If he mentions the names and castes (gati) of the (twice-born) with contumely, an iron nail, ten fingers long, shall be thrust red-hot into his mouth.

column1: dharmopadeśaṃ darpeṇa viprāṇām asya kurvataḥ / taptam āsecayet tailaṃ vaktre śrotre ca pārthivaḥ // śrutaṃ deśaṃ ca jātiṃ ca karma śarīram eva ca / vitathena bruvan darpād dāpyaḥ syād dviśataṃ damam //
column2: If he arrogantly teaches Brahmanas their duty, the king shall cause hot oil to be poured into his mouth and into his ears. He who through arrogance makes false statements regarding the learning (of a caste-fellow), his country, his caste (gati), or the rites by which his body was sanctified, shall be compelled to pay a fine of two hundred (panas).

column1: kāṇaṃ vāpy atha vā khañjam anyaṃ vāpi tathāvidham / tathyenāpi bruvan dāpyo daṇḍaṃ kārṣāpaṇāvaram //
column2: He who even in accordance with the true facts (contemptuously) calls another man one-eyed, lame, or the like (names), shall be fined at least one karshapana.

column1: mātaraṃ pitaraṃ jāyāṃ bhrātaraṃ tanayaṃ gurum / ākṣārayañ śataṃ dāpyaḥ panthānaṃ cādadad guroḥ //
column2: He who defames his mother, his father, his wife, his brother, his son, or his teacher, and he who gives not the way to his preceptor, shall be compelled to pay one hundred (panas).

column1: brāhmaṇakṣatriyābhyāṃ tu daṇḍaḥ kāryo vijānatā / brāhmaṇe sāhasaḥ pūrvaḥ kṣatriye tv eva madhyamaḥ //
column2: (For mutual abuse) by a Brahmana and a Kshatriya a fine must be imposed by a discerning (king), on the Brahmana the lowest amercement, but on the Kshatriya the middlemost.

column1: viṭśūdrayor evam eva svajātiṃ prati tattvataḥ / chedavarjaṃ praṇayanaṃ daṇḍasyeti viniścayaḥ //
column2: A Vaisya and a Sudra must be punished exactly in the same manner according to their respective castes, but the tongue (of the Sudra) shall not be cut out; that is the decision.

column1: eṣa daṇḍavidhiḥ prokto vākpāruṣyasya tattvataḥ / ata ūrdhvaṃ pravakṣyāmi daṇḍapāruṣyanirṇayam //
column2: Thus the rules for punishments (applicable to cases) of defamation have been truly declared; I will next propound the decision (of cases) of assault.

column1: yena kena cid aṅgena hiṃsyāc cec chreṣṭham antyajaḥ / chettavyaṃ tad tad evāsya tan manor anuśāsanam //
column2: With whatever limb a man of a low caste does hurt to (a man of the three) highest (castes), even that limb shall be cut off; that is the teaching of Manu.

column1: pāṇim udyamya daṇḍaṃ vā pāṇicchedanam arhati / pādena praharan kopāt pādacchedanam arhati // sahāsanam abhiprepsur utkṛṣṭasyāpakṛṣṭajaḥ / kaṭyāṃ kṛtāṅko nirvāsyaḥ sphicaṃ vāsyāvakartayet //
column2: He who raises his hand or a stick, shall have his hand cut off; he who in anger kicks with his foot, shall have his foot cut off. A low-caste man who tries to place himself on the same seat with a man of a high caste, shall be branded on his hip and be banished, or (the king) shall cause his buttock to be gashed.

column1: avaniṣṭhīvato darpād dvāv oṣṭhau chedayen nṛpaḥ / avamūtrayato meḍhram avaśardhayato gudam //
column2: If out of arrogance he spits (on a superior), the king shall cause both his lips to be cut off; if he urines (on him), the penis; if he breaks wind (against him), the anus.

column1: keśeṣu gṛhṇato hastau chedayed avicārayan / pādayor dāḍhikāyāṃ ca grīvāyāṃ vṛṣaṇeṣu ca //
column2: If he lays hold of the hair (of a superior), let the (king) unhesitatingly cut off his hands, likewise (if he takes him) by the feet, the beard, the neck, or the scrotum.

column1: tvagbhedakaḥ śataṃ daṇḍyo lohitasya ca darśakaḥ / māṃsabhettā tu ṣaṇniṣkān pravāsyas tv asthibhedakaḥ //
column2: He who breaks the skin (of an equal) or fetches blood (from him) shall be fined one hundred (panas), he who cuts a muscle six nishkas, he who breaks a bone shall be banished.

column1: vanaspatīnāṃ sarveṣām upabhogo yathā yathā / yathā tathā damaḥ kāryo hiṃsāyām iti dhāraṇā //
column2: According to the usefulness of the several (kinds of) trees a fine must be inflicted for injuring them; that is the settled rule.

column1: manuṣyāṇāṃ paśūnāṃ ca duḥkhāya prahṛte sati / yathā yathā mahad duḥkhaṃ daṇḍaṃ kuryāt tathā tathā //
column2: If a blow is struck against men or animals in order to (give them) pain, (the judge) shall inflict a fine in proportion to the amount of pain (caused).

column1: aṅgāvapīḍanāyāṃ ca vraṇaśonitayos tathā / samutthānavyayaṃ dāpyaḥ sarvadaṇḍam athāpi vā //
column2: If a limb is injured, a wound (is caused), or blood (flows, the assailant) shall be made to pay (to the sufferer) the expenses of the cure, or the whole (both the usual amercement and the expenses of the cure as a) fine (to the king).

column1: dravyāṇi hiṃsyād yo yasya jñānato 'jñānato 'pi vā / sa tasyotpādayet tuṣṭiṃ rājñe dadyāc ca tatsamam //
column2: He who damages the goods of another, be it intentionally or unintentionally, shall give satisfaction to the (owner) and pay to the king a fine equal to the (damage).

column1: carmacārmikabhāṇḍeṣu kāṣṭhaloṣṭamayeṣu / mūlyāt pañcaguṇo daṇḍaḥ puṣpamūlaphaleṣu ca //
column2: In the case of (damage done to) leather, or to utensils of leather, of wood, or of clay, the fine (shall be) five times their value; likewise in the case of (damage to) flowers, roots, and fruit.

column1: yānasya caiva yātuś ca yānasvāmina eva ca / daśātivartanāny āhuḥ śeṣe daṇḍo vidhīyate //
column2: They declare with respect to a carriage, its driver and its owner, (that there are) ten cases in which no punishment (for damage done) can be inflicted; in other cases a fine is prescribed.

column1: chinnanāsye bhagnayuge tiryakpratimukhāgate / akṣabhaṅge ca yānasya cakrabhaṅge tathaiva ca //
column2: When the nose-string is snapped, when the yoke is broken, when the carriage turns sideways or back, when the axle or a wheel is broken,

column1: chedane caiva yantrāṇāṃ yoktraraśmyos tathaiva ca / ākrande cāpy apaihīti na daṇḍaṃ manur abravīt //
column2: When the leather-thongs, the rope around the neck or the bridle are broken, and when (the driver) has loudly called out, 'Make way,' Manu has declared (that in all these cases) no punishment (shall be inflicted).

column1: yatrāpavartate yugyaṃ vaiguṇyāt prājakasya tu / tatra svāmī bhaved daṇḍyo hiṃsāyāṃ dviśataṃ damam //
column2: But if the cart turns off (the road) through the driver's want of skill, the owner shall be fined, if damage (is done), two hundred (panas).

column1: prājakaś ced bhaved āptaḥ prājako daṇḍam arhati / yugyasthāḥ prājake 'nāpte sarve daṇḍyāḥ śataṃ śatam //
column2: If the driver is skilful (but negligent), he alone shall be fined; if the driver is unskilful, the occupants of the carriage (also) shall be each fined one hundred (panas).

column1: sa cet tu pathi saṃruddhaḥ paśubhir vā rathena vā / pramāpayet prāṇabhṛtas tatra daṇḍo 'vicāritaḥ //
column2: But if he is stopped on his way by cattle or by (another) carriage, and he causes the death of any living being, a fine shall without doubt be imposed.

column1: manuṣyamāraṇe kṣipraṃ cauravat kilbiṣaṃ bhavet / prāṇabhṛtsu mahatsv ardhaṃ gogajoṣṭrahayādiṣu //
column2: If a man is killed, his guilt will be at once the same as (that of) a thief; for large animals such as cows, elephants, camels or horses, half of that.

column1: kṣudrakāṇāṃ paśūnāṃ tu hiṃsāyāṃ dviśato damaḥ / pañcāśat tu bhaved daṇḍaḥ śubheṣu mṛgapakṣiṣu //
column2: For injuring small cattle the fine (shall be) two hundred (panas); the fine for beautiful wild quadrupeds and birds shall amount to fifty (panas).

column1: gardhabhājāvikānāṃ tu daṇḍaḥ syāt pañcamāṣikaḥ / māṣikas tu bhaved daṇḍaḥ śvasūkaranipātane //
column2: For donkeys, sheep, and goats the fine shall be five mashas; but the punishment for killing a dog or a pig shall be one masha.

column1: bhāryā putraś ca dāsaś ca preṣyo bhrātrā ca sodaraḥ / prāptāparādhās tāḍyāḥ syū rajjvā veṇudalena vā //
column2: A wife, a son, a slave, a pupil, and a (younger) brother of the full blood, who have committed faults, may be beaten with a rope or a split bamboo,

column1: pṛṣṭhatas tu śarīrasya nottamāṅge kathaṃ cana / ato 'nyathā tu praharan prāptaḥ syāc caurakilbiṣam //
column2: But on the back part of the body (only), never on a noble part; he who strikes them otherwise will incur the same guilt as a thief.

column1: eṣo 'khilenābhihito daṇḍapāruṣyanirṇayaḥ / stenasyātaḥ pravakṣyāmi vidhiṃ daṇḍavinirṇaye //
column2: Thus the whole law of assault (and hurt) has been declared completely; I will now explain the rules for the decision (in cases) of theft.

column1: paramaṃ yatnam ātiṣṭhet stenānāṃ nigrahe nṛpaḥ / stenānāṃ nigrahād asya yaśo rāṣṭraṃ ca vardhate // abhayasya hi yo dātā sa pūjyaḥ satataṃ nṛpaḥ / sattraṃ hi vardhate tasya sadaivābhayadakṣiṇam //
column2: Let the king exert himself to the utmost to punish thieves; for, if he punishes thieves, his fame grows and his kingdom prospers. That king, indeed, is ever worthy of honour who ensures the safety (of his subjects); for the sacrificial session (sattra, which he, as it were, performs thereby) ever grows in length, the safety (of his subjects representing) the sacrificial fee.

column1: sarvato dharmaṣaḍbhāgo rājño bhavati rakṣataḥ / adharmād api ṣaḍbhāgo bhavaty asya hy arakṣataḥ //
column2: A king who (duly) protects (his subjects) receives from each and all the sixth part of their spiritual merit; if he does not protect them, the sixth part of their demerit also (will fall on him).

column1: yad adhīte yad yajate yad dadāti yad arcati / tasya ṣaḍbhāgabhāg rājā samyag bhavati rakṣaṇāt //
column2: Whatever (merit a man gains by) reading the Veda, by sacrificing, by charitable gifts, (or by) worshipping (Gurus and gods), the king obtains a sixth part of that in consequence of his duly protecting (his kingdom).

column1: rakṣan dharmeṇa bhūtāni rājā vadhyāṃś ca ghātayan / yajate 'har ahar yajñaiḥ sahasraśatadakṣiṇaiḥ //
column2: A king who protects the created beings in accordance with the sacred law and smites those worthy of corporal punishment, daily offers (as it were) sacrifices at which hundred thousands (are given as) fees.

column1: yo 'rakṣan balim ādatte karaṃ śulkaṃ ca pārthivaḥ / pratibhāgaṃ ca daṇḍaṃ ca sa sadyo narakaṃ vrajet //
column2: A king who does not afford protection, (yet) takes his share in kind, his taxes, tolls and duties, daily presents and fines, will (after death) soon sink into hell.

column1: arakṣitāraṃ rājānaṃ baliṣaḍbhāgahāriṇam / tam āhuḥ sarvalokasya samagramalahārakam //
column2: They declare that a king who affords no protection, (yet) receives the sixth part of the produce, takes upon himself all the foulness of his whole people.

column1: anapekṣitamaryādaṃ nāstikaṃ vipraluṃpakam / arakṣitāram attāraṃ nṛpaṃ vidyād adhogatim //
column2: Know that a king who heeds not the rules (of the law), who is an atheist, and rapacious, who does not protect (his subjects, but) devours them, will sink low (after death).

column1: adhārmikaṃ tribhir nyāyair nigṛhṇīyāt prayatnataḥ / nirodhanena bandhena vividhena vadhena ca //
column2: Let him carefully restrain the wicked by three methods,- by imprisonment by putting them in fetters, and by various (kinds of) corporal punishments.

column1: nigraheṇa hi pāpānāṃ sādhūnāṃ saṃgraheṇa ca / dvijātaya ivejyābhiḥ pūyante satataṃ nṛpāḥ //
column2: For by punishing the wicked and by favouring the virtuous, kings are constantly sanctified, just as twice-born men by sacrifices.

column1: kṣantavyaṃ prabhuṇā nityaṃ kṣipatāṃ kāryiṇāṃ nṛṇām / bālavṛddhāturāṇāṃ ca kurvatā hitam ātmanaḥ //
column2: A king who desires his own welfare must always forgive litigants, infants, aged and sick men, who inveigh against him.

column1: yaḥ kṣipto marṣayaty ārtais tena svarge mahīyate / yas tv aiśvaryān na kṣamate narakaṃ tena gacchati //
column2: He who, being abused by men in pain, pardons (them), will in reward of that (act) be exalted in heaven; but he who, (proud) of his kingly state, forgives them not, will for that (reason) sink into hell.

column1: rājā stenena gantavyo muktakeśena dhāvatā / ācakṣāṇena tat steyam evaṃkarmāsmi śādhi mām //
column2: A thief shall, running, approach the king, with flying hair, confessing that theft (and saying), 'Thus have I done, punish me;'

column1: skandhenādāya musalaṃ laguḍaṃ vāpi khādiram / śaktiṃ cobhayatas tīkṣṇām āyasaṃ daṇḍam eva vā //
column2: (And he must) carry on his shoulder a pestle, or a club of Khadira wood, or a spear sharp at both ends, or an iron staff.

column1: śāsanād vā vimokṣād vā stenaḥ steyād vimucyate / aśāsitvā tu taṃ rājā stenasyāpnoti kilbiṣam //
column2: Whether he be punished or pardoned, the thief is freed from the (guilt of) theft; but the king, if he punishes not, takes upon himself the guilt of the thief.

column1: annāde bhrūṇahā mārṣṭi patyau bhāryāpacāriṇī / gurau śiṣyaś ca yājyaś ca steno rājani kilbiṣam //
column2: The killer of a learned Brahmana throws his guilt on him who eats his food, an adulterous wife on her (negligent) husband, a (sinning) pupil or sacrificer on (their negligent) teacher (or priest), a thief on the king (who pardons him).

column1: rājabhiḥ kṛtadaṇḍās tu kṛtvā pāpāni mānavāḥ / nirmalāḥ svargam āyānti santaḥ sukṛtino yathā //
column2: But men who have committed crimes and have been punished by the king, go to heaven, being pure like those who performed meritorious deeds.

column1: yas tu rajjuṃ ghaṭaṃ kūpād dhared bhindyāc ca yaḥ prapām / sa daṇḍaṃ prāpnuyān māṣaṃ tac ca tasmin samāharet //
column2: He who steals the rope or the water-pot from a well, or damages a hut where water is distributed, shall pay one masha as a fine and restore the (article abstracted or damaged) in its (proper place).

column1: dhānyaṃ daśabhyaḥ kumbhebhyo harato 'bhyadhikaṃ vadhaḥ / śeṣe 'py ekādaśaguṇaṃ dāpyas tasya ca tad dhanam //
column2: On him who steals more than ten kumbhas of grain corporal punishment (shall be inflicted); in other cases he shall be fined eleven times as much, and shall pay to the (owner the value of his) property.

column1: tathā dharimameyānāṃ śatād abhyadhike vadhaḥ / suvarṇarajatādīnām uttamānāṃ ca vāsasām //
column2: So shall corporal punishment be inflicted for stealing more than a hundred (palas) of articles sold by the weight, (i.e.) of gold, silver, and so forth, and of most excellent clothes.

column1: pañcāśatas tv abhyadhike hastacchedanam iṣyate / śeṣe tv ekādaśaguṇaṃ mūlyād daṇḍaṃ prakalpayet //
column2: For (stealing) more than fifty (palas) it is enacted that the hands (of the offender) shall be cut off; but in other cases, let him inflict a fine of eleven times the value.

column1: puruṣāṇāṃ kulīnānāṃ nārīṇāṃ ca viśeṣataḥ / mukhyānāṃ caiva ratnānāṃ haraṇe vadham arhati //
column2: For stealing men of noble family and especially women and the most precious gems, (the offender) deserves corporal (or capital) punishment.

column1: mahāpaśūnāṃ haraṇe śastrāṇām auṣadhasya ca / kālam āsādya kāryaṃ ca daṇḍaṃ rājā prakalpayet //
column2: For stealing large animals, weapons, or medicines, let the king fix a punishment, after considering the time and the purpose (for which they were destined).

column1: goṣu brāhmaṇasaṃsthāsu churikāyāś ca bhedane / paśūnāṃ haraṇe caiva sadyaḥ kāryo 'rdhapādikaḥ //
column2: For (stealing) cows belonging to Brahmanas, piercing (the nostrils of) a barren cow, and for stealing (other) cattle (belonging to Brahmanas, the offender) shall forthwith lose half his feet.

column1: veṇuvaidalabhāṇḍānāṃ lavaṇānāṃ tathaiva ca / mṛṇmayānāṃ ca haraṇe mṛdo bhasmana eva ca // matsyānāṃ pakṣiṇāṃ caiva tailasya ca ghṛtasya ca / māṃsasya madhunaś caiva yac cānyat paśusaṃbhavam //
column2: (For stealing) thread, cotton, drugs causing fermentation, cowdung, molasses, sour milk, sweet milk, butter-milk, water, or grass, Vessels made of bamboo or other cane, salt of various kinds, earthen (vessels), earth and ashes, Fish, birds, oil, clarified butter, meat, honey, and other things that come from beasts,

column1: anyeṣāṃ caivamādīnāṃ madyānām odanasya ca / pakvānnānāṃ ca sarveṣāṃ tanmulyād dviguṇo damaḥ //
column2: Or other things of a similar kind, spirituous liquor, boiled rice, and every kind of cooked food, the fine (shall be) twice the value (of the stolen article).

column1: puṣpeṣu harite dhānye gulmavallīnageṣu ca / anyeṣv aparipūteṣu daṇḍaḥ syāt pañcakṛṣṇalaḥ // paripūteṣu dhānyeṣu śākamūlaphaleṣu ca / niranvaye śataṃ daṇḍaḥ sānvaye 'rdhaśataṃ damaḥ //
column2: For flowers, green corn, shrubs, creepers, trees, and other unhusked (grain) the fine (shall be) five krishnalas. For husked grain, vegetables, roots, and fruit the fine (shall be) one hundred (panas) if there is no connexion (between the owner and the thief), fifty (panas) if such a connexion exists.

column1: syāt sāhasaṃ tv anvayavat prasabhaṃ karma yat kṛtam / niranvayaṃ bhavet steyaṃ hṛtvāpavyayate ca yat //
column2: An offence (of this description), which is committed in the presence (of the owner) and with violence, will be robbery; if (it is committed) in his absence, it will be theft; likewise if (the possession of) anything is denied after it has been taken.

column1: yas tv etāny upakḷptāni dravyāṇi stenayen naraḥ / tam ādyaṃ daṇḍayed rājā yaś cāgniṃ corayed gṛhāt // yena yena yathāṅgena steno nṛṣu viceṣṭate / tat tad eva haret tasya pratyādeśāya pārthivaḥ //
column2: On that man who may steal (any of) the above-mentioned articles, when they are prepared for (use), let the king inflict the first (or lowest) amercement; likewise on him who may steal (a sacred) fire out of the room (in which it is kept). With whatever limb a thief in any way commits (an offence) against men, even of that (the king) shall deprive him in order to prevent (a repetition of the crime).

column1: pitācāryaḥ suhṛn mātā bhāryā putraḥ purohitaḥ / nādaṇḍyo nāma rājño 'sti yaḥ svadharme na tiṣṭhati //
column2: Neither a father, nor a teacher, nor a friend, nor a mother, nor a wife, nor a son, nor a domestic priest must be left unpunished by a king, if they do not keep within their duty.

column1: kārṣāpaṇaṃ bhaved daṇḍyo yatrānyaḥ prākṛto janaḥ / tatra rājā bhaved daṇḍyaḥ sahasram iti dhāraṇā //
column2: Where another common man would be fined one karshapana, the king shall be fined one thousand; that is the settled rule.

column1: aṣṭāpādyaṃ tu śūdrasya steye bhavati kilbiṣam / ṣoḍaśaiva tu vaiśyasya dvātriṃśat kṣatriyasya ca //
column2: In (a case of) theft the guilt of a Sudra shall be eightfold, that of a Vaisya sixteenfold, that of a Kshatriya two-and-thirtyfold,

column1: brāhmaṇasya catuḥṣaṣṭiḥ pūrṇaṃ vāpi śataṃ bhavet / dviguṇā vā catuḥṣaṣṭis taddoṣaguṇavid dhi saḥ //
column2: That of a Brahmana sixty-fourfold, or quite a hundredfold, or (even) twice four-and-sixtyfold; (each of them) knowing the nature of the offence.

column1: vānaspatyaṃ mūlaphalaṃ dārv agnyarthaṃ tathaiva ca / tṛṇaṃ ca gobhyo grāsārtham asteyaṃ manur abravīt //
column2: (The taking of) roots and of fruit from trees, of wood for a (sacrificial) fire, and of grass for feeding cows, Manu has declared (to be) no theft.

column1: yo 'dattādāyino hastāl lipseta brāhmaṇo dhanam / yājanādhyāpanenāpi yathā stenas tathaiva saḥ //
column2: A Brahmana, seeking to obtain property from a man who took what was not given to him, either by sacrificing for him or by teaching him, is even like a thief.

column1: dvijo 'dhvagaḥ kṣīṇavṛttir dvāv ikṣū dve ca mūlake / ādadānaḥ parakṣetrān na daṇḍaṃ dātum arhati //
column2: A twice-born man, who is travelling and whose provisions are exhausted, shall not be fined, if he takes two stalks of sugar-cane or two (esculent) roots from the field of another man.

column1: asaṃditānāṃ saṃdātā saṃditānāṃ ca mokṣakaḥ / dāsāśvarathahartā ca prāptaḥ syāc corakilbiṣam //
column2: He who ties up unbound or sets free tied up (cattle of other men), he who takes a slave, a horse, or a carriage will have incurred the guilt of a thief.

column1: anena vidhinā rājā kurvāṇaḥ stenanigraham / yaśo 'smin prāpnuyāl loke pretya cānuttamaṃ sukham //
column2: A king who punishes thieves according to these rules, will gain fame in this world and after death unsurpassable bliss.

column1: aindraṃ sthānam abhiprepsur yaśaś cākṣayam avyayam / nopekṣeta kṣaṇam api rājā sāhasikaṃ naram //
column2: A king who desires to gain the throne of Indra and imperishable eternal fame, shall not, even for a moment, neglect (to punish) the man who commits violence.

column1: vāgduṣṭāt taskarāc caiva daṇḍenaiva ca hiṃsataḥ / sāhasasya naraḥ kartā vijñeyaḥ pāpakṛttamaḥ //
column2: He who commits violence must be considered as the worst offender, (more wicked) than a defamer, than a thief, and than he who injures (another) with a staff.

column1: sāhase vartamānaṃ tu yo marṣayati pārthivaḥ / sa vināśaṃ vrajaty āśu vidveṣaṃ cādhigacchati //
column2: But that king who pardons the perpetrator of violence quickly perishes and incurs hatred.

column1: na mitrakāraṇād rājā vipulād vā dhanāgamāt / samutsṛjet sāhasikān sarvabhūtabhayāvahān //
column2: Neither for friendship's sake, nor for the sake of great lucre, must a king let go perpetrators of violence, who cause terror to all creatures.

column1: śastraṃ dvijātibhir grāhyaṃ dharmo yatroparudhyate / dvijātīnāṃ ca varṇānāṃ viplave kālakārite //
column2: Twice-born men may take up arms when (they are) hindered (in the fulfilment of their duties, when destruction (threatens) the twice-born castes (varna) in (evil) times,

column1: ātmanaś ca paritrāṇe dakṣiṇānāṃ ca saṃgare / strīviprābhyupapattau ca ghnan dharmeṇa na duṣyati //
column2: In their own defence, in a strife for the fees of officiating priests, and in order to protect women and Brahmanas; he who (under such circumstances) kills in the cause of right, commits no sin.

column1: guruṃ vā bālavṛddhau vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā bahuśrutam / ātatāyinam āyāntaṃ hanyād evāvicārayan //
column2: One may slay without hesitation an assassin who approaches (with murderous intent), whether (he be one's) teacher, a child or an aged man, or a Brahmana deeply versed in the Vedas.

column1: nātatāyivadhe doṣo hantur bhavati kaś cana / prakāśaṃ vāprakāśaṃ vā manyus taṃ manyum ṛcchati //
column2: By killing an assassin the slayer incurs no guilt, whether (he does it) publicly or secretly; in that case fury recoils upon fury.

column1: paradārābhimarśeṣu pravṛttān nṝn mahīpatiḥ / udvejanakarair daṇḍaiś chinnayitvā pravāsayet //
column2: Men who commit adultery with the wives of others, the king shall cause to be marked by punishments which cause terror, and afterwards banish.

column1: tatsamuttho hi lokasya jāyate varṇasaṃkaraḥ / yena mūlaharo 'dharmaḥ sarvanāśāya kalpate //
column2: For by (adultery) is caused a mixture of the castes (varna) among men; thence (follows) sin, which cuts up even the roots and causes the destruction of everything.

column1: parasya patnyā puruṣaḥ saṃbhāṣāṃ yojayan rahaḥ / pūrvam ākṣārito doṣaiḥ prāpnuyāt pūrvasāhasam //
column2: A man formerly accused of (such) offences, who secretly converses with another man's wife, shall pay the first (or lowest) amercement.

column1: yas tv anākṣāritaḥ pūrvam abhibhāṣate kāraṇāt / na doṣaṃ prāpnuyāt kiṃ cin na hi tasya vyatikramaḥ //
column2: But a man, not before accused, who (thus) speaks with (a woman) for some (reasonable) cause, shall not incur any guilt, since in him there is no transgression.

column1: parastriyaṃ yo 'bhivadet tīrthe 'raṇye vane 'pi vā / nadīnāṃ vāpi saṃbhede sa saṃgrahaṇam āpnuyāt //
column2: He who addresses the wife of another man at a Tirtha, outside the village, in a forest, or at the confluence of rivers, suffer (the punishment for) adulterous acts (samgrahana).

column1: upacārakriyā keliḥ sparśo bhūṣaṇavāsasām / saha khaṭvāsanaṃ caiva sarvaṃ saṃgrahaṇaṃ smṛtam //
column2: Offering presents (to a woman), romping (with her), touching her ornaments and dress, sitting with her on a bed, all (these acts) are considered adulterous acts (samgrahana).

column1: striyaṃ spṛśed adeśe yaḥ spṛṣṭo vā marṣayet tayā / parasparasyānumate sarvaṃ saṃgrahaṇaṃ smṛtam //
column2: If one touches a woman in a place (which ought) not (to be touched) or allows (oneself to be touched in such a spot), all (such acts done) with mutual consent are declared (to be) adulterous (samgrahana).

column1: abrāhmaṇaḥ saṃgrahaṇe prāṇāntaṃ daṇḍam arhati / caturṇām api varṇānāṃ dārā rakṣyatamāḥ sadā //
column2: A man who is not a Brahmana ought to suffer death for adultery (samgrahana); for the wives of all the four castes even must always be carefully guarded.

column1: bhikṣukā bandinaś caiva dīkṣitāḥ kāravas tathā / saṃbhāṣanaṃ saha strībhiḥ kuryur aprativāritāḥ //
column2: Mendicants, bards, men who have performed the initiatory ceremony of a Vedic sacrifice, and artisans are not prohibited from speaking to married women.

column1: na saṃbhāṣāṃ parastrībhiḥ pratiṣiddhaḥ samācaret / niṣiddho bhāṣamāṇas tu suvarṇaṃ daṇḍam arhati //
column2: Let no man converse with the wives of others after he has been forbidden (to do so); but he who converses (with them), in spite of a prohibition, shall be fined one suvarna.

column1: naiṣa cāraṇadāreṣu vidhir nātmopajīviṣu / sajjayanti hi te nārīr nigūḍhāś cārayanti ca //
column2: This rule does not apply to the wives of actors and singers, nor (of) those who live on (the intrigues of) their own (wives); for such men send their wives (to others) or, concealing themselves, allow them to hold criminal intercourse.

column1: kiṃ cid eva tu dāpyaḥ syāt saṃbhāṣāṃ tābhir ācaran / praiṣyāsu caikabhaktāsu rahaḥ pravrajitāsu ca //
column2: Yet he who secretly converses with such women, or with female slaves kept by one (master), and with female ascetics, shall be compelled to pay a small fine.

column1: yo 'kāmāṃ dūṣayet kanyāṃ sa sadyo vadham arhati / sakāmāṃ dūṣayaṃs tulyo na vadhaṃ prāpnuyān naraḥ //
column2: He who violates an unwilling maiden shall instantly suffer corporal punishment; but a man who enjoys a willing maiden shall not suffer corporal punishment, if (his caste be) the same (as hers).

column1: kanyāṃ bhajantīm utkṛṣṭaṃ na kiṃ cid api dāpayet / jaghanyaṃ sevamānāṃ tu saṃyatāṃ vāsayed gṛhe //
column2: From a maiden who makes advances to a (man of) high (caste), he shall not take any fine; but her, who courts a (man of) low (caste), let him force to live confined in her house.

column1: uttamāṃ sevamānas tu jaghanyo vadham arhati / śulkaṃ dadyāt sevamānaḥ samām icchet pitā yadi //
column2: A (man of) low (caste) who makes love to a maiden (of) the highest (caste) shall suffer corporal punishment; he who addresses a maiden (on) equal (caste) shall pay the nuptial fee, if her father desires it.

column1: abhiṣahya tu yaḥ kanyāṃ kuryād darpeṇa mānavaḥ / tasyāśu kartye aṅgulyau daṇḍaṃ cārhati ṣaṭśatam // sakāmāṃ dūṣayaṃs tulyo nāṅgulicchedam āpnuyāt / dviśataṃ tu damaṃ dāpyaḥ prasaṅgavinivṛttaye //
column2: But if any man through insolence forcibly contaminates a maiden, two of his fingers shall be instantly cut off, and he shall pay a fine of six hundred (panas). A man (of) equal (caste) who defiles a willing maiden shall not suffer the amputation of his fingers, but shall pay a fine of two hundred (panas) in order to deter him from a repetition (of the offence).

column1: kanyaiva kanyāṃ yā kuryāt tasyāḥ syād dviśato damaḥ / śulkaṃ ca dviguṇaṃ dadyāc chiphāś caivāpnuyād daśa //
column2: A damsel who pollutes (another) damsel must be fined two hundred (panas), pay the double of her (nuptial) fee, and receive ten (lashes with a) rod.

column1: yā tu kanyāṃ prakuryāt strī sā sadyo mauṇḍyam arhati / aṅgulyor eva vā chedaṃ khareṇodvahanaṃ tathā //
column2: But a woman who pollutes a damsel shall instantly have (her head) shaved or two fingers cut off, and be made to ride (through the town) on a donkey.

column1: bhartāraṃ laṅghayed yā tu strī jñātiguṇadarpitā / tāṃ śvabhiḥ khādayed rājā saṃsthāne bahusaṃsthite //
column2: If a wife, proud of the greatness of her relatives or (her own) excellence, violates the duty which she owes to her lord, the king shall cause her to be devoured by dogs in a place frequented by many.

column1: pumāṃsaṃ dāhayet pāpaṃ śayane tapta āyase / abhyādadhyuś ca kāṣṭhāni tatra dahyeta pāpakṛt //
column2: Let him cause the male offender to be burnt on a red-hot iron bed; they shall put logs under it, (until) the sinner is burned (to death).

column1: saṃvatsarābhiśastasya duṣṭasya dviguṇo damaḥ / vrātyayā saha saṃvāse cāṇḍālyā tāvad eva tu //
column2: On a man (once) convicted, who is (again) accused within a year, a double fine (must be inflicted); even thus (must the fine be doubled) for (repeated) intercourse with a Vratya and a Kandali.

column1: śūdro guptam aguptaṃ vā dvaijātaṃ varṇam āvasan / aguptam aṅgasarvasvair guptaṃ sarveṇa hīyate //
column2: A Sudra who has intercourse with a woman of a twice-born caste (varna), guarded or unguarded, (shall be punished in the following manner): if she was unguarded, he loses the part (offending) and all his property; if she was guarded, everything (even his life).

column1: vaiśyaḥ sarvasvadaṇḍaḥ syāt saṃvatsaranirodhataḥ / sahasraṃ kṣatriyo daṇḍyo mauṇḍyaṃ mūtreṇa cārhati //
column2: (For intercourse with a guarded Brahmana a Vaisya shall forfeit all his property after imprisonment for a year; a Kshatriya shall be fined one thousand (panas) and be shaved with the urine (of an ass).

column1: brāhmaṇīṃ yady aguptāṃ tu gacchetāṃ vaiśyapārthivau / vaiśyaṃ pañcaśataṃ kuryāt kṣatriyaṃ tu sahasriṇam //
column2: If a Vaisya or a Kshatriya has connexion with an unguarded Brahmana, let him fine the Vaisya five hundred (panas) and the Kshatriya one thousand.

column1: ubhāv api tu tāv eva brāhmaṇyā guptayā saha / viplutau śūdravad daṇḍyau dagdhavyau vā kaṭāgninā //
column2: But even these two, if they offend with a Brahmani (not only) guarded (but the wife of an eminent man), shall be punished like a Sudra or be burnt in a fire of dry grass.

column1: sahasraṃ brāhmaṇo daṇḍyo guptāṃ viprāṃ balād vrajan / śatāni pañca daṇḍyaḥ syād icchantyā saha saṃgataḥ //
column2: A Brahmana who carnally knows a guarded Brahmani against her will, shall be fined one thousand (panas); but he shall be made to pay five hundred, if he had connexion with a willing one.

column1: mauṇḍyaṃ prāṇāntikaṃ daṇḍo brāhmaṇasya vidhīyate / itareṣāṃ tu varṇānāṃ daṇḍaḥ prāṇāntiko bhavet //
column2: Tonsure (of the head) is ordained for a Brahmana (instead of) capital punishment; but (men of) other castes shall suffer capital punishment.

column1: na jātu brāhmaṇaṃ hanyāt sarvapāpeṣv api sthitam / rāṣṭrād enaṃ bahiḥ kuryāt samagradhanam akṣatam //
column2: Let him never slay a Brahmana, though he have committed all (possible) crimes; let him banish such an (offender), leaving all his property (to him) and (his body) unhurt.

column1: na brāhmaṇavadhād bhūyān adharmo vidyate bhuvi / tasmād asya vadhaṃ rājā manasāpi na cintayet //
column2: No greater crime is known on earth than slaying a Brahmana; a king, therefore, must not even conceive in his mind the thought of killing a Brahmana.

column1: vaiśyaś cet kṣatriyāṃ guptāṃ vaiśyāṃ vā kṣatriyo vrajet / yo brāhmaṇyām aguptāyāṃ tāv ubhau daṇḍam arhataḥ // sahasraṃ brāhmaṇo daṇḍaṃ dāpyo gupte tu te vrajan / śūdrāyāṃ kṣatriyaviśoḥ sāhasro vai bhaved damaḥ //
column2: If a Vaisya approaches a guarded female of the Kshatriya caste, or a Kshatriya a (guarded) Vaisya woman, they both deserve the same punishment as in the case of an unguarded Brahmana female. A Brahmana shall be compelled to pay a fine of one thousand (panas) if he has intercourse with guarded (females of) those two (castes); for (offending with) a (guarded) Sudra female a fine of one thousand (panas shall be inflicted) on a Kshatriya or a Vaisya.

column1: kṣatriyāyām aguptāyāṃ vaiśye pañcaśataṃ damaḥ / mūtreṇa mauṇḍyam icchet tu kṣatriyo daṇḍam eva vā //
column2: For (intercourse with) an unguarded Kshatriya a fine of five hundred (panas shall fall) on a Vaisya; but (for the same offence) a Kshatriya shall be shaved with the urine (of a donkey) or (pay) the same fine.

column1: agupte kṣatriyāvaiśye śūdrāṃ vā brāhmaṇo vrajan / śatāni pañca daṇḍyaḥ syāt sahasraṃ tv antyajastriyam //
column2: A Brahmana who approaches unguarded females (of the) Kshatriya or Vaisya (castes), or a Sudra female, shall be fined five hundred (panas); but (for intercourse with) a female (of the) lowest (castes), one thousand.

column1: yasya stenaḥ pure nāsti nānyastrīgo na duṣṭavāk / na sāhasikadaṇḍaghno sa rājā śakralokabhāk //
column2: That king in whose town lives no thief, no adulterer, no defamer, no man guilty of violence, and no committer of assaults, attains the world of Sakra (Indra).

column1: eteṣāṃ nigraho rājñaḥ pañcānāṃ viṣaye svake / sāṃrājyakṛt sajātyeṣu loke caiva yaśaskaraḥ //
column2: The suppression of those five in his dominions secures to a king paramount sovereignty among his peers and fame in the world.

column1: ṛtvijaṃ yas tyajed yājyo yājyaṃ ca rtvik tyajed yadi / śaktaṃ karmaṇy aduṣṭaṃ ca tayor daṇḍaḥ śataṃ śatam //
column2: A sacrificer who forsakes an officiating priest, and an officiating priest who forsakes a sacrificer, (each being) able to perform his work and not contaminated (by grievous crimes), must each be fined one hundred (panas).

column1: na mātā na pitā na strī na putras tyāgam arhati / tyajann apatitān etān rājñā daṇḍyaḥ śatāni ṣaṭ //
column2: Neither a mother, nor a father, nor a wife, nor a son shall be cast off; he who casts them off, unless guilty of a crime causing loss of caste, shall be fined six hundred (panas).

column1: āśrameṣu dvijātīnāṃ kārye vivadatāṃ mithaḥ / na vibrūyān nṛpo dharmaṃ cikīrṣan hitam ātmanaḥ //
column2: If twice-born men dispute among each other concerning the duty of the orders, a king who desires his own welfare should not (hastily) decide (what is) the law.

column1: yathārham etān abhyarcya brāhmaṇaiḥ saha pārthivaḥ / sāntvena praśamayyādau svadharmaṃ pratipādayet //
column2: Having shown them due honor, he should, with (the assistance of) Brahmanas, first soothe them by gentle (speech) and afterwards teach them their duty.

column1: prativeśyānuveśyau ca kalyāṇe viṃśatidvije / arhāv abhojayan vipro daṇḍam arhati māṣakam //
column2: A Brahmana who does not invite his next neighbour and his neighbour next but one, (though) both (he) worthy (of the honour), to a festival at which twenty Brahmanas are entertained, is liable to a fine of one masha.

column1: śrotriyaḥ śrotriyaṃ sādhuṃ bhūtikṛtyeṣv abhojayan / tadannaṃ dviguṇaṃ dāpyo hiraṇyaṃ caiva māṣakam //
column2: A Srotriya who does not entertain a virtuous Srotriya at auspicious festive rites, shall be made to pay him twice (the value of) the meal and a masha of gold (as a fine to the king).

column1: andho jaḍaḥ pīṭhasarpī saptatyā sthaviraś ca yaḥ / śrotriyeṣūpakurvaṃś ca na dāpyāḥ kena cit karam //
column2: A blind man, an idiot, (a cripple) who moves with the help of a board, a man full seventy years old, and he who confers benefits on Srotriyas, shall not be compelled by any (king) to pay a tax.

column1: śrotriyaṃ vyādhitārtau ca bālavṛddhāv akiṃcanam / mahākulīnam āryaṃ ca rājā saṃpūjayet sadā //
column2: Let the king always treat kindly a Srotriya, a sick or distressed man, an infant and an aged or indigent man, a man of high birth, and an honourable man (Arya).

column1: śālmalīphalake ślakṣṇe nenijyān nejakaḥ śanaiḥ / na ca vāsāṃsi vāsobhir nirharen na ca vāsayet //
column2: A washerman shall wash (the clothes of his employers) gently on a smooth board of Salmaliwood he shall not return the clothes (of one person) for those (of another), nor allow anybody (but the owner) to wear them.

column1: tantuvāyo daśapalaṃ dadyād ekapalādhikam / ato 'nyathā vartamāno dāpyo dvādaśakaṃ damam // śulkasthāneṣu kuśalāḥ sarvapaṇyavicakṣaṇāḥ / kuryur arghaṃ yathāpaṇyaṃ tato viṃśaṃ nṛpo haret //
column2: A weaver (who has received) ten palas (of thread), shall return (cloth weighing) one pala more; he who acts differently shall be compelled to pay a fine of twelve (panas). Let the king take one-twentieth of that (amount) which men, well acquainted with the settlement of tolls and duties (and) skilful in (estimating the value of) all kinds of merchandise, may fix as the value for each saleable commodity.

column1: rājñaḥ prakhyātabhāṇḍāni pratiṣiddhāni yāni ca / tāṇi nirharato lobhāt sarvahāraṃ haren nṛpaḥ //
column2: Let the king confiscate the whole property of (a trader) who out of greed exports goods of which the king has a monopoly or (the export of which is) forbidden.

column1: śulkasthānaṃ pariharann akāle krayavikrayī / mithyāvādī ca saṃkhyāne dāpyo 'ṣṭaguṇam atyayam //
column2: He who avoids a custom-house (or a toll), he who buys or sells at an improper time, or he who makes a false statement in enumerating (his goods), shall be fined eight times (the amount of duty) which he tried to evade.

column1: āgamaṃ nirgamaṃ sthānaṃ tathā vṛddhikṣayāv ubhau / vicārya sarvapaṇyānāṃ kārayet krayavikrayau //
column2: Let (the king) fix (the rates for) the purchase and sale of all marketable goods, having (duly) considered whence they come, whither they go, how long they have been kept, the (probable) profit and the (probable) outlay.

column1: pañcarātre pañcarātre pakṣe pakṣe 'tha vā gate / kurvīta caiṣāṃ pratyakṣam arghasaṃsthāpanaṃ nṛpaḥ //
column2: Once in five nights, or at the close of each fortnight, let the king publicly settle the prices for the (merchants).

column1: tulāmānaṃ pratīmānaṃ sarvaṃ ca syāt sulakṣitam / ṣaṭsu ṣaṭsu ca māseṣu punar eva parīkṣayet //
column2: All weights and measures must be duly marked, and once in six months let him re-examine them.

column1: paṇaṃ yānaṃ tare dāpyaṃ pauruṣo 'rdhapaṇaṃ tare / pādaṃ paśuś ca yoṣic ca pādārdhaṃ riktakaḥ pumān // bhāṇḍapūrṇāni yānāni tāryaṃ dāpyāni sārataḥ / riktabhāṇḍāni yat kiṃ cit pumāṃsaś cāparicchadāḥ //
column2: At a ferry an (empty) cart shall be made to pay one pana, a man's (load) half a pana, an animal and a woman one quarter of a (pana), an unloaded man one-half of a quarter. Carts (laden) with vessels full (of merchandise) shall be made to pay toll at a ferry according to the value (of the goods), empty vessels and men without luggage some trifle.

column1: dīrghādhvani yathādeśaṃ yathākālaṃ taro bhavet / nadītīreṣu tad vidyāt samudre nāsti lakṣaṇam //
column2: For a long passage the boat-hire must be proportioned to the places and times; know that this (rule refers) to (passages along) the banks of rivers; at sea there is no settled (freight).

column1: garbhiṇī tu dvimāsādis tathā pravrajito muniḥ / brāhmaṇā liṅginaś caiva na dāpyās tārikaṃ tare //
column2: But a woman who has been pregnant two months or more, an ascetic, a hermit in the forest, and Brahmanas who are students of the Veda, shall not be made to pay toll at a ferry.

column1: yan nāvi kiṃ cid dāśānāṃ viśīryetāparādhataḥ / tad dāśair eva dātavyaṃ samāgamya svato 'ṃśataḥ //
column2: Whatever may be damaged in a boat by the fault of the boatmen, that shall be made good by the boatmen collectively, (each paying) his share.

column1: eṣa nauyāyinām ukto vyavahārasya nirṇayaḥ / dāśāparādhatas toye daivike nāsti nigrahaḥ //
column2: This decision in suits (brought) by passengers (holds good only) in case the boatmen are culpably negligent on the water; in the case of (an accident) caused by (the will of) the gods, no fine can be (inflicted on them).

column1: vāṇijyaṃ kārayed vaiśyaṃ kusīdaṃ kṛṣim eva ca / paśūnāṃ rakṣaṇaṃ caiva dāsyaṃ śūdraṃ dvijanmanām //
column2: (The king) should order a Vaisya to trade, to lend money, to cultivate the land, or to tend cattle, and a Sudra to serve the twice-born castes

column1: kṣatriyaṃ caiva vaiśyaṃ ca brāhmaṇo vṛttikarśitau / bibhṛyād ānṛśaṃsyena svāni karmāṇi kārayet //
column2: (Some wealthy) Brahmana shall compassionately support both a Kshatriya and a Vaisya, if they are distressed for a livelihood, employing them on work (which is suitable for) their (castes).

column1: dāsyaṃ tu kārayaṃl lobhād brāhmaṇaḥ saṃskṛtān dvijān / anicchataḥ prābhavatyād rājñā daṇḍyaḥ śatāni ṣaṭ //
column2: But a Brahmana who, because he is powerful, out of greed makes initiated (men of the) twice-born (castes) against their will do the work of slaves, shall be fined by the king six hundred (panas).

column1: śūdraṃ tu kārayed dāsyaṃ krītam akrītam eva vā / dāsyāyaiva hi sṛṣṭo 'sau brāhmaṇasya svayaṃbhuvā //
column2: But a Sudra, whether bought or unbought, he may compel to do servile work; for he was created by the Self-existent (Svayambhu) to be the slave of a Brahmana.

column1: na svāminā nisṛṣṭo 'pi śūdro dāsyād vimucyate / nisargajaṃ hi tat tasya kas tasmāt tad apohati //
column2: A Sudra, though emancipated by his master, is not released from servitude; since that is innate in him, who can set him free from it?

column1: dhvajāhṛto bhaktadāso gṛhajaḥ krītadattrimau / paitriko daṇḍadāsaś ca saptaite dāsayonayaḥ //
column2: There are slaves of seven kinds, (viz.) he who is made a captive under a standard, he who serves for his daily food, he who is born in the house, he who is bought and he who is given, he who is inherited from ancestors, and he who is enslaved by way of punishment.

column1: bhāryā putraś ca dāsaś ca traya evādhanāḥ smṛtāḥ / yat te samadhigacchanti yasya te tasya tad dhanam //
column2: A wife, a son, and a slave, these three are declared to have no property; the wealth which they earn is (acquired) for him to whom they belong.

column1: visrabdhaṃ brāhmaṇaḥ śūdrād dravyopādānam ācaret / na hi tasyāsti kiṃ cit svaṃ bhartṛhāryadhano hi saḥ //
column2: A Brahmana may confidently seize the goods of (his) Sudra (slave); for, as that (slave) can have no property, his master may take his possessions.

column1: vaiśyaśūdrau prayatnena svāni karmāṇi kārayet / tau hi cyutau svakarmabhyaḥ kṣobhayetām idaṃ jagat //
column2: (The king) should carefully compel Vaisyas and Sudra to perform the work (prescribed) for them; for if these two (castes) swerved from their duties, they would throw this (whole) world into confusion.

column1: ahany ahany avekṣeta karmāntān vāhanāni ca / āyavyayau ca niyatāv ākarān kośam eva ca //
column2: Let him daily look after the completion of his undertakings, his beasts of burden, and carriages, (the collection of) his revenues and the disbursements, his mines and his treasury.

column1: evaṃ sarvān imān rājā vyavahārān samāpayan / vyapohya kilbiṣaṃ sarvaṃ prāpnoti paramāṃ gatim //
column2: A king who thus brings to a conclusion. all the legal business enumerated above, and removes all sin, reaches the highest state (of bliss).

column1: puruṣasya striyāś caiva dharme vartmani tiṣṭhatoḥ / saṃyoge viprayoge ca dharmān vakṣyāmi śāśvatān //
column2: I will now propound the eternal laws for a husband and his wife who keep to the path of duty, whether they be united or separated.

column1: asvatantrāḥ striyaḥ kāryāḥ puruṣaiḥ svair divāniśam / viṣayeṣu ca sajjantyaḥ saṃsthāpyā ātmano vaśe //
column2: Day and night woman must be kept in dependence by the males (of) their (families), and, if they attach themselves to sensual enjoyments, they must be kept under one's control.

column1: pitā rakṣati kaumāre bhartā rakṣati yauvane / rakṣanti sthavire putrā na strī svātantryam arhati //
column2: Her father protects (her) in childhood, her husband protects (her) in youth, and her sons protect (her) in old age; a woman is never fit for independence.

column1: kāle 'dātā pitā vācyo vācyaś cānupayan patiḥ / mṛte bhartari putras tu vācyo mātur arakṣitā //
column2: Reprehensible is the father who gives not (his daughter in marriage) at the proper time; reprehensible is the husband who approaches not (his wife in due season), and reprehensible is the son who does not protect his mother after her husband has died.

column1: sūkṣmebhyo 'pi prasaṅgebhyaḥ striyo rakṣyā viśeṣataḥ / dvayor hi kulayoḥ śokam āvaheyur arakṣitāḥ //
column2: Women must particularly be guarded against evil inclinations, however trifling (they may appear); for, if they are not guarded, they will bring sorrow on two families.

column1: imaṃ hi sarvavarṇānāṃ paśyanto dharmam uttamam / yatante rakṣituṃ bhāryāṃ bhartāro durbalā api //
column2: Considering that the highest duty of all castes, even weak husbands (must) strive to guard their wives.

column1: svāṃ prasūtiṃ caritraṃ ca kulam ātmānam eva ca / svaṃ ca dharmaṃ prayatnena jāyāṃ rakṣan hi rakṣati //
column2: He who carefully guards his wife, preserves (the purity of) his offspring, virtuous conduct, his family, himself, and his (means of acquiring) merit.

column1: patir bhāryāṃ saṃpraviśya garbho bhūtveha jāyate / jāyāyās tad dhi jāyātvaṃ yad asyāṃ jāyate punaḥ //
column2: The husband, after conception by his wife, becomes an embryo and is born again of her; for that is the wifehood of a wife (gaya), that he is born (gayate) again by her.

column1: yādṛśaṃ bhajate hi strī sutaṃ sūte tathāvidham / tasmāt prajāviśuddhyarthaṃ striyaṃ rakṣet prayatnataḥ //
column2: As the male is to whom a wife cleaves, even so is the son whom she brings forth; let him therefore carefully guard his wife, in order to keep his offspring pure.

column1: na kaś cid yoṣitaḥ śaktaḥ prasahya parirakṣitum / etair upāyayogais tu śakyās tāḥ parirakṣitum //
column2: No man can completely guard women by force; but they can be guarded by the employment of the (following) expedients:

column1: arthasya saṃgrahe caināṃ vyaye caiva niyojayet / śauce dharme 'nnapaktyāṃ ca pāriṇāhyasya vekṣaṇe //
column2: Let the (husband) employ his (wife) in the collection and expenditure of his wealth, in keeping (everything) clean, in (the fulfilment of) religious duties, in the preparation of his food, and in looking after the household utensils.

column1: arakṣitā gṛhe ruddhāḥ puruṣair āptakāribhiḥ / ātmānam ātmanā yās tu rakṣeyus tāḥ surakṣitāḥ //
column2: Women, confined in the house under trustworthy and obedient servants, are not (well) guarded; but those who of their own accord keep guard over themselves, are well guarded.

column1: pānaṃ durjanasaṃsargaḥ patyā ca viraho 'ṭanam / svapno 'nyagehavāsaś ca nārīsaṃdūṣaṇāni ṣaṭ //
column2: Drinking (spirituous liquor), associating with wicked people, separation from the husband, rambling abroad, sleeping (at unseasonable hours), and dwelling in other men's houses, are the six causes of the ruin of women.

column1: naitā rūpaṃ parīkṣante nāsāṃ vayasi saṃsthitiḥ / surūpaṃ vā virūpaṃ vā pumān ity eva bhuñjate //
column2: Women do not care for beauty, nor is their attention fixed on age; (thinking), '(It is enough that) he is a man,' they give themselves to the handsome and to the ugly.

column1: pauṃścalyāc calacittāc ca naisnehyāc ca svabhāvataḥ / rakṣitā yatnato 'pīha bhartṛṣv etā vikurvate //
column2: Through their passion for men, through their mutable temper, through their natural heartlessness, they become disloyal towards their husbands, however carefully they may be guarded in this (world).

column1: evaṃ svabhāvaṃ jñātvāsāṃ prajāpatinisargajam / paramaṃ yatnam ātiṣṭhet puruṣo rakṣaṇaṃ prati //
column2: Knowing their disposition, which the Lord of creatures laid in them at the creation, to be such, (every) man should most strenuously exert himself to guard them.

column1: śayyāsanam alaṅkāraṃ kāmaṃ krodham anārjavam M:anāryatām] / drohabhāvaṃ kucaryāṃ ca strībhyo manur akalpayat //
column2: (When creating them) Manu allotted to women (a love of their) bed, (of their) seat and (of) ornament, impure desires, wrath, dishonesty, malice, and bad conduct.

column1: nāsti strīṇāṃ kriyā mantrair iti dharme vyavasthitiḥ / nirindriyā hy amantrāś ca strībhyo 'nṛtam iti sthitiḥ //
column2: For women no (sacramental) rite (is performed) with sacred texts, thus the law is settled; women (who are) destitute of strength and destitute of (the knowledge of) Vedic texts, (are as impure as) falsehood (itself), that is a fixed rule.

column1: tathā ca śrutayo bahvyo nigītā nigameṣv api / svālakṣaṇyaparīkṣārthaṃ tāsāṃ śṛṇuta niṣkṛtīḥ //
column2: And to this effect many sacred texts are sung also in the Vedas, in order to (make) fully known the true disposition (of women); hear (now those texts which refer to) the expiation of their (sins).

column1: yan me mātā pralulubhe vicaranty apativratā / tan me retaḥ pitā vṛṅktām ity asyaitan nidarśanam //
column2: 'If my mother, going astray and unfaithful, conceived illicit desires, may my father keep that seed from me,' that is the scriptural text.

column1: dhyāyaty aniṣṭaṃ yat kiṃ cit pāṇigrāhasya cetasā / tasyaiṣa vyabhicārasya nihnavaḥ samyag ucyate //
column2: If a woman thinks in her heart of anything that would pain her husband, the (above-mentioned text) is declared (to be a means for) completely removing such infidelity.

column1: yādṛgguṇena bhartrā strī saṃyujyeta yathāvidhi / tādṛgguṇā sā bhavati samudreṇeva nimnagā //
column2: Whatever be the qualities of the man with whom a woman is united according to the law, such qualities even she assumes, like a river (united) with the ocean.

column1: akṣamālā vasiṣṭhena saṃyuktādhamayonijā / śāraṅgī mandapālena jagāmābhyarhaṇīyatām //
column2: Akshamala, a woman of the lowest birth, being united to Vasishtha and Sarangi, (being united) to Mandapala, became worthy of honour.

column1: etāś cānyāś ca loke 'sminn apakṛṣṭaprasūtayaḥ / utkarṣaṃ yoṣitaḥ prāptāḥ svaiḥ svair bhartṛguṇaiḥ śubhaiḥ // eṣoditā lokayātrā nityaṃ strīpuṃsayoḥ śubhā / pretyeha ca sukhodarkān prajādharmān nibodhata //
column2: These and other females of low birth have attained eminence in this world by the respective good qualities of their husbands. Thus has been declared the ever pure popular usage (which regulates the relations) between husband and wife; hear (next) the laws concerning children which are the cause of happiness in this world and after death.

column1: prajanārthaṃ mahābhāgāḥ pūjārhā gṛhadīptayaḥ / striyaḥ śriyaś ca geheṣu na viśeṣo 'sti kaś cana //
column2: Between wives (striyah) who (are destined) to bear children, who secure many blessings, who are worthy of worship and irradiate (their) dwellings, and between the goddesses of fortune (sriyah, who reside) in the houses (of men), there is no difference whatsoever.

column1: utpādanam apatyasya jātasya paripālanam / pratyahaṃ lokayātrāyāḥ pratyakṣaṃ strī nibandhanam //
column2: The production of children, the nurture of those born, and the daily life of men, (of these matters) woman is visibly the cause.

column1: apatyaṃ dharmakāryāṇi śuśrūṣā ratir uttamā / dārādhīnas tathā svargaḥ pitṝṇām ātmanaś ca ha // patiṃ yā nābhicarati manovāgdehasaṃyatā / sā bhartṛlokān āpnoti sadbhiḥ sādhvīti cocyate //
column2: Offspring, (the due performance on religious rites, faithful service, highest conjugal happiness and heavenly bliss for the ancestors and oneself, depend on one's wife alone. She who, controlling her thoughts, speech, and acts, violates not her duty towards her lord, dwells with him (after death) in heaven, and in this world is called by the virtuous a faithful (wife, sadhvi)

column1: vyabhicārāt tu bhartuḥ strī loke prāpnoti nindyatām / sṛgālayoniṃ cāpnoti pāparogaiś ca pīḍyate //
column2: But for disloyalty to her husband a wife is censured among men, and (in her next life) she is born in the womb of a jackal and tormented by diseases, the punishment of her sin.

column1: putraṃ pratyuditaṃ sadbhiḥ pūrvajaiś ca maharṣibhiḥ / viśvajanyam imaṃ puṇyam upanyāsaṃ nibodhata //
column2: Listen (now) to the following holy discussion, salutary to all men, which the virtuous (of the present day) and the ancient great sages have held concerning male offspring.

column1: bhartari putraṃ vijānanti śrutidvaidhaṃ tu kartari / āhur utpādakaṃ ke cid apare kṣetriṇaṃ viduḥ //
column2: They (all) say that the male issue (of a woman) belongs to the lord, but with respect to the (meaning of the term) lord the revealed texts differ; some call the begetter (of the child the lord), others declare (that it is) the owner of the soil.

column1: kṣetrabhūtā smṛtā nārī bījabhūtaḥ smṛtaḥ pumān / kṣetrabījasamāyogāt saṃbhavaḥ sarvadehinām //
column2: By the sacred tradition the woman is declared to be the soil, the man is declared to be the seed; the production of all corporeal beings (takes place) through the union of the soil with the seed.

column1: viśiṣṭaṃ kutra cid bījaṃ strīyonis tv eva kutra cit / ubhayaṃ tu samaṃ yatra sā prasūtiḥ praśasyate //
column2: In some cases the seed is more distinguished, and in some the womb of the female; but when both are equal, the offspring is most highly esteemed.

column1: bījasya caiva yonyāś ca bījam utkṛṣṭam ucyate / sarvabhūtaprasūtir hi bījalakṣaṇalakṣitā //
column2: On comparing the seed and the receptacle (of the seed), the seed is declared to be more important; for the offspring of all created beings is marked by the characteristics of the seed.

column1: yādṛśaṃ tūpyate bījaṃ kṣetre kālopapādite / tādṛg rohati tat tasmin bījaṃ svair vyañjitaṃ guṇaiḥ //
column2: Whatever (kind on seed is sown in a field, prepared in due season, (a plant) of that same kind, marked with the peculiar qualities of the seed, springs up in it.

column1: iyaṃ bhūmir hi bhūtānāṃ śāśvatī yonir ucyate / na ca yoniguṇān kāṃś cid bījaṃ puṣyati puṣṭiṣu //
column2: This earth, indeed, is called the primeval womb of created beings; but the seed develops not in its development any properties of the womb.

column1: bhūmāv apy ekakedāre kāloptāni kṛṣīvalaiḥ / nānārūpāṇi jāyante bījānīha svabhāvataḥ //
column2: In this world seeds of different kinds, sown at the proper time in the land, even in one field, come forth (each) according to its kind.

column1: vrīhayaḥ śālayo mudgās tilā māṣās tathā yavāḥ / yathābījaṃ prarohanti laśunānīkṣavas tathā //
column2: The rice (called) vrihi and (that called) sali, mudga-beans, sesamum, masha-beans, barley, leeks, and sugar-cane, (all) spring up according to their seed.

column1: anyad uptaṃ jātam anyad ity etan nopapadyate / upyate yad dhi yad bījaṃ tat tad eva prarohati //
column2: That one (plant) should be sown and another be produced cannot happen; whatever seed is sown, (a plant of) that kind even comes forth.

column1: tat prājñena vinītena jñānavijñānavedinā / āyuṣkāmena vaptavyaṃ na jātu parayoṣiti //
column2: Never therefore must a prudent well-trained man, who knows the Veda and its Angas and desires long life, cohabit with another's wife.

column1: atra gāthā vāyugītāḥ kīrtayanti purāvidaḥ / yathā bījaṃ na vaptavyaṃ puṃsā paraparigrahe //
column2: With respect to this (matter), those acquainted with the past recite some stanzas, sung by Vayu (the Wind, to show) that seed must not be sown by (any) man on that which belongs to another.

column1: naśyatīṣur yathā viddhaḥ khe viddham anuvidhyataḥ / tathā naśyati vai kṣipraṃ bījaṃ paraparigrahe //
column2: As the arrow, shot by (a hunter) who afterwards hits a wounded (deer) in the wound (made by another), is shot in vain, even so the seed, sown on what belongs to another, is quickly lost (to the sower).

column1: pṛthor apīmāṃ pṛthivīṃ bhāryāṃ pūrvavido viduḥ / sthāṇucchedasya kedāram āhuḥ śālyavato mṛgam //
column2: (Sages) who know the past call this earth (prithivi) even the wife of Prithu; they declare a field to belong to him who cleared away the timber, and a deer to him who (first) wounded it.

column1: etāvān eva puruṣo yaj jāyātmā prajeti ha / viprāḥ prāhus tathā caitad yo bhartā sā smṛtāṅganā //
column2: He only is a perfect man who consists (of three persons united), his wife, himself, and his offspring; thus (says the Veda), and (learned) Brahmanas propound this (maxim) likewise, 'The husband is declared to be one with the wife.'

column1: na niṣkrayavisargābhyāṃ bhartur bhāryā vimucyate / evaṃ dharmaṃ vijānīmaḥ prāk prajāpatinirmitam //
column2: Neither by sale nor by repudiation is a wife released from her husband; such we know the law to be, which the Lord of creatures (Pragapati) made of old.

column1: sakṛd aṃśo nipatati sakṛt kanyā pradīyate / sakṛd āha dadānīti trīṇy etāni satāṃ sakṛt //
column2: Once is the partition (of the inheritance) made, (once is) a maiden given in marriage, (and) once does (a man) say,' I will give;' each of those three (acts is done) once only.

column1: yathā go'śvoṣṭradāsīṣu mahiṣy ajāvikāsu ca / notpādakaḥ prajābhāgī tathaivānyāṅganāsv api //
column2: As with cows, mares, female camels, slave-girls, buffalo-cows, she-goats, and ewes, it is not the begetter (or his owner) who obtains the offspring, even thus (it is) with the wives of others.

column1: ye 'kṣetriṇo bījavantaḥ parakṣetrapravāpiṇaḥ / te vai sasyasya jātasya na labhante phalaṃ kva cit //
column2: Those who, having no property in a field, but possessing seed-corn, sow it in another's soil, do indeed not receive the grain of the crop which may spring up.

column1: yad anyagoṣu vṛṣabho vatsānāṃ janayec chatam / gominām eva te vatsā moghaṃ skanditam ārṣabham //
column2: If (one man's) bull were to beget a hundred calves on another man's cows, they would belong to the owner of the cows; in vain would the bull have spent his strength.

column1: tathaivākṣetriṇo bījaṃ parakṣetrapravāpiṇaḥ / kurvanti kṣetriṇām arthaṃ na bījī labhate phalam //
column2: Thus men who have no marital property in women, but sow their seed in the soil of others, benefit the owner of the woman; but the giver of the seed reaps no advantage.

column1: phalaṃ tv anabhisaṃdhāya kṣetriṇāṃ bījināṃ tathā / pratyakṣaṃ kṣetriṇām artho bījād yonir galīyasī //
column2: If no agreement with respect to the crop has been made between the owner of the field and the owner of the seed, the benefit clearly belongs to the owner of the field; the receptacle is more important than the seed.

column1: kriyābhyupagamāt tv etad bījārthaṃ yat pradīyate / tasyeha bhāginau dṛṣṭau bījī kṣetrika eva ca //
column2: But if by a special contract (a field) is made over (to another) for sowing, then the owner of the seed and the owner of the soil are both considered in this world as sharers of the (crop).

column1: oghavātāhṛtaṃ bījaṃ yasya kṣetre prarohati / kṣetrikasyaiva tad bījaṃ na vaptā labhate phalam //
column2: If seed be carried by water or wind into somebody's field and germinates (there), the (plant sprung from that) seed belongs even to the owner of the field, the owner of the seed does not receive the crop.

column1: eṣa dharmo gavāśvasya dāsyuṣṭrājāvikasya ca / vihaṃgamahiṣīṇāṃ ca vijñeyaḥ prasavaṃ prati //
column2: Know that such is the law concerning the offspring of cows, mares, slave-girls, female camels, she-goats, and ewes, as well as of females of birds and buffalo-cows.

column1: etad vaḥ sāraphalgutvaṃ bījayonyoḥ prakīrtitam / ataḥ paraṃ pravakṣyāmi yoṣitāṃ dharmam āpadi //
column2: Thus the comparative importance of the seed and of the womb has been declared to you; I will next propound the law (applicable) to women in times of misfortune.

column1: bhrātur jyeṣṭhasya bhāryā yā gurupatny anujasya sā / yavīyasas tu yā bhāryā snuṣā jyeṣṭhasya sā smṛtā //
column2: The wife of an elder brother is for his younger (brother) the wife of a Guru; but the wife of the younger is declared (to be) the daughter-in-law of the elder.

column1: jyeṣṭho yavīyaso bhāryāṃ yavīyān vāgrajastriyam / patitau bhavato gatvā niyuktāv apy anāpadi //
column2: An elder (brother) who approaches the wife of the younger, and a younger (brother who approaches) the wife of the elder, except in times of misfortune, both become outcasts, even though (they were duly) authorised.

column1: devarād vā sapiṇḍād vā striyā samyaṅ niyuktayā / prajepsitāādhigantavyā saṃtānasya parikṣaye //
column2: On failure of issue (by her husband) a woman who has been authorised, may obtain, (in the) proper (manner prescribed), the desired offspring by (cohabitation with) a brother-in-law or (with some other) Sapinda (of the husband).

column1: vidhavāyāṃ niyuktas tu ghṛtākto vāgyato niśi / ekam utpādayet putraṃ na dvitīyaṃ kathaṃ cana //
column2: He (who is) appointed to (cohabit with) the widow shall (approach her) at night anointed with clarified butter and silent, (and) beget one son, by no means a second.

column1: dvitīyam eke prajanaṃ manyante strīṣu tadvidaḥ / anirvṛtaṃ niyogārthaṃ paśyanto dharmatas tayoḥ //
column2: Some (sages), versed in the law, considering the purpose of the appointment not to have been attained by those two (on the birth of the first), think that a second (son) may be lawfully procreated on (such) women.

column1: vidhavāyāṃ niyogārthe nirvṛtte tu yathāvidhi / guruvac ca snuṣāvac ca varteyātāṃ parasparam // niyuktau yau vidhiṃ hitvā varteyātāṃ tu kāmataḥ / tāv ubhau patitau syātāṃ snuṣāgagurutalpagau //
column2: But when the purpose of the appointment to (cohabit with) the widow bas been attained in accordance with the law, those two shall behave towards each other like a father and a daughter-in-law. If those two (being thus) appointed deviate from the rule and act from carnal desire, they will both become outcasts, (as men) who defile the bed of a daughter-in-law or of a Guru.

column1: nānyasmin vidhavā nārī niyoktavyā dvijātibhiḥ / anyasmin hi niyuñjānā dharmaṃ hanyuḥ sanātanam //
column2: By twice-born men a widow must not be appointed to (cohabit with) any other (than her husband); for they who appoint (her) to another (man), will violate the eternal law.

column1: nodvāhikeṣu mantreṣu niyogaḥ kīrtyate kva cit / na vivāhavidhāv uktaṃ vidhavāvedanaṃ punaḥ //
column2: In the sacred texts which refer to marriage the appointment (of widows) is nowhere mentioned, nor is the re-marriage of widows prescribed in the rules concerning marriage.

column1: ayaṃ dvijair hi vidvadbhiḥ paśudharmo vigarhitaḥ / manuṣyāṇām api prokto vene rājyaṃ praśāsati //
column2: This practice which is reprehended by the learned of the twice-born castes as fit for cattle is said (to have occurred) even among men, while Vena ruled.

column1: sa mahīm akhilāṃ bhuñjan rājarṣipravaraḥ purā / varṇānāṃ saṃkaraṃ cakre kāmopahatacetanaḥ //
column2: That chief of royal sages who formerly possessed the whole world, caused a confusion of the castes (varna), his intellect being destroyed by lust.

column1: tataḥ prabhṛti yo mohāt pramītapatikāṃ striyam / niyojayaty apatyārthaṃ taṃ vigarhanti sādhavaḥ // yasyā mriyeta kanyāyā vācā satye kṛte patiḥ / tām anena vidhānena nijo vindeta devaraḥ //
column2: Since that (time) the virtuous censure that (man) who in his folly appoints a woman, whose husband died, to (bear) children (to another man). If the (future) husband of a maiden dies after troth verbally plighted, her brother-in-law shall wed her according to the following rule.

column1: yathāvidhy adhigamyaināṃ śuklavastrāṃ śucivratām / mitho bhajetā prasavāt sakṛtsakṛd ṛtāvṛtau //
column2: Having, according to the rule, espoused her (who must be) clad in white garments and be intent on purity, he shall approach her once in each proper season until issue (be had).

column1: na dattvā kasya cit kanyāṃ punar dadyād vicakṣaṇaḥ / dattvā punaḥ prayacchan hi prāpnoti puruṣānṛtam //
column2: Let no prudent man, after giving his daughter to one (man), give her again to another; for he who gives (his daughter) whom he had before given, incurs (the guilt of) speaking falsely regarding a human being.

column1: vidhivat pratigṛhyāpi tyajet kanyāṃ vigarhitām / vyādhitāṃ vipraduṣṭāṃ vā chadmanā copapāditām //
column2: Though (a man) may have accepted a damsel in due form, he may abandon (her if she be) blemished, diseased, or deflowered, and (if she have been) given with fraud.

column1: yas tu doṣavatīṃ kanyām anākhyāyopapādayet / tasya tad vitathaṃ kuryāt kanyādātur durātmanaḥ //
column2: If anybody gives away a maiden possessing blemishes without declaring them, (the bridegroom) may annul that (contract) with the evil-minded giver.

column1: vidhāya vṛttiṃ bhāryāyāḥ pravaset kāryavān naraḥ / avṛttikarśitā hi strī praduṣyet sthitimaty api // vidhāya proṣite vṛttiṃ jīven niyamam āsthitā / proṣite tv avidhāyaiva jīvec chilpair agarhitaiḥ //
column2: A man who has business (abroad) may depart after securing a maintenance for his wife; for a wife, even though virtuous, may be corrupted if she be distressed by want of subsistence. If (the husband) went on a journey after providing (for her), the wife shall subject herself to restraints in her daily life; but if he departed without providing (for her), she may subsist by blameless manual work.

column1: proṣito dharmakāryārthaṃ pratīkṣyo 'ṣṭau naraḥ samāḥ / vidyārthaṃ ṣaḍ yaśo'rthaṃ vā kāmārthaṃ trīṃs tu vatsarān //
column2: If the husband went abroad for some sacred duty, (she) must wait for him eight years, if (he went) to (acquire) learning or fame six (years), if (he went) for pleasure three years.

column1: saṃvatsaraṃ pratīkṣeta dviṣantīṃ yoṣitaṃ patiḥ / ūrdhvaṃ saṃvatsarāt tv enāṃ dāyaṃ hṛtvā na saṃvaset //
column2: For one year let a husband bear with a wife who hates him; but after (the lapse of) a year let him deprive her of her property and cease to cohabit with her.

column1: atikrāmet pramattaṃ yā mattaṃ rogārtam eva vā / sā trīn māsān parityājyā vibhūṣaṇaparicchadā //
column2: She who shows disrespect to (a husband) who is addicted to (some evil) passion, is a drunkard, or diseased, shall be deserted for three months (and be) deprived of her ornaments and furniture.

column1: unmattaṃ patitaṃ klībam abījaṃ pāparogiṇam / na tyāgo 'sti dviṣantyāś ca na ca dāyāpavartanam //
column2: But she who shows aversion towards a mad or outcast (husband), a eunuch, one destitute of manly strength, or one afflicted with such diseases as punish crimes, shall neither be cast off nor be deprived of her property.

column1: madyapāsādhuvṛttā ca pratikūlā ca yā bhavet / vyādhitā vādhivettavyā hiṃsrārthaghnī ca sarvadā //
column2: She who drinks spirituous liquor, is of bad conduct, rebellious, diseased, mischievous, or wasteful, may at any time be superseded (by another wife).

column1: vandhyāṣṭame 'dhivedyā'abde daśame tu mṛtaprajā / ekādaśe strījananī sadyas tv apriyavādinī //
column2: A barren wife may be superseded in the eighth year, she whose children (all) die in the tenth, she who bears only daughters in the eleventh, but she who is quarrelsome without delay.

column1: yā rogiṇī syāt tu hitā saṃpannā caiva śīlataḥ / sānujñāpyādhivettavyā nāvamānyā ca karhi cit //
column2: But a sick wife who is kind (to her husband) and virtuous in her conduct, may be superseded (only) with her own consent and must never be disgraced.

column1: adhivinnā tu yā nārī nirgacched ruṣitā gṛhāt / sā sadyaḥ saṃniroddhavyā tyājyā vā kulasaṃnidhau //
column2: A wife who, being superseded, in anger departs from (her husband's) house, must either be instantly confined or cast off in the presence of the family.

column1: pratiṣiddhāpi ced yā tu madyam abhyudayeṣv api / prekṣāsamājaṃ gacched vā sā daṇḍyā kṛṣṇalāni ṣaṭ //
