column2: But she who, though having been forbidden, drinks spirituous liquor even at festivals, or goes to public spectacles or assemblies, shall be fined six krishnalas.

column1: yadi svāś cāparāś caiva vinderan yoṣito dvijāḥ / tāsāṃ varṇakrameṇa syāj jyeṣṭhyaṃ pūjā ca veśma ca //
column2: If twice-born men wed women of their own and of other (lower castes), the seniority, honour, and habitation of those (wives) must be (settled) according to the order of the castes (varna).

column1: bhartuḥ śarīraśuśrūṣāṃ dharmakāryaṃ ca naityakam / svā caiva kuryāt sarveṣāṃ nāsvajātiḥ kathaṃ cana //
column2: Among all (twice-born men) the wife of equal caste alone, not a wife of a different caste by any means, shall personally attend her husband and assist him in his daily sacred rites.

column1: yas tu tat kārayen mohāt sajātyā sthitayānyayā / yathā brāhmaṇacāṇḍālaḥ pūrvadṛṣṭas tathaiva saḥ //
column2: But he who foolishly causes that (duty) to be performed by another, while his wife of equal caste is alive, is declared by the ancients (to be) as (despicable) as a Kandala (sprung from the) Brahmana (caste).

column1: utkṛṣṭāyābhirūpāya varāya sadṛśāya ca / aprāptām api tāṃ tasmai kanyāṃ dadyād yathāvidhi //
column2: To a distinguished, handsome suitor (of) equal (caste) should (a father) give his daughter in accordance with the prescribed rule, though she have not attained (the proper age).

column1: kāmam ā maraṇāt tiṣṭhed gṛhe kanyā rtumaty api / na caivaināṃ prayaccet tu guṇahīnāya karhi cit //
column2: (But) the maiden, though marriageable, should rather stop in (the father's) house until death, than that he should ever give her to a man destitute of good qualities.

column1: trīṇi varṣāṇy udīkṣeta kumāry ṛtumatī satī / ūrdhvaṃ tu kālād etasmād vindeta sadṛśaṃ patim //
column2: Three years let a damsel wait, though she be marriageable; but after that time let her choose for herself a bridegroom (of) equal (caste and rank).

column1: adīyamānā bhartāram adhigacched yadi svayam / nainaḥ kiṃ cid avāpnoti na ca yaṃ sādhigacchati //
column2: If, being not given in marriage, she herself seeks a husband, she incurs no guilt, nor (does) he whom she weds.

column1: alaṅkāraṃ nādadīta pitryaṃ kanyā svayaṃvarā / mātṛkaṃ bhrātṛdattaṃ vā stenā syād yadi taṃ haret // pitre na dadyāc chulkaṃ tu kanyām ṛtumatīṃ haran / sa ca svāmyād atikrāmed ṛtūnāṃ pratirodhanāt //
column2: A maiden who choses for herself, shall not take with her any ornaments, given by her father or her mother, or her brothers; if she carries them away, it will be theft. But he who takes (to wife) a marriageable damsel, shall not pay any nuptial fee to her father; for the (latter) will lose his dominion over her in consequence of his preventing (the legitimate result of the appearance of) her enemies.

column1: triṃśadvarṣo vahet kanyāṃ hṛdyāṃ dvādaśavārṣikīm / tryaṣṭavarṣo 'ṣṭavarṣāṃ vā dharme sīdati satvaraḥ //
column2: A man, aged thirty years, shall marry a maiden of twelve who pleases him, or a man of twenty-four a girl eight years of age; if (the performance of) his duties would (otherwise) be impeded, (he must marry) sooner.

column1: devadattāṃ patir bhāryāṃ vindate necchayātmanaḥ / tāṃ sādhvīṃ bibhṛyān nityaṃ devānāṃ priyam ācaran //
column2: The husband receives his wife from the gods, (he does not wed her) according to his own will; doing what is agreeable to the gods, he must always support her (while she is) faithful.

column1: prajanārthaṃ striyaḥ sṛṣṭāḥ saṃtānārthaṃ ca mānavaḥ / tasmāt sādhāraṇo dharmaḥ śrutau patnyā sahoditaḥ //
column2: To be mothers were women created, and to be fathers men; religious rites, therefore, are ordained in the Veda to be performed (by the husband) together with the wife.

column1: kanyāyāṃ dattaśulkāyāṃ mriyeta yadi śulkadaḥ / devarāya pradātavyā yadi kanyānumanyate //
column2: If, after the nuptial fee has been paid for a maiden, the giver of the fee dies, she shall be given in marriage to his brother, in case she consents.

column1: ādadīta na śūdro 'pi śulkaṃ duhitaraṃ dadan / śulkaṃ hi gṛhṇan kurute channaṃ duhitṛvikrayam //
column2: Even a Sudra ought not to take a nuptial fee, when he gives away his daughter; for he who takes a fee sell his daughter, covering (the transaction by another name).

column1: etat tu na pare cakrur nāpare jātu sādhavaḥ / yad anyasya pratijñāya punar anyasya dīyate //
column2: Neither ancients nor moderns who were good men have done such (a deed) that, after promising (a daughter) to one man, they have her to another;

column1: nānuśuśruma jātv etat pūrveṣv api hi janmasu / śulkasaṃjñena mūlyena channaṃ duhitṛvikrayam //
column2: Nor, indeed, have we heard, even in former creations, of such (a thing as) the covert sale of a daughter for a fixed price, called a nuptial fee.

column1: anyonyasyāvyabhicāro bhaved āmaraṇāntikaḥ / eṣa dharmaḥ samāsena jñeyaḥ strīpuṃsayoḥ paraḥ //
column2: 'Let mutual fidelity continue until death,' this may be considered as the summary of the highest law for husband and wife.

column1: tathā nityaṃ yateyātāṃ strīpuṃsau tu kṛtakriyau / yathā nābhicaretāṃ tau viyuktāv itaretaram //
column2: Let man and woman, united in marriage, constantly exert themselves, that (they may not be) disunited (and) may not violate their mutual fidelity.

column1: eṣa strīpuṃsayor ukto dharmo vo ratisaṃhitaḥ / āpady apatyaprāptiś ca dāyadharmaṃ nibodhata //
column2: Thus has been declared to you the law for a husband and his wife, which is intimately connected with conjugal happiness, and the manner of raising offspring in times of calamity; learn (now the law concerning) the division of the inheritance.

column1: ūrdhvaṃ pituś ca mātuś ca sametya bhrātaraḥ samam / bhajeran paitṛkaṃ riktham anīśās te hi jīvatoḥ // jyeṣṭha eva tu gṛhṇīyāt pitryaṃ dhanam aśeṣataḥ / śeṣās tam upajīveyur yathaiva pitaraṃ tathā // jyeṣṭhena jātamātreṇa putrī bhavati mānavaḥ / pitṝṇām anṛṇaś caiva sa tasmāt sarvam arhati //
column2: After the death of the father and of the mother, the brothers, being assembled, may divide among themselves in equal shares the paternal (and the maternal) estate; for, they have no power (over it) while the parents live. (Or) the eldest alone may take the whole paternal estate, the others shall live under him just as (they lived) under their father. Immediately on the birth of his first-born a man is (called) the father of a son and is freed from the debt to the manes; that (son), therefore, is worthy (to receive) the whole estate.

column1: yasminn ṛṇaṃ saṃnayati yena cānantyam aśnute / sa eva dharmajaḥ putraḥ kāmajān itarān viduḥ //
column2: That son alone on whom he throws his debt and through whom he obtains immortality, is begotten for (the fulfilment of) the law; all the rest they consider the offspring of desire.

column1: piteva pālayet pūtrān jyeṣṭho bhrātṝṇ yavīyasaḥ / putravac cāpi varteran jyeṣṭhe bhrātari dharmataḥ //
column2: As a father (supports) his sons, so let the eldest support his younger brothers, and let them also in accordance with the law behave towards their eldest brother as sons (behave towards their father).

column1: jyeṣṭhaḥ kulaṃ vardhayati vināśayati vā punaḥ / jyeṣṭhaḥ pūjyatamo loke jyeṣṭhaḥ sadbhir agarhitaḥ //
column2: The eldest (son) makes the family prosperous or, on the contrary, brings it to ruin; the eldest (is considered) among men most worthy of honour, the eldest is not treated with disrespect by the virtuous.

column1: yo jyeṣṭho jyeṣṭhavṛttiḥ syān māteva sa piteva saḥ / ajyeṣṭhavṛttir yas tu syāt sa saṃpūjyas tu bandhuvat //
column2: If the eldest brother behaves as an eldest brother (ought to do), he (must be treated) like a mother and like a father; but if he behaves in a manner unworthy of an eldest brother, he should yet be honoured like a kinsman.

column1: evaṃ saha vaseyur vā pṛthag vā dharmakāmyayā / pṛthag vivardhate dharmas tasmād dharmyā pṛthakkriyā //
column2: Either let them thus live together, or apart, if (each) desires (to gain) spiritual merit; for (by their living) separate (their) merit increases, hence separation is meritorious.

column1: jyeṣṭhasya viṃśa uddhāraḥ sarvadravyāc ca yad varam / tato 'rdhaṃ madhyamasya syāt turīyaṃ tu yavīyasaḥ //
column2: The additional share (deducted) for the eldest shall be one-twentieth (of the estate) and the best of all chattels, for the middlemost half of that, but for the youngest one-fourth.

column1: jyeṣṭhaś caiva kaniṣṭhaś ca saṃharetāṃ yathoditam / ye 'nye jyeṣṭhakaniṣṭhābhyāṃ teṣāṃ syān madhyamaṃ dhanam //
column2: Both the eldest and the youngest shall take (their shares) according to (the rule just) stated (each of) those who are between the eldest and the youngest, shall have the share (prescribed for the) middlemost.

column1: sarveṣāṃ dhanajātānām ādadītāgryam agrajaḥ / yac ca sātiśayaṃ kiṃ cid daśataś cāpnuyād varam //
column2: Among the goods of every kind the eldest shall take the best (article), and (even a single chattel) which is particularly good, as well as the best of ten (animals).

column1: uddhāro na daśasv asti saṃpannānāṃ svakarmasu / yat kiṃ cid eva deyaṃ tu jyāyase mānavardhanam //
column2: But among (brothers) equally skilled in their occupations, there is no additional share, (consisting of the best animal) among ten; some trifle only shall be given to the eldest as a token of respect.

column1: evaṃ samuddhṛtoddhāre samān aṃśān prakalpayet / uddhāre 'nuddhṛte tv eṣām iyaṃ syād aṃśakalpanā //
column2: If additional shares are thus deducted, one must allot equal shares (out of the residue to each); but if no deduction is made, the allotment of the shares among them shall be (made) in the following manner.

column1: ekādhikaṃ harej jyeṣṭhaḥ putro 'dhyardhaṃ tato 'nujaḥ / aṃśam aṃśaṃ yavīyāṃsa iti dharmo vyavasthitaḥ //
column2: Let the eldest son take one share in excess, the (brother) born next after him one (share) and a half, the younger ones one share each; thus the law is settled.

column1: svebhyo 'ṃśebhyas tu kanyābhyaḥ pradadyur bhrātaraḥ pṛthak / svāt svād aṃśāc caturbhāgaṃ patitāḥ syur aditsavaḥ //
column2: But to the maiden (sisters) the brothers shall severally give (portions) out of their shares, each out of his share one-fourth part; those who refuse to give (it), will become outcasts.

column1: ajāvikaṃ saikaśaphaṃ na jātu viṣamaṃ bhajet / ajāvikaṃ tu viṣamaṃ jyeṣṭhasyaiva vidhīyate //
column2: Let him never divide (the value of) a single goat or sheep, or a (single beast) with uncloven hoofs; it is prescribed (that) a single goat or sheep (remaining after an equal division, belongs) to the eldest alone.

column1: yavīyāñ jyeṣṭhabhāryāyāṃ putram utpādayed yadi / samas tatra vibhāgaḥ syād iti dharmo vyavasthitaḥ //
column2: If a younger brother begets a son on the wife of the elder, the division must then be made equally; this the law is settled.

column1: upasarjanaṃ pradhānasya dharmato nopapadyate / pitā pradhānaṃ prajane tasmād dharmeṇa taṃ bhajet //
column2: The representative (the son begotten on the wife) is not invested with the right of the principal (the eldest brother to an additional share); the principal (became) a father on the procreation (of a son by his younger brother); hence one should give a share to the (son begotten on the wife of the elder brother) according to the rule (stated above).

column1: putraḥ kaniṣṭho jyeṣṭhāyāṃ kaniṣṭhāyāṃ ca pūrvajaḥ / kathaṃ tatra vibhāgaḥ syād iti cet saṃśayo bhavet //
column2: If there be a doubt, how the division shall be made, in case the younger son is born of the elder wife and the elder son of the younger wife,

column1: ekaṃ vṛṣabham uddhāraṃ saṃhareta sa pūrvajaḥ / tato 'pare jyeṣṭhavṛṣās tadūnānāṃ svamātṛtaḥ // jyeṣṭhas tu jāto jyeṣṭhāyāṃ hared vṛṣabhaṣoḍaśāḥ / tataḥ svamātṛtaḥ śeṣā bhajerann iti dhāraṇā //
column2: (Then the son) born of the first wife shall take as his additional share one (most excellent) bull; the next best bulls (shall belong) to those (who are) inferior on account of their mothers. But the eldest (son, being) born of the eldest wife, shall receive fifteen cows and a bull, the other sons may then take shares according to (the seniority of) their mothers; that is a settled rule.

column1: sadṛśastrīṣu jātānāṃ putrāṇām aviśeṣataḥ / na mātṛto jyaiṣṭhyam asti janmato jyaiṣṭhyam ucyate //
column2: Between sons born of wives equal (in caste) (and) without (any other) distinction no seniority in right of the mother exists; seniority is declared (to be) according to birth.

column1: janmajyeṣṭhena cāhvānaṃ subrahmaṇyāsv api smṛtam / yamayoś caiva garbheṣu janmato jyeṣṭhatā smṛtā //
column2: And with respect to the Subrahmanya (texts) also it is recorded that the invocation (of Indra shall be made) by the first-born, of twins likewise, (conceived at one time) in the wombs (of their mothers) the seniority is declared (to depend) on (actual) birth.

column1: aputro 'nena vidhinā sutāṃ kurvīta putrikām / yad apatyaṃ bhaved asyāṃ tan mama syāt svadhākaram //
column2: He who has no son may make his daughter in the following manner an appointed daughter (putrika, saying to her husband), 'The (male) child, born of her, shall perform my funeral rites.'

column1: anena tu vidhānena purā cakre 'tha putrikāḥ / vivṛddhyarthaṃ svavaṃśasya svayaṃ dakṣaḥ prajāpatiḥ //
column2: According to this rule Daksha, himself, lord of created beings, formerly made (all his female offspring) appointed daughters in order to multiply his race.

column1: dadau sa daśa dharmāya kaśyapāya trayodaśa / somāya rājñe satkṛtya prītātmā saptaviṃśatim //
column2: He gave ten to Dharma, thirteen to Kasyapa, twenty-seven to King Soma, honouring (them) with an affectionate heart.

column1: yathaivātmā tathā putraḥ putreṇa duhitā samā / tasyām ātmani tiṣṭhantyāṃ katham anyo dhanaṃ haret //
column2: A son is even (as) oneself, (such) a daughter is equal to a son; how can another (heir) take the estate, while such (an appointed daughter who is even) oneself, lives?

column1: mātus tu yautakaṃ yat syāt kumārībhāga eva saḥ / dauhitra eva ca hared aputrasyākhilaṃ dhanam //
column2: But whatever may be the separate property of the mother, that is the share of the unmarried daughter alone; and the son of an (appointed) daughter shall take the whole estate of (his maternal grandfather) who leaves no son.

column1: dauhitro hy akhilaṃ riktham aputrasya pitur haret / sa eva dadyād dvau piṇḍau pitre mātāmahāya ca //
column2: The son of an (appointed) daughter, indeed, shall (also) take the estate of his (own) father, who leaves no (other) son; he shall (then) present two funeral cakes to his own father and to his maternal grandfather.

column1: pautradauhitrayor loke na viśeṣo 'sti dharmataḥ / tayor hi mātāpitarau saṃbhūtau tasya dehataḥ //
column2: Between a son's son and the son of an (appointed) daughter there is no difference, neither with respect to worldly matters nor to sacred duties; for their father and mother both sprang from the body of the same (man).

column1: putrikāyāṃ kṛtāyāṃ tu yadi putro 'nujāyate / samas tatra vibhāgaḥ syāj jyeṣṭhatā nāsti hi striyāḥ //
column2: But if, after a daughter has been appointed, a son be born (to her father), the division (of the inheritance) must in that (case) be equal; for there is no right of primogeniture for a woman.

column1: aputrāyāṃ mṛtāyāṃ tu putrikāyāṃ kathaṃ cana / dhanaṃ tat putrikābhartā haretaivāvicārayan // akṛtā vā kṛtā vāpi yaṃ vindet sadṛśāt sutam / pautrī mātāmahas tena dadyāt piṇḍaṃ hared dhanam //
column2: But if an appointed daughter by accident dies without (leaving) a son, the husband of the appointed daughter may, without hesitation, take that estate. Through that son whom (a daughter), either not appointed or appointed, may bear to (a husband) of equal (caste), his maternal grandfather (has) a son's son; he shall present the funeral cake and take the estate.

column1: putreṇa lokāñ jayati pautreṇānantyam aśnute / atha putrasya pautreṇa bradhnasyāpnoti viṣṭapam //
column2: Through a son he conquers the worlds, through a son's son he obtains immortality, but through his son's grandson he gains the world of the sun.

column1: puṃnāmno narakād yasmāt trāyate pitaraṃ sutaḥ / tasmāt putra iti proktaḥ svayam eva svayaṃbhuvā //
column2: Because a son delivers (trayate) his father from the hell called Put, he was therefore called put-tra (a deliverer from Put) by the Self-existent (Svayambhu) himself.

column1: pautradauhitrayor loke viśeṣo nopapadyate / dauhitro 'pi hy amutrainaṃ saṃtārayati pautravat //
column2: Between a son's son and the son of a daughter there exists in this world no difference; for even the son of a daughter saves him (who has no sons) in the next world, like the son's son.

column1: mātuḥ prathamataḥ piṇḍaṃ nirvapet putrikāsutaḥ / dvitīyaṃ tu pitus tasyās tṛtīyaṃ tatpituḥ pituḥ //
column2: Let the son of an appointed daughter first present a funeral cake to his mother, the second to her father, the funeral to his father's father.

column1: upapanno guṇaiḥ sarvaiḥ putro yasya tu dattrimaḥ / sa haretaiva tadrikthaṃ saṃprāpto 'py anyagotrataḥ //
column2: Of the man who has an adopted (Datrima) son possessing all good qualities, that same (son) shall take the inheritance, though brought from another family.

column1: gotrarikthe janayitur na hared dattrimaḥ kva cit / gotrarikthānugaḥ piṇḍo vyapaiti dadataḥ svadhā //
column2: An adopted son shall never take the family (name) and the estate of his natural father; the funeral cake follows the family (name) and the estate, the funeral offerings of him who gives (his son in adoption) cease (as far as that son is concerned).

column1: aniyuktāsutaś caiva putriṇyāptaś ca devarāt / ubhau tau nārhato bhāgaṃ jārajātakakāmajau //
column2: The son of a wife, not appointed (to have issue by another), and he whom (an appointed female, already) the mother of a son, bears to her brother-in-law, are both unworthy of a share, (one being) the son of an adulterer and (the other) produced through (mere) lust.

column1: niyuktāyām api pumān nāryāṃ jāto 'vidhānataḥ / naivārhaḥ paitṛkaṃ rikthaṃ patitotpādito hi saḥ //
column2: Even the male (child) of a female (duly) appointed, not begotten according to the rule (given above), is unworthy of the paternal estate; for he was procreated by an outcast.

column1: haret tatra niyuktāyāṃ jātaḥ putro yathāurasaḥ / kṣetrikasya tu tad bījaṃ dharmataḥ prasavaś ca saḥ //
column2: A son (legally) begotten on such an appointed female shall inherit like a legitimate son of the body; for that seed and the produce belong, according to the law, to the owner of the soil.

column1: dhanaṃ yo bibhṛyād bhrātur mṛtasya striyam eva ca / so 'patyaṃ bhrātur utpādya dadyāt tasyaiva taddhanam // yā niyuktānyataḥ putraṃ devarād vāpy avāpnuyāt / taṃ kāmajam arikthīyaṃ vṛthotpannaṃ pracakṣate //
column2: He who takes care of his deceased brother's estate and of his widow, shall, after raising up a son for his brother, give that property even to that (son). If a woman (duly) appointed bears a son to her brother-in-law or to another (Sapinda), that (son, if he is) begotten through desire, they declare (to be) incapable of inheriting and to be produced in vain.

column1: etad vidhānaṃ vijñeyaṃ vibhāgasyaikayoniṣu / bahvīṣu caikajātānāṃ nānāstrīṣu nibodhata //
column2: The rules (given above) must be understood (to apply) to a distribution among sons of women of the same (caste); hear (now the law) concerning those begotten by one man on many wives of different (castes).

column1: brāhmaṇasyānupūrvyeṇa catasras tu yadi striyaḥ / tāsāṃ putreṣu jāteṣu vibhāge 'yaṃ vidhiḥ smṛtaḥ //
column2: If there be four wives of a Brahmana in the direct order of the castes, the rule for the division (of the estate) among the sons born of them is as follows:

column1: kīnāśo govṛṣo yānam alaṅkāraś ca veśma ca / viprasyāuddhārikaṃ deyam ekāṃśaś ca pradhānataḥ //
column2: The (slave) who tills (the field), the bull kept for impregnating cows, the vehicle, the ornaments, and the house shall be given as an additional portion to the Brahmana (son), and one most excellent share.

column1: tryaṃśaṃ dāyād dhared vipro dvāv aṃśau kṣatriyāsutaḥ / vaiśyājaḥ sārdham evāṃśam aṃśaṃ śūdrāsuto haret //
column2: Let the son of the Brahmana (wife) take three shares of the (remainder of the) estate, the son of the Kshatriya two, the son of the Vaisya a share and a half, and the son of the Sudra may take one share.

column1: sarvaṃ vā rikthajātaṃ tad daśadhā parikalpya ca / dharmyaṃ vibhāgaṃ kurvīta vidhinānena dharmavit //
column2: Or let him who knows the law make ten shares of the whole estate, and justly distribute them according to the following rule:

column1: caturo 'ṃśān hared vipras trīn aṃśān kṣatriyāsutaḥ / vaiśyāputro hared dvyaṃśaṃ aṃśaṃ śūdrāsuto haret //
column2: The Brahmana (son) shall take four shares, son of the Kshatriya (wife) three, the son of the Vaisya shall have two parts, the son of the Sudra may take one share.

column1: yady api syāt tu satputro 'py asatputro 'pi vā bhavet / nādhikaṃ daśamād dadyāc chūdrāputrāya dharmataḥ //
column2: Whether (a Brahmana) have sons or have no sons (by wives of the twice-born castes), the (heir) must, according to the law, give to the son of a Sudra (wife) no more than a tenth (part of his estate).

column1: brāhmaṇakṣatriyaviśāṃ śūdrāputro na rikthabhāk / yad evāsya pitā dadyāt tad evāsya dhanaṃ bhavet //
column2: The son of a Brahmana, a Kshatriya, and a Vaisya by a Sudra (wife) receives no share of the inheritance; whatever his father may give to him, that shall be his property.

column1: samavarṇāsu vā jātāḥ sarve putrā dvijanmanām / uddhāraṃ jyāyase dattvā bhajerann itare samam //
column2: All the sons of twice-born men, born of wives of the same caste, shall equally divide the estate, after the others have given to the eldest an additional share.

column1: śūdrasya tu savarṇaiva nānyā bhāryā vidhīyate / tasyāṃ jātāḥ samāṃśāḥ syur yadi putraśataṃ bhavet //
column2: For a Sudra is ordained a wife of his own caste only (and) no other; those born of her shall have equal shares, even if there be a hundred sons.

column1: putrān dvādaśa yān āha nṝṇāṃ svāyaṃbhuvo manuḥ / teṣāṃ ṣaḍ bandhudāyādāḥ ṣaḍ adāyādabāndhavāḥ //
column2: Among the twelve sons of men whom Manu, sprung from the Self-existent (Svayambhu), enumerates, six are kinsmen and heirs, and six not heirs, (but) kinsmen.

column1: aurasaḥ kṣetrajaś caiva dattaḥ kṛtrima eva ca / gūḍhotpanno 'paviddhaś ca dāyādā bāndhavāś ca ṣaṭ // kānīnaś ca sahoḍhaś ca krītaḥ paunarbhavas tathā / svayaṃdattaś ca śaudraś ca ṣaḍ adāyādabāndhavāḥ //
column2: The legitimate son of the body, the son begotten on a wife, the son adopted, the son made, the son secretly born, and the son cast off, (are) the six heirs and kinsmen. The son of an unmarried damsel, the son received with the wife, the son bought, the son begotten on a re-married woman, the son self-given, and the son of a Sudra female, (are) the six (who are) not heirs, (but) kinsmen.

column1: yādṛśaṃ phalam āpnoti kuplavaiḥ saṃtarañ jalam / tādṛśaṃ phalam āpnoti kuputraiḥ saṃtaraṃs tamaḥ //
column2: Whatever result a man obtains who (tries to) cross a (sheet of) water in an unsafe boat, even that result obtains he who (tries to) pass the gloom (of the next world) with (the help of) bad (substitutes for a real) son.

column1: yady ekarikthinau syātām aurasakṣetrajau sutau / yasya yat paitṛkaṃ rikthaṃ sa tad gṛhṇīta netaraḥ // eka evāurasaḥ putraḥ pitryasya vasunaḥ prabhuḥ / śeṣāṇām ānṛśaṃsyārthaṃ pradadyāt tu prajīvanam //
column2: If the two heirs of one man be a legitimate son of his body and a son begotten on his wife, each (of the two sons), to the exclusion of the other, shall take the estate of his (natural) father. The legitimate son of the body alone (shall be) the owner of the paternal estate; but, in order to avoid harshness, let him allow a maintenance to the rest.

column1: ṣaṣṭhaṃ tu kṣetrajasyāṃśaṃ pradadyāt paitṛkād dhanāt / auraso vibhajan dāyaṃ pitryaṃ pañcamam eva vā //
column2: But when the legitimate son of the body divides the paternal estate, he shall give one-sixth or one-fifth part of his father's property to the son begotten on the wife.

column1: aurasakṣetrajau putrau pitṛrikthasya bhāginau / daśāpare tu kramaśo gotrarikthāṃśabhāginaḥ // svakṣetre saṃskṛtāyāṃ tu svayam utpādayed dhi yam / tam aurasaṃ vijānīyāt putraṃ prāthamakalpikam //
column2: The legitimate son and the son of the wife (thus) share the father's estate; but the other tell become members of the family, and inherit according to their order (each later named on failure of those named earlier). Him whom a man begets on his own wedded wife, let him know to be a legitimate son of the body (Aurasa), the first in rank.

column1: yas talpajaḥ pramītasya klībasya vyādhitasya vā / svadharmeṇa niyuktāyāṃ sa putraḥ kṣetrajaḥ smṛtaḥ //
column2: He who was begotten according to the peculiar law (of the Niyoga) on the appointed wife of a dead man, of a eunuch, or of one diseased, is called a son begotten on a wife (Kshetraga).

column1: mātā pitā vā dadyātāṃ yam adbhiḥ putram āpadi / sadṛśaṃ prītisaṃyuktaṃ sa jñeyo dattrimaḥ sutaḥ //
column2: That (boy) equal (by caste) whom his mother or his father affectionately give, (confirming the gift) with (a libation of) water, in times of distress (to a man) as his son, must be considered as an adopted son (Datrima).

column1: sadṛśaṃ tu prakuryād yaṃ guṇadoṣavicakṣaṇam / putraṃ putraguṇair yuktaṃ sa vijñeyaś ca kṛtrimaḥ //
column2: But he is considered a son made (Kritrima) whom (a man) makes his son, (he being) equal (by caste), acquainted with (the distinctions between) right and wrong, (and) endowed with filial virtues.

column1: utpadyate gṛhe yas tu na ca jñāyeta kasya saḥ / sa gṛhe gūḍha utpannas tasya syād yasya talpajaḥ //
column2: If (a child) be born in a man's house and his father be not known, he is a son born secretly in the house (Gudhotpanna), and shall belong to him of whose wife he was born.

column1: mātāpitṛbhyām utsṛṣṭaṃ tayor anyatareṇa vā / yaṃ putraṃ parigṛhṇīyād apaviddhaḥ sa ucyate //
column2: He whom (a man) receives as his son, (after he has been) deserted by his parents or by either of them, is called a son cast off (Apaviddha).

column1: pitṛveśmani kanyā tu yaṃ putraṃ janayed rahaḥ / taṃ kānīnaṃ vaden nāmnā voḍhuḥ kanyāsamudbhavam //
column2: A son whom a damsel secretly bears in the house of her father, one shall name the son of an unmarried damsel (Kanina, and declare) such offspring of an unmarried girl (to belong) to him who weds her (afterwards).

column1: yā garbhiṇī saṃskriyate jñātājñātāpi vā satī / voḍhuḥ sa garbho bhavati sahoḍha iti cocyate //
column2: If one marries, either knowingly or unknowingly, a pregnant (bride), the child in her womb belongs to him who weds her, and is called (a son) received with the bride (Sahodha).

column1: krīṇīyād yas tv apatyārthaṃ mātāpitror yam antikāt / sa krītakaḥ sutas tasya sadṛśo 'sadṛśo 'pi vā //
column2: If a man buys a (boy), whether equal or unequal (in good qualities), from his father and mother for the sake of having a son, that (child) is called a (son) bought (Kritaka).

column1: yā patyā vā parityaktā vidhavā vā svayecchayā / utpādayet punar bhūtvā sa paunarbhava ucyate //
column2: If a woman abandoned by her husband, or a widow, of her own accord contracts a second marriage and bears (a son), he is called the son of a re-married woman (Paunarbhava).

column1: sā ced akṣatayoniḥ syād gatapratyāgatāpi vā / paunarbhavena bhartrā sā punaḥ saṃskāram arhati //
column2: If she be (still) a virgin, or one who returned (to her first husband) after leaving him, she is worthy to again perform with her second (or first deserted) husband the (nuptial) ceremony.

column1: mātāpitṛvihīno yas tyakto vā syād akāraṇāt / ātmānam arpayed yasmai svayaṃdattas tu sa smṛtaḥ //
column2: He who, having lost his parents or being abandoned (by them) without (just) cause, gives himself to a (man), is called a son self-given (Svayamdatta).

column1: yaṃ brāhmaṇas tu śūdrāyāṃ kāmād utpādayet sutam / sa pārayann eva śavas tasmāt pāraśavaḥ smṛtaḥ //
column2: The son whom a Brahmana begets through lust on a Sudra female is, (though) alive (parayan), a corpse (sava), and hence called a Parasava (a living corpse).

column1: dāsyāṃ vā dāsadāsyāṃ vā yaḥ śūdrasya suto bhavet / so 'nujñāto hared aṃśam iti dharmo vyavasthitaḥ //
column2: A son who is (begotten) by a Sudra on a female slave, or on the female slave of his slave, may, if permitted (by his father), take a share (of the inheritance); thus the law is settled.

column1: kṣetrajādīn sutān etān ekādaśa yathoditān / putrapratinidhīn āhuḥ kriyālopān manīṣiṇaḥ //
column2: These eleven, the son begotten on the wife and the rest as enumerated (above), the wise call substitutes for a son, (taken) in order (to prevent) a failure of the (funeral) ceremonies.

column1: ya ete 'bhihitāḥ putrāḥ prasaṅgād anyabījajāḥ / yasya te bījato jātās tasya te netarasya tu //
column2: Those sons, who have been mentioned in connection with (the legitimate son of the body), being begotten by strangers, belong (in reality) to him from whose seed they sprang, but not to the other (man who took them).

column1: bhrātṝṇām ekajātānām ekaś cet putravān bhavet / sarvāṃs tāṃs tena putreṇa putriṇo manur abravīt // sarvāsām ekapatnīnām ekā cet putriṇī bhavet / sarvās tās tena putreṇa prāha putravatīr manuḥ //
column2: If among brothers, sprung from one (father), one have a son, Manu has declared them all to have male offspring through that son. If among all the wives of one husband one have a son, Manu declares them all (to be) mothers of male children through that son.

column1: śreyasaḥ śreyaso 'lābhe pāpīyān riktham arhati / bahavaś cet tu sadṛśāḥ sarve rikthasya bhāginaḥ //
column2: On failure of each better (son), each next inferior (one) is worthy of the inheritance; but if there be many (of) equal (rank), they shall all share the estate.

column1: na bhrātaro na pitaraḥ putrā rikthaharāḥ pituḥ / pitā hared aputrasya rikthaṃ bhrātara eva ca //
column2: Not brothers, nor fathers, (but) sons take the paternal estate; but the father shall take the inheritance of (a son) who leaves no male issue, and his brothers.

column1: trayāṇām udakaṃ kāryaṃ triṣu piṇḍaḥ pravartate / caturthaḥ saṃpradātaiṣāṃ pañcamo nopapadyate //
column2: To three (ancestors) water must be offered, to three the funeral cake is given, the fourth (descendant is) the giver of these (oblations), the fifth has no connection (with them).

column1: anantaraḥ sapiṇḍād yas tasya tasya dhanaṃ bhavet / ata ūrdhvaṃ sakulyaḥ syād ācāryaḥ śiṣya eva vā //
column2: Always to that (relative within three degrees) who is nearest to the (deceased) Sapinda the estate shall belong; afterwards a Sakulya shall be (the heir, then) the spiritual teacher or the pupil.

column1: sarveṣām apy abhāve tu brāhmaṇā rikthabhāginaḥ / traividyāḥ śucayo dāntās tathā dharmo na hīyate //
column2: But on failure of all (heirs) Brahmanas (shall) share the estate, (who are) versed the in the three Vedas, pure and self-controlled; thus the law is not violated.

column1: ahāryaṃ brāhmaṇadravyaṃ rājñā nityam iti sthitiḥ / itareṣāṃ tu varṇānāṃ sarvābhāve haren nṛpaḥ //
column2: The property of a Brahmana must never be taken by the king, that is a settled rule; but (the property of men) of other castes the king may take on failure of all (heirs).

column1: saṃsthitasyānapatyasya sagotrāt putram āharet / tatra yad rikthajātaṃ syāt tat tasmin pratipādayet //
column2: (If the widow) of (a man) who died without leaving issue, raises up to him a son by a member of the family (Sagotra), she shall deliver to that (son) the whole property which belonged to the (deceased).

column1: dvau tu yau vivadeyātāṃ dvābhyāṃ jātau striyā dhane / tayor yad yasya pitryaṃ syāt tat sa gṛhṇīta netaraḥ //
column2: But if two (sons), begotten by two (different men), contend for the property (in the hands) of their mother, each shall take, to the exclusion of the other, what belonged to his father.

column1: jananyāṃ saṃsthitāyāṃ tu samaṃ sarve sahodarāḥ / bhajeran mātṛkaṃ rikthaṃ bhaginyaś ca sanābhayaḥ //
column2: But when the mother has died, all the uterine brothers and the uterine sisters shall equally divide the mother's estate.

column1: yās tāsāṃ syur duhitaras tāsām api yathārhataḥ / mātāmahyā dhanāt kiṃ cit pradeyaṃ prītipūrvakam //
column2: Even to the daughters of those (daughters) something should be given, as is seemly, out of the estate of their maternal grandmother, on the score of affection.

column1: adhyagnyadhyāvāhanikaṃ dattaṃ ca prītikarmaṇi / bhrātṛmātṛpitṛprāptaṃ ṣaḍvidhaṃ strīdhanaṃ smṛtam //
column2: What (was given) before the (nuptial) fire, what (was given) on the bridal procession, what was given in token of love, and what was received from her brother, mother, or father, that is called the sixfold property of a woman.

column1: anvādheyaṃ ca yad dattaṃ patyā prītena caiva yat / patyau jīvati vṛttāyāḥ prajāyās tad dhanaṃ bhavet //
column2: (Such property), as well as a gift subsequent and what was given (to her) by her affectionate husband, shall go to her offspring, (even) if she dies in the lifetime of her husband.

column1: brāhmadaivārṣagāndharva- prājāpatyeṣu yad vasu / aprajāyām atītāyāṃ bhartur eva tad iṣyate //
column2: It is ordained that the property (of a woman married) according to the Brahma, the Daiva, the Arsha, the Gandharva, or the Pragapatya rite (shall belong) to her husband alone, if she dies without issue.

column1: yat tv asyāḥ syād dhanaṃ dattaṃ vivāheṣv āsurādiṣu / aprajāyām atītāyāṃ mātāpitros tad iṣyate //
column2: But it is prescribed that the property which may have been given to a (wife) on an Asura marriage or (one of the) other (blamable marriages, shall go) to her mother and to her father, if she dies without issue.

column1: striyāṃ tu yad bhaved vittaṃ pitrā dattaṃ kathaṃ cana / brāhmaṇī tad dharet kanyā tadapatyasya vā bhavet //
column2: Whatever property may have been given by her father to a wife (who has co-wives of different castes), that the daughter (of the) Brahmani (wife) shall take, or that (daughter's) issue.

column1: na nirhāraṃ striyaḥ kuryuḥ kuṭumbād bahumadhyagāt / svakād api ca vittād dhi svasya bhartur anājñayā //
column2: Women should never make a hoard from (the property of) their families which is common to many, nor from their own (husbands' particular) property without permission.

column1: patyau jīvati yaḥ strībhir alaṅkāro dhṛto bhavet / na taṃ bhajeran dāyādā bhajamānāḥ patanti te //
column2: The ornaments which may have been worn by women during their husbands' lifetime, his heirs shall not divide; those who divide them become outcasts.

column1: anaṃśau klībapatitau jātyandhabadhirau tathā / unmattajaḍamūkāś ca ye ca ke cin nirindriyāḥ //
column2: Eunuchs and outcasts, (persons) born blind or deaf, the insane, idiots and the dumb, as well as those deficient in any organ (of action or sensation), receive no share.

column1: sarveṣām api tu nyāyyaṃ dātuṃ śaktyā manīṣiṇā / grāsācchādanam atyantaṃ patito hy adadad bhavet //
column2: But it is just that (a man) who knows (the law) should give even to all of them food and raiment without stint, according to his ability; he who gives it not will become all outcast.

column1: yady arthitā tu dāraiḥ syāt klībādīnāṃ kathaṃ cana / teṣām utpannatantūnām apatyaṃ dāyam arhati // yat kiṃ cit pitari prete dhanaṃ jyeṣṭho 'dhigacchati / bhāgo yavīyasāṃ tatra yadi vidyānupālinaḥ //
column2: If the eunuch and the rest should somehow or other desire to (take) wives, the offspring of such among them as have children is worthy of a share. Whatever property the eldest (son) acquires (by his own exertion) after the father's death, a share of that (shall belong) to his younger (brothers), provided they have made a due progress in learning.

column1: avidyānāṃ tu sarveṣāṃ īhātaś ced dhanaṃ bhavet / samas tatra vibhāgaḥ syād apitrya iti dhāraṇā //
column2: But if all of them, being unlearned, acquire property by their labour, the division of that shall be equal, (as it is) not property acquired by the father; that is a settled rule.

column1: vidyādhanaṃ tu yady asya tat tasyaiva dhanaṃ bhavet / maitryam audvāhikaṃ caiva mādhuparkikam eva ca //
column2: Property (acquired) by learning belongs solely to him to whom (it was given), likewise the gift of a friend, a present received on marriage or with the honey-mixture.

column1: bhrātṝṇāṃ yas tu neheta dhanaṃ śaktaḥ svakarmaṇā / sa nirbhājyaḥ svakād aṃśāt kiṃ cid dattvopajīvanam // anupaghnan pitṛdravyaṃ śrameṇa yad upārjitam / svayam īhitalabdhaṃ tan nākāmo dātum arhati //
column2: But if one of the brothers, being able (to maintain himself) by his own occupation, does not desire (a share of the family) property, he may be made separate (by the others) receiving a trifle out of his share to live upon. What one (brother) may acquire by his labour without using the patrimony, that acquisition, (made solely) by his own effort, he shall not share unless by his own will (with his brothers).

column1: paitṛkaṃ tu pitā dravyam anavāptaṃ yad āpnuyāt / na tat putrair bhajet sārdham akāmaḥ svayam arjitam //
column2: But if a father recovers lost ancestral property, he shall not divide it, unless by his own will, with his sons, (for it is) self-acquired (property).

column1: vibhaktāḥ saha jīvanto vibhajeran punar yadi / samas tatra vibhāgaḥ syāj jyaiṣṭhyaṃ tatra na vidyate //
column2: If brothers, (once) divided and living (again) together (as coparceners), make a second partition, the division shall in that case be equal; in such a case there is no right of primogeniture.

column1: yeṣāṃ jyeṣṭhaḥ kaniṣṭho vā hīyetāṃśapradānataḥ / mriyetānyataro vāpi tasya bhāgo na lupyate //
column2: If the eldest or the youngest (brother) is deprived of his share, or if either of them dies, his share is not lost (to his immediate heirs).

column1: sodaryā vibhajeraṃs taṃ sametya sahitāḥ samam / bhrātaro ye ca saṃsṛṣṭā bhāginyaś ca sanābhayaḥ //
column2: His uterine brothers, having assembled together, shall equally divide it, and those brothers who were reunited (with him) and the uterine sisters.

column1: yo jyeṣṭho vinikurvīta lobhād bhrātṝn yavīyasaḥ / so 'jyeṣṭhaḥ syād abhāgaś ca niyantavyaś ca rājabhiḥ // sarva eva vikarmasthā nārhanti bhrātaro dhanam / na cādattvā kaniṣṭhebhyo jyeṣṭhaḥ kurvīta yautakam //
column2: An eldest brother who through avarice may defraud the younger ones, shall no (longer hold the position of) the eldest, shall not receive an (eldest son's additional) share, and shall be punished by the king. All brothers who habitually commit forbidden acts, are unworthy of (a share of) the property, and the eldest shall not make (anything his) separate property without giving (an equivalent) to his younger brothers.

column1: bhrātṝṇām avibhaktānāṃ yady utthānaṃ bhavet saha / na putrabhāgaṃ viṣamaṃ pitā dadyāt kathaṃ cana //
column2: If undivided brethren, (living with their father,) together make an exertion (for gain), the father shall on no account give to them unequal shares (on a division of the estate).

column1: ūrdhvaṃ vibhāgāj jātas tu pitryam eva hared dhanam / saṃsṛṣṭās tena vā ye syur vibhajeta sa taiḥ saha //
column2: But a son, born after partition, shall alone take the property of his father, or if any (of the other sons) be reunited with the (father), he shall share with them.

column1: anapatyasya putrasya mātā dāyam avāpnuyāt / mātary api ca vṛttāyāṃ pitur mātā hared dhanam //
column2: A mother shall obtain the inheritance of a son (who dies) without leaving issue, and, if the mother be dead, the paternal grandmother shall take the estate.

column1: ṛṇe dhane ca sarvasmin pravibhakte yathāvidhi / paścād dṛśyeta yat kiṃ cit tat sarvaṃ samatāṃ nayet //
column2: And if, after all the debts and assets have been duly distributed according to the rule, any (property) be afterwards discovered, one must divide it equally.

column1: vastraṃ patram alaṅkāraṃ kṛtānnam udakaṃ striyaḥ / yogakṣemaṃ pracāraṃ ca na vibhājyaṃ pracakṣate //
column2: A dress, a vehicle, ornaments, cooked food, water, and female (slaves), property destined for pious uses or sacrifices, and a pasture-ground, they declare to be indivisible.

column1: ayam ukto vibhāgo vaḥ putrāṇāṃ ca kriyāvidhiḥ / kramaśaḥ kṣetrajādīnāṃ dyūtadharmaṃ nibodhata //
column2: The division (of the property) and the rules for allotting (shares) to the (several) sons, those begotten on a wife and the rest, in (due) order, have been thus declared to you; hear (now) the laws concerning gambling.

column1: dyūtaṃ samāhvayaṃ caiva rājā rāṣṭrān nivārayet / rājāntakaraṇāv etau dvau doṣau pṛthivīkṣitām //
column2: Gambling and betting let the king exclude from his realm; those two vices cause the destruction of the kingdoms of princes.

column1: prakāśam etat tāskaryaṃ yad devanasamāhvayau / tayor nityaṃ pratīghāte nṛpatir yatnavān bhavet //
column2: Gambling and betting amount to open theft; the king shall always exert himself in suppressing both (of them).

column1: aprāṇibhir yat kriyate tal loke dyūtam ucyate / prāṇibhiḥ kriyate yas tu sa vijñeyaḥ samāhvayaḥ //
column2: When inanimate (things) are used (for staking money on them), that is called among men gambling (dyuta), when animate beings are used (for the same purpose), one must know that to be betting (samahvaya).

column1: dyūtaṃ samāhvayaṃ caiva yaḥ kuryāt kārayeta vā / tān sarvān ghātayed rājā śūdrāṃś ca dvijaliṅginaḥ //
column2: Let the king corporally punish all those (persons) who either gamble and bet or afford (an opportunity for it), likewise Sudras who assume the distinctive marks of twice-born (men).

column1: kitavān kuśīlavān krūrān pāṣaṇḍasthāṃś ca mānavān / vikarmasthān śauṇḍikāṃś ca kṣipraṃ nirvāsayet purāt //
column2: Gamblers, dancers and singers, cruel men, men belonging to an heretical sect, those following forbidden occupations, and sellers of spirituous liquor, let him instantly banish from his town.

column1: ete rāṣṭre vartamānā rājñaḥ prachannataskarāḥ / vikarmakriyayā nityaṃ bādhante bhadrikāḥ prajāḥ //
column2: If such (persons who are) secret thieves, dwell in the realm of a king, they constantly harass his good subjects by their forbidden practices.

column1: dyūtam etat purā kalpe dṛṣṭaṃ vairakaraṃ mahat / tasmād dyūtaṃ na seveta hāsyārtham api buddhimān //
column2: In a former Kalpa this (vice of) gambling has been seen to cause great enmity; a wise man, therefore, should not practise it even for amusement.

column1: pracchannaṃ vā prakāśaṃ vā tan niṣeveta yo naraḥ / tasya daṇḍavikalpaḥ syād yatheṣṭaṃ nṛpates tathā //
column2: On every man who addicts himself to that (vice) either secretly or openly, the king may inflict punishment according to his discretion.

column1: kṣatraviṭśūdrayonis tu daṇḍaṃ dātum aśaknuvan / ānṛṇyaṃ karmaṇā gacched vipro dadyāc chanaiḥ śanaiḥ //
column2: But a Kshatriya, a Vaisya, and a Sudra who are unable to pay a fine, shall discharge the debt by labour; a Brahmana shall pay it by installments.

column1: strībālonmattavṛddhānāṃ daridrāṇāṃ ca rogiṇām / śiphāvidalarajjvādyair vidadhyān nṛpatir damam //
column2: On women, infants, men of disordered mind, the poor and the sick, the king shall inflict punishment with a whip, a cane, or a rope and the like.

column1: ye niyuktās tu kāryeṣu hanyuḥ kāryāṇi kāryiṇām / dhanoṣmaṇā pacyamānās tān niḥsvān kārayen nṛpaḥ //
column2: But those appointed (to administer public) affairs, who, baked by the fire of wealth, mar the business of suitors, the king shall deprive of their property.

column1: kūṭaśāsanakartṝṃś ca prakṛtīnāṃ ca dūṣakān / strībālabrāhmaṇaghnāṃś ca hanyād dviṭsevinas tathā //
column2: Forgers of royal edicts, those who corrupt his ministers, those who slay women, infants, or Brahmanas, and those who serve his enemies, the king shall put to death.

column1: tīritaṃ cānuśiṣṭaṃ ca yatra kva cana yad bhavet / kṛtaṃ tad dharmato vidyān na tad bhūyo nivartayet //
column2: Whenever any (legal transaction) has been completed or (a punishment) been inflicted according to the law, he shall sanction it and not annul it.

column1: amātyāḥ prāḍvivāko vā yat kuryuḥ kāryam anyathā / tat svayaṃ nṛpatiḥ kuryāt tān sahasraṃ ca daṇḍayet //
column2: Whatever matter his ministers or the judge may settle improperly, that the king himself shall (re-) settle and fine (them) one thousand (panas).

column1: brahmahā ca surāpaś ca steyī ca gurutalpagaḥ / ete sarve pṛthag jñeyā mahāpātakino narāḥ //
column2: The slayer of a Brahmana, (A twice-born man) who drinks (the spirituous liquor called) Sura, he who steals (the gold of a Brahmana), and he who violates a Guru's bed, must each and all be considered as men who committed mortal sins (mahapataka).

column1: caturṇām api caiteṣāṃ prāyaścittam akurvatām / śārīraṃ dhanasaṃyuktaṃ daṇḍaṃ dharmyaṃ prakalpayet //
column2: On those four even, if they do not perform a penance, let him inflict corporal punishment and fines in accordance with the law.

column1: gurutalpe bhagaḥ kāryaḥ surāpāne surādhvajaḥ / steye ca śvapadaṃ kāryaṃ brahmahaṇy aśirāḥ pumān //
column2: For violating a Guru's bed, (the mark of) a female part shall be (impressed on the forehead with a hot iron); for drinking (the spirituous liquor called) Sura, the sign of a tavern; for stealing (the gold of a Brahmana), a dog's foot; for murdering a Brahmana, a headless corpse.

column1: asaṃbhojyā hy asaṃyājyā asaṃpāṭhyā 'vivāhinaḥ / careyuḥ pṛthivīṃ dīnāḥ sarvadharmabahiṣkṛtāḥ //
column2: Excluded from all fellowship at meals, excluded from all sacrifices, excluded from instruction and from matrimonial alliances, abject and excluded from all religious duties, let them wander over (this) earth.

column1: jñātisaṃbandhibhis tv ete tyaktavyāḥ kṛtalakṣaṇāḥ / nirdayā nirnamaskārās tan manor anuśāsanam //
column2: Such (persons) who have been branded with (indelible) marks must be cast off by their paternal and maternal relations, and receive neither compassion nor a salutation; that is the teaching of Manu.

column1: prāyaścittaṃ tu kurvāṇāḥ sarvavarṇā yathoditam / nāṅkyā rājñā lalāṭe syur dāpyās tūttamasāhasam //
column2: But (men of) all castes who perform the prescribed penances, must not be branded on the forehead by the king, but shall be made to pay the highest amercement.

column1: āgaḥsu brāhmaṇasyaiva kāryo madhyamasāhasaḥ / vivāsyo vā bhaved rāṣṭrāt sadravyaḥ saparicchadaḥ //
column2: For (such) offences the middlemost amercement shall be inflicted on a Brahmana, or he may be banished from the realm, keeping his money and his chattels.

column1: itare kṛtavantas tu pāpāny etāny akāmataḥ / sarvasvahāram arhanti kāmatas tu pravāsanam //
column2: But (men of) other (castes), who have unintentionally committed such crimes, ought to be deprived of their whole property; if (they committed them) intentionally, they shall be banished.

column1: nādadīta nṛpaḥ sādhur mahāpātakino dhanam / ādadānas tu tal lobhāt tena doṣeṇa lipyate //
column2: A virtuous king must not take for himself the property of a man guilty of mortal sin; but if he takes it out of greed, he is tainted by that guilt (of the offender).

column1: apsu praveśya taṃ daṇḍaṃ varuṇāyopapādayet / śrutavṛttopapanne vā brāhmaṇe pratipādayet //
column2: Having thrown such a fine into the water, let him offer it to Varuna, or let him bestow it on a learned and virtuous Brahmana.

column1: īśo daṇḍasya varuṇo rājñāṃ daṇḍadharo hi saḥ / īśaḥ sarvasya jagato brāhmaṇo vedapāragaḥ //
column2: Varuna is the lord of punishment, for he holds the sceptre even over kings; a Brahmana who has learnt the whole Veda is the lord of the whole world.

column1: yatra varjayate rājā pāpakṛdbhyo dhanāgamam / tatra kālena jāyante mānavā dīrghajīvinaḥ //
column2: In that (country), where the king avoids taking the property of (mortal) sinners, men are born in (due) time (and are) long-lived,

column1: niṣpadyante ca sasyāni yathoptāni viśāṃ pṛthak / bālāś ca na pramīyante vikṛtaṃ ca na jāyate //
column2: And the crops of the husbandmen spring up, each as it was sown, and the children die not, and no misshaped (offspring) is born.

column1: brāhmaṇān bādhamānaṃ tu kāmād avaravarṇajam / hanyāc citrair vadhopāyair udvejanakarair nṛpaḥ //
column2: But the king shall inflict on a base-born (Sudra), who intentionally gives pain to Brahmanas, various (kinds of) corporal punishment which cause terror.

column1: yāvān avadhyasya vadhe tāvān vadhyasya mokṣaṇe / adharmo nṛpater dṛṣṭo dharmas tu viniyacchataḥ //
column2: When a king punishes an innocent (man), his guilt is considered as great as when he sets free a guilty man; but (he acquires) merit when he punishes (justly).

column1: udito 'yaṃ vistaraśo mitho vivādamānayoḥ / aṣṭādaśasu mārgeṣu vyavahārasya nirṇayaḥ //
column2: Thus the (manner of) deciding suits (falling) under the eighteen titles, between two litigant parties, has been declared at length.

column1: evaṃ dharmyāṇi kāryāṇi samyak kurvan mahīpatiḥ / deśān alabdhāṃl lipseta labdhāṃś ca paripālayet //
column2: A king who thus duly fulfils his duties in accordance with justice, may seek to gain countries which he has not yet gained, and shall duly protect them when he has gained them.

column1: samyaṅ niviṣṭadeśas tu kṛtadurgaś ca śāstrataḥ / kaṇṭakoddharaṇe nityam ātiṣṭhed yatnam uttamam //
column2: Having duly settled his country, and having built forts in accordance with the Institutes, he shall use his utmost exertions to remove (those men who are nocuous like) thorns.

column1: rakṣanād āryavṛttānāṃ kaṇṭakānāṃ ca śodhanāt / narendrās tridivaṃ yānti prajāpālanatatparāḥ //
column2: By protecting those who live as (becomes) Aryans and by removing the thorns, kings, solely intent on guarding their subjects, reach heaven.

column1: aśāsaṃs taskarān yas tu baliṃ gṛhṇāti pārthivaḥ / tasya prakṣubhyate rāṣṭraṃ svargāc ca parihīyate //
column2: The realm of that king who takes his share in kind, though he does not punish thieves, (will be) disturbed and he (will) lose heaven.

column1: nirbhayaṃ tu bhaved yasya rāṣṭraṃ bāhubalāśritam / tasya tad vardhate nityaṃ sicyamāna iva drumaḥ //
column2: But if his kingdom be secure, protected by the strength of his arm, it will constantly flourish like a (well)- watered tree.

column1: dvividhāṃs taskarān vidyāt paradravyāpahārakān / prakāśāṃś cāprakāśāṃś ca cāracakṣur mahīpatiḥ //
column2: Let the king who sees (everything) through his spies, discover the two sorts of thieves who deprive others of their property, both those who (show themselves) openly and those who (lie) concealed.

column1: prakāśavañcakās teṣāṃ nānāpaṇyopajīvinaḥ / pracchannavañcakās tv ete ye stenāṭavikādayaḥ //
column2: Among them, the open rogues (are those) who subsist by (cheating in the sale of) various marketable commodities, but the concealed rogues are burglars, robbers in forests, and so forth.

column1: utkocakāś cāupadhikā vañcakāḥ kitavās tathā / maṅgalādeśavṛttāś ca bhadrāś cekṣaṇikaiḥ saha // asamyakkāriṇaś caiva mahāmātrāś cikitsakāḥ / śilpopacārayuktāś ca nipuṇāḥ paṇyayoṣitaḥ //
column2: Those who take bribes, cheats and rogues, gamblers, those who live by teaching (the performance of) auspicious ceremonies, sanctimonious hypocrites, and fortune-tellers, Officials of high rank and physicians who act improperly, men living by showing their proficiency in arts, and clever harlots,

column1: evamādīn vijānīyāt prakāśāṃl lokakaṇṭakān / nigūḍhacāriṇaś cānyān anāryān āryaliṅginaḥ //
column2: These and the like who show themselves openly, as well as others who walk in disguise (such as) non-Aryans who wear the marks of Aryans, he should know to be thorns (in the side of his people).

column1: tān viditvā sucaritair gūḍhais tatkarmakāribhiḥ / cāraiś cānekasaṃsthānaiḥ protsādya vaśam ānayet // teṣāṃ doṣān abhikhyāpya sve sve karmaṇi tattvataḥ / kurvīta śāsanaṃ rājā samyak sārāparādhataḥ //
column2: Having detected them by means of trustworthy persons, who, disguising themselves, (pretend) to follow the same occupations and by means of spies, wearing various disguises, he must cause them to be instigated (to commit offences), and bring them into his power. Then having caused the crimes, which they committed by their several actions, to be proclaimed in accordance with the facts, the king shall duly punish them according to their strength and their crimes.

column1: na hi daṇḍād ṛte śakyaḥ kartuṃ pāpavinigrahaḥ / stenānāṃ pāpabuddhīnāṃ nibhṛtaṃ caratāṃ kṣitau //
column2: For the wickedness of evil-minded thieves, who secretly prowl over this earth, cannot be restrained except by punishment.

column1: sabhāprapāpūpaśālā- veśamadyānnavikrayāḥ / catuṣpathāṃś caityavṛkṣāḥ samājāḥ prekṣaṇāni ca //
column2: Assembly-houses, houses where water is distributed or cakes are sold, brothels, taverns and victualler's shops, cross-roads, well-known trees, festive assemblies, and play-houses and concert-rooms,

column1: jīrṇodyānāny araṇyāni kārukāveśanāni ca / śūnyāni cāpy agārāṇi vanāny upavanāni ca //
column2: Old gardens, forests, the shops of artisans, empty dwellings, natural and artificial groves,

column1: evaṃvidhān nṛpo deśān gulmaiḥ sthāvarajaṅgamaiḥ / taskarapratiṣedhārthaṃ cāraiś cāpy anucārayet //
column2: These and the like places the king shall cause to be guarded by companies of soldiers, both stationary and patrolling, and by spies, in order to keep away thieves.

column1: tatsahāyair anugatair nānākarmapravedibhiḥ / vidyād utsādayec caiva nipuṇaiḥ pūrvataskaraiḥ //
column2: By the means of clever reformed thieves, who associate with such (rogues), follow them and know their various machinations, he must detect and destroy them.

column1: bhakṣyabhojyopadeśaiś ca brāhmaṇānāṃ ca darśanaiḥ / śauryakarmāpadeśaiś ca kuryus teṣāṃ samāgamam //
column2: Under the pretext of (offering them) various dainties, of introducing them to Brahmanas, and on the pretence of (showing them) feats of strength, the (spies) must make them meet (the officers of justice).

column1: ye tatra nopasarpeyur mūlapraṇihitāś ca ye / tān prasahya nṛpo hanyāt samitrajñātibāndhavān //
column2: Those among them who do not come, and those who suspect the old (thieves employed by the king), the king shall attack by force and slay together with their friends, blood relations, and connexions.

column1: na hoḍhena vinā cauraṃ ghātayed dhārmiko nṛpaḥ / sahoḍhaṃ sopakaraṇaṃ ghātayed avicārayan //
column2: A just king shall not cause a thief to be put to death, (unless taken) with the stolen goods (in his possession); him who (is taken) with the stolen goods and the implements (of burglary), he may, without hesitation, cause to be slain.

column1: grāmeṣv api ca ye ke cic caurāṇāṃ bhaktadāyakāḥ / bhāṇḍāvakāśadāś caiva sarvāṃs tān api ghātayet //
column2: All those also who in villages give food to thieves or grant them room for (concealing their implements), he shall cause to be put to death.

column1: rāṣṭreṣu rakṣādhikṛtān sāmantāṃś caiva coditān / abhyāghāteṣu madhyasthāñ śiṣyāc caurān iva drutam //
column2: Those who are appointed to guard provinces and his vassals who have been ordered (to help), he shall speedily punish like thieves, (if they remain) inactive in attacks (by robbers).

column1: yaś cāpi dharmasamayāt pracyuto dharmajīvanaḥ / daṇḍenaiva tam apy oṣet svakād dharmād dhi vicyutam //
column2: Moreover if (a man), who subsists by (the fulfilment of) the law, departs from the established rule of the law, the (king) shall severely punish him by a fine, (because he) violated his duty.

column1: grāmaghāte hitābhaṅge pathi moṣābhidarśane / śaktito nābhidhāvanto nirvāsyāḥ saparicchadāḥ //
column2: Those who do not give assistance according to their ability when a village is being plundered, a dyke is being destroyed, or a highway robbery committed, shall be banished with their goods and chattels.

column1: rājñaḥ kośāpahartṝṃś ca pratikūleṣu ca sthitān / ghātayed vividhair daṇḍair arīṇāṃ copajāpakān // saṃdhiṃ chittvā tu ye cauryaṃ rātrau kurvanti taskarāḥ / teṣāṃ chittvā nṛpo hastau tīkṣṇe śūle niveśayet //
column2: On those who rob the king's treasury and those who persevere in opposing (his commands), he shall inflict various kinds of capital punishment, likewise on those who conspire with his enemies. But the king shall cut off the hands of those robbers who, breaking into houses, commit thefts at night, and cause them to be impaled on a pointed stake.

column1: aṅgulīr granthibhedasya chedayet prathame grahe / dvitīye hastacaraṇau tṛtīye vadham arhati //
column2: On the first conviction, let him cause two fingers of a cut-purse to be amputated; on the second, one hand and one foot; on the third, he shall suffer death.

column1: agnidān bhaktadāṃś caiva tathā śastrāvakāśadān / saṃnidhātṝṃś ca moṣasya hanyāc cauram iveśvaraḥ //
column2: Those who give (to thieves) fire, food, arms, or shelter, and receivers of stolen goods, the ruler shall punish like thieves.

column1: taḍāgabhedakaṃ hanyād apsu śuddhavadhena vā / yad vāpi pratisaṃskuryād dāpyas tūttamasāhasam //
column2: Him who breaks (the dam of) a tank he shall slay (by drowning him) in water or by (some other) (mode of) capital punishment; or the offender may repair the (damage), but shall be made to pay the highest amercement.

column1: koṣṭhāgārāyudhāgāra- devatāgārabhedakān / hastyaśvarathahartṝṃś ca hanyād evāvicārayan //
column2: Those who break into a (royal) storehouse, an armoury, or a temple, and those who steal elephants, horses, or chariots, he shall slay without hesitation.

column1: yas tu pūrvaniviṣṭasya taḍāgasyodakaṃ haret / āgamaṃ vāpy apāṃ bhindyāt sa dāpyaḥ pūrvasāhasam //
column2: But he who shall take away the water of a tank, made in ancient times, or shall cut off the supply of water, must be made to pay the first (or lowest) amercement.

column1: samutsṛjed rājamārge yas tv amedhyam anāpadi / sa dvau kārṣāpaṇau dadyād amedhyaṃ cāśu śodhayet //
column2: But he who, except in a case of extreme necessity, drops filth on the king's high-road, shall pay two karshapanas and immediately remove (that) filth.

column1: āpadgato 'tha vā vṛddhā garbhiṇī bāla eva vā / paribhāṣaṇam arhanti tac ca śodhyam iti sthitiḥ //
column2: But a person in urgent necessity, an aged man, a pregnant woman, or a child, shall be reprimanded and clean the (place); that is a settled rule.

column1: cikitsakānāṃ sarveṣāṃ mithyāpracaratāṃ damaḥ / amānuṣeṣu prathamo mānuṣeṣu tu madhyamaḥ //
column2: All physicians who treat (their patients) wrongly (shall pay) a fine; in the case of animals, the first (or lowest); in the case of human beings, the middlemost (amercement).

column1: saṃkramadhvajayaṣṭīnāṃ pratimānāṃ ca bhedakaḥ / pratikuryāc ca tat sarvaṃ pañca dadyāc chatāni ca //
column2: He who destroys a bridge, the flag (of a temple or royal palace), a pole, or images, shall repair the whole (damage) and pay five hundred (panas).

column1: adūṣitānāṃ dravyāṇāṃ dūṣaṇe bhedane tathā / maṇīnām apavedhe ca daṇḍaḥ prathamasāhasaḥ //
column2: For adulterating unadulterated commodities, and for breaking gems or for improperly boring (them), the fine is the first (or lowest) amercement.

column1: samair hi viṣamaṃ yas tu cared vai mūlyato 'pi vā / samāpnuyād damaṃ pūrvaṃ naro madhyamam eva vā //
column2: But that man who behaves dishonestly to honest (customers) or cheats in his prices, shall be fined in the first or in the middlemost amercement.

column1: bandhanāni ca sarvāṇi rājā mārge niveśayet / duḥkhitā yatra dṛśyeran vikṛtāḥ pāpakāriṇah //
column2: Let him place all prisons near a high-road, where the suffering and disfigured offenders can be seen.

column1: prākārasya ca bhettāraṃ parikhāṇāṃ ca pūrakam / dvārāṇāṃ caiva bhaṅktāraṃ kṣipram eva pravāsayet // abhicāreṣu sarveṣu kartavyo dviśato damaḥ / mūlakarmaṇi cānāpteḥ kṛtyāsu vividhāsu ca // abījavikrayī caiva bījotkṛṣṭā tathaiva ca / maryādābhedakaś caiva vikṛtaṃ prāpnuyād vadham //
column2: Him who destroys the wall (of a town), or fills up the ditch (round a town), or breaks a (town)- gate, he shall instantly banish. For all incantations intended to destroy life, for magic rites with roots (practised by persons) not related (to him against whom they are directed), and for various kinds of sorcery, a fine of two hundred (panas) shall be inflicted. He who sells (for seed-corn that which is) not seed-corn, he who takes up seed (already sown), and he who destroys a boundary (-mark), shall be punished by mutilation.

column1: sarvakaṇṭakapāpiṣṭhaṃ hemakāraṃ tu pārthivaḥ / pravartamānam anyāye chedayel lavaśaḥ kṣuraiḥ //
column2: But the king shall cause a goldsmith who behaves dishonestly, the most nocuous of all the thorns, to be cut to pieces with razors.

column1: sītādravyāpaharaṇe śastrāṇām auṣadhasya ca / kālam āsādya kāryaṃ ca rājā daṇḍaṃ prakalpayet //
column2: For the theft of agricultural implements, of arms and of medicines, let the king award punishment, taking into account the time (of the offence) and the use (of the object).

column1: svāmyamātyau puraṃ rāṣṭraṃ kośadaṇḍau suhṛt tathā / sapta prakṛtayo hy etāḥ saptāṅgaṃ rājyam ucyate //
column2: The king and his minister, his capital, his realm, his treasury, his army, and his ally are the seven constituent parts (of a kingdom); (hence) a kingdom is said to have seven limbs (anga).

column1: saptānāṃ prakṛtīnāṃ tu rājyasyāsāṃ yathākramam / pūrvaṃ pūrvaṃ gurutaraṃ jānīyād vyasanaṃ mahat //
column2: But let him know (that) among these seven constituent parts of a kingdom (which have been enumerated) in due order, each earlier (named) is more important and (its destruction) the greater calamity.

column1: saptāṅgasyeha rājyasya viṣṭabdhasya tridaṇḍavat / anyonyaguṇavaiśeṣyān na kiṃ cid atiricyate //
column2: Yet in a kingdom containing seven constituent parts, which is upheld like the triple staff (of an ascetic), there is no (single part) more important (than the others), by reason of the importance of the qualities of each for the others.

column1: teṣu teṣu tu kṛtyeṣu tat tad aṅgaṃ viśiṣyate / yena yat sādhyate kāryaṃ tat tasmiñ śreṣṭham ucyate //
column2: For each part is particularly qualified for (the accomplishment of) certain objects, (and thus) each is declared to be the most important for that particular purpose which is effected by its means.

column1: cāreṇotsāhayogena kriyayaiva ca karmaṇām / svaśaktiṃ paraśaktiṃ ca nityaṃ vidyān mahīpatiḥ //
column2: By spies, by a (pretended) display of energy, and by carrying out (various) undertakings, let the king constantly ascertain his own and his enemy's strength;

column1: pīḍanāni ca sarvāṇi vyasanāni tathaiva ca / ārabheta tataḥ kāryaṃ saṃcintya gurulāghavam //
column2: Moreover, all calamities and vices; afterwards, when he has fully considered their relative importance, let him begin his operations.

column1: ārabhetaiva karmāṇi śrāntaḥ śrāntaḥ punaḥ punaḥ / karmāṇy ārabhamāṇaṃ hi puruṣaṃ śrīr niṣevate //
column2: (Though he be) ever so much tired (by repeated failures), let him begin his operations again and again; for fortune greatly favours the man who (strenuously) exerts himself in his undertakings.

column1: kṛtaṃ tretāyugaṃ caiva dvāparaṃ kalir eva ca / rājño vṛttāni sarvāṇi rājā hi yugam ucyate //
column2: The various ways in which a king behaves (resemble) the Krita, Treta, Dvapara, and Kali ages; hence the king is identified with the ages (of the world).

column1: kaliḥ prasupto bhavati sa jāgrad dvāparaṃ yugam / karmasv abhyudyatas tretā vicaraṃs tu kṛtaṃ yugam //
column2: Sleeping he represents the Kali (or iron age), waking the Dvapara (or brazen) age, ready to act the Treta (or silver age), but moving (actively) the Krita (or golden) age.

column1: indrasyārkasya vāyoś ca yamasya varuṇasya ca / candrasyāgneḥ pṛthivyāś ca tejovṛttaṃ nṛpaś caret //
column2: Let the king emulate the energetic action of Indra, of the Sun, of the Wind, of Yama, of Varuna, of the Moon, of the Fire, and of the Earth.

column1: vārṣikāṃś caturo māsān yathendro 'bhipravarṣati / tathābhivarṣet svaṃ rāṣṭraṃ kāmair indravrataṃ caran //
column2: As Indra sends copious rain during the four months of the rainy season, even so let the king, taking upon himself the office of Indra, shower benefits on his kingdom.

column1: aṣṭau māsān yathādityas toyaṃ harati raśmibhiḥ / tathā haret karaṃ rāṣṭrān nityam arkavrataṃ hi tat //
column2: As the Sun during eight months (imperceptibly) draws up the water with his rays, even so let him gradually draw his taxes from his kingdom; for that is the office in which he resembles the Sun.

column1: praviśya sarvabhūtāni yathā carati mārutaḥ / tathā cāraiḥ praveṣṭavyaṃ vratam etad dhi mārutam //
column2: As the Wind moves (everywhere), entering (in the shape of the vital air) all created beings, even so let him penetrate (everywhere) through his spies; that is the office in which he resembles the Wind.

column1: yathā yamaḥ priyadveṣyau prāpte kāle niyacchati / tathā rājñā niyantavyāḥ prajās tad dhi yamavratam //
column2: As Yama at the appointed time subjects to his rule both friends and foes, even so all subjects must be controlled by the king; that is the office in which he resembles Yama.

column1: varuṇena yathā pāśair baddha evābhidṛśyate / tathā pāpān nigṛhṇīyād vratam etad dhi vāruṇam //
column2: As (a sinner) is seen bound with ropes by Varuna, even so let him punish the wicked; that is his office in which he resembles Varuna.

column1: paripūrṇaṃ yathā candraṃ dṛṣṭvā hṛṣyanti mānavāḥ / tathā prakṛtayo yasmin sa cāndravratiko nṛpaḥ //
column2: He is a king, taking upon himself the office of the Moon, whose (appearance) his subjects (greet with as great joy) as men feel on seeing the full moon.

column1: pratāpayuktas tejasvī nityaṃ syāt pāpakarmasu / duṣṭasāmantahiṃsraś ca tad āgneyaṃ vrataṃ smṛtam //
column2: (If) he is ardent in wrath against criminals and endowed with brilliant energy, and destroys wicked vassals, then his character is said (to resemble) that of Fire.

column1: yathā sarvāṇi bhūtāni dharā dhārayate samam / tathā sarvāṇi bhūtāni bibhrataḥ pārthivaṃ vratam //
column2: As the Earth supports all created beings equally, thus (a king) who supports all his subjects, (takes upon himself) the office of the Earth.

column1: etair upāyair anyaiś ca yukto nityam atandritaḥ / stenān rājā nigṛhṇīyāt svarāṣṭre para eva ca //
column2: Employing these and other means, the king shall, ever untired, restrain thieves both in his own dominions and in (those of) others.

column1: parām apy āpadaṃ prāpto brāhmaṇān na prakopayet / te hy enaṃ kupitā hanyuḥ sadyaḥ sabalavāhanam //
column2: Let him not, though fallen into the deepest distress, provoke Brahmanas to anger; for they, when angered, could instantly destroy him together with his army and his vehicles.

column1: yaiḥ kṛtaḥ sarvabhakṣyo 'gnir apeyaś ca mahodadhiḥ / kṣayī cāpyāyitaḥ somaḥ ko na naśyet prakopya tān //
column2: Who could escape destruction, when he provokes to anger those (men), by whom the fire was made to consume all things, by whom the (water of the) ocean was made undrinkable, and by whom the moon was made to wane and to increase again?

column1: lokān anyān sṛjeyur ye lokapālāṃś ca kopitāḥ / devān kuryur adevāṃś ca kaḥ kṣiṇvaṃs tān samṛdhnuyāt //
column2: Who could prosper, while he injures those (men) who provoked to anger, could create other worlds and other guardians of the world, and deprive the gods of their divine station?

column1: yān upāśritya tiṣṭhanti lokā devāś ca sarvadā / brahma caiva dhanaṃ yeṣāṃ ko hiṃsyāt tāñ jijīviṣuḥ //
column2: What man, desirous of life, would injure them to whose support the (three) worlds and the gods ever owe their existence, and whose wealth is the Veda?

column1: avidvāṃś caiva vidvāṃś ca brāhmaṇo daivataṃ mahat / praṇītaś cāpraṇītaś ca yathāgnir daivataṃ mahat //
column2: A Brahmana, be he ignorant or learned, is a great divinity, just as the fire, whether carried forth (for the performance of a burnt-oblation) or not carried forth, is a great divinity.

column1: śmaśāneṣv api tejasvī pāvako naiva duṣyati / hūyamānaś ca yajñeṣu bhūya evābhivardhate //
column2: The brilliant fire is not contaminated even in burial-places, and, when presented with oblations (of butter) at sacrifices, it again increases mightily.

column1: evaṃ yady apy aniṣṭeṣu vartante sarvakarmasu / sarvathā brāhmaṇāḥ pūjyāḥ paramaṃ daivataṃ hi tat //
column2: Thus, though Brahmanas employ themselves in all (sorts of) mean occupations, they must be honoured in every way; for (each of) them is a very great deity.

column1: kṣatrasyātipravṛddhasya brāhmaṇān prati sarvaśaḥ / brahmaiva saṃniyantṛ syāt kṣatraṃ hi brahmasaṃbhavam //
column2: When the Kshatriyas become in any way overbearing towards the Brahmanas, the Brahmanas themselves shall duly restrain them; for the Kshatriyas sprang from the Brahmanas.

column1: adbhyo 'gnir brahmataḥ kṣatram aśmano loham utthitam / teṣāṃ sarvatragaṃ tejaḥ svāsu yoniṣu śāmyati //
column2: Fire sprang from water, Kshatriyas from Brahmanas, iron from stone; the all-penetrating force of those (three) has no effect on that whence they were produced.

column1: nābrahma kṣatram ṛdhnoti nākṣatraṃ brahma vardhate / brahma kṣatraṃ ca saṃpṛktam iha cāmutra vardhate //
column2: Kshatriyas prosper not without Brahmanas, Brahmanas prosper not without Kshatriyas; Brahmanas and Kshatriyas, being closely united, prosper in this (world) and in the next.

column1: dattvā dhanaṃ tu viprebhyaḥ sarvadaṇḍasamutthitam / putre rājyaṃ samāsṛjya kurvīta prāyaṇaṃ raṇe //
column2: But (a king who feels his end drawing nigh) shall bestow all his wealth, accumulated from fines, on Brahmanas, make over his kingdom to his son, and then seek death in battle.

column1: evaṃ caran sadā yukto rājadharmeṣu pārthivaḥ / hiteṣu caiva lokasya sarvān bhṛtyān niyojayet //
column2: Thus conducting himself (and) ever intent on (discharging) his royal duties, a king shall order all his servants (to work) for the good of his people.

column1: eṣo 'khilaḥ karmavidhir ukto rājñaḥ sanātanaḥ / imaṃ karmavidhiṃ vidyāt kramaśo vaiśyaśūdrayoḥ //
column2: Thus the eternal law concerning the duties of a king has been fully declared; know that the following rules apply in (due) order to the duties of Vaisyas and Sudras.

column1: vaiśyas tu kṛtasaṃskāraḥ kṛtvā dāraparigraham / vārtāyāṃ nityayuktaḥ syāt paśūnāṃ caiva rakṣaṇe //
column2: After a Vaisya has received the sacraments and has taken a wife, he shall be always attentive to the business whereby he may subsist and to (that of) tending cattle.

column1: prajāpatir hi vaiśyāya sṛṣṭvā paridade paśūn / brāhmaṇāya ca rājñe ca sarvāḥ paridade prajāḥ //
column2: For when the Lord of creatures (Pragapati) created cattle, he made them over to the Vaisya; to the Brahmana, and to the king he entrusted all created beings.

column1: na ca vaiśyasya kāmaḥ syān na rakṣeyaṃ paśūn iti / vaiśye cecchati nānyena rakṣitavyāḥ kathaṃ cana //
column2: A Vaisya must never (conceive this) wish, I will not keep cattle; and if a Vaisya is willing (to keep them), they must never be kept by (men of) other (castes).

column1: maṇimuktāpravālānāṃ lohānāṃ tāntavasya ca / gandhānāṃ ca rasānāṃ ca vidyād arghabalābalam //
column2: (A Vaisya) must know the respective value of gems, of pearls, of coral, of metals, of (cloth) made of thread, of perfumes, and of condiments.

column1: bījānām uptivic ca syāt kṣetradoṣaguṇasya ca / mānayogaṃ ca jānīyāt tulāyogāṃś ca sarvaśaḥ //
column2: He must be acquainted with the (manner of) sowing of seeds, and of the good and bad qualities of fields, and he must perfectly know all measures and weights.

column1: sārāsāraṃ ca bhāṇḍānāṃ deśānāṃ ca guṇāguṇān / lābhālābhaṃ ca paṇyānāṃ paśūnāṃ parivardhanam // bhṛtyānāṃ ca bhṛtiṃ vidyād bhāṣāś ca vividhā nṛṇāṃ / dravyāṇāṃ sthānayogāṃś ca krayavikrayam eva ca //
column2: Moreover, the excellence and defects of commodities, the advantages and disadvantages of (different) countries, the (probable) profit and loss on merchandise, and the means of properly rearing cattle. He must be acquainted with the (proper), wages of servants, with the various languages of men, with the manner of keeping goods, and (the rules of) purchase and sale.

column1: dharmeṇa ca dravyavṛddhāv ātiṣṭhed yatnam uttamam / dadyāc ca sarvabhūtānām annam eva prayatnataḥ //
column2: Let him exert himself to the utmost in order to increase his property in a righteous manner, and let him zealously give food to all created beings.

column1: viprāṇāṃ vedaviduṣāṃ gṛhasthānāṃ yaśasvinām / śuśrūṣaiva tu śūdrasya dharmo naiśreyasaḥ paraḥ //
column2: But to serve Brahmanas (who are) learned in the Vedas, householders, and famous (for virtue) is the highest duty of a Sudra, which leads to beatitude.

column1: śucir utkṛṣṭaśuśrūṣur mṛduvāg anahaṃkṛtaḥ / brāhmaṇādyāśrayo nityam utkṛṣṭāṃ jātim aśnute //
column2: (A Sudra who is) pure, the servant of his betters, gentle in his speech, and free from pride, and always seeks a refuge with Brahmanas, attains (in his next life) a higher caste.

column1: eṣo 'nāpadi varṇānām uktaḥ karmavidhiḥ śubhaḥ / āpady api hi yas teṣāṃ kramaśas tan nibodhata //
column2: The excellent law for the conduct of the (four) castes (varna), (when they are) not in distress, has been thus promulgated; now hear in order their (several duties) in times of distress.

column1: adhīyīraṃs trayo varṇāḥ svakarmasthā dvijātayaḥ / prabrūyād brāhmaṇas tv eṣāṃ netarāv iti niścayaḥ //
column2: Let the three twice-born castes (varna), discharging their (prescribed) duties, study (the Veda); but among them the Brahmana (alone) shall teach it, not the other two; that is an established rule.

column1: sarveṣāṃ brāhmaṇo vidyād vṛttyupāyān yathāvidhi / prabrūyād itarebhyaś ca svayaṃ caiva tathā bhavet //
column2: The Brahmana must know the means of subsistence (prescribed) by law for all, instruct the others, and himself live according to (the law)

column1: vaiśeṣyāt prakṛtiśraiṣṭhyān niyamasya ca dhāraṇāt / saṃskārasya viśeṣāc ca varṇānāṃ brāhmaṇaḥ prabhuḥ //
column2: On account of his pre-eminence, on account of the superiority of his origin, on account of his observance of (particular) restrictive rules, and on account of his particular sanctification the Brahmana is the lord of (all) castes (varna).

column1: brāhmaṇaḥ kṣatriyo vaiśyas trayo varṇā dvijātayaḥ / caturtha ekajātis tu śūdro nāsti tu pañcamaḥ //
column2: Brahmana, the Kshatriya, and the Vaisya castes (varna) are the twice-born ones, but the fourth, the Sudra, has one birth only; there is no fifth (caste).

column1: sarvavarṇeṣu tulyāsu patnīṣv akṣatayoniṣu / ānulomyena saṃbhūtā jātyā jñeyās ta eva te //
column2: In all castes (varna) those (children) only which are begotten in the direct order on wedded wives, equal (in caste and married as) virgins, are to be considered as belonging to the same caste (as their fathers)

column1: strīṣv anantarajātāsu dvijair utpāditān sutān / sadṛśān eva tān āhur mātṛdoṣavigarhitān //
column2: Sons, begotten by twice-born man on wives of the next lower castes, they declare to be similar (to their fathers, but) blamed on account of the fault (inherent) in their mothers.

column1: anantarāsu jātānāṃ vidhir eṣa sanātanaḥ / dvyekāntarāsu jātānāṃ dharmyaṃ vidyād imaṃ vidhim //
column2: Such is the eternal law concerning (children) born of wives one degree lower (than their husbands); know (that) the following rule (is applicable) to those born of women two or three degrees lower.

column1: brāhmaṇād vaiśyakanyāyām ambaṣṭho nāma jāyate / niṣādaḥ śūdrakanyāyāṃ yaḥ pāraśava ucyate //
column2: From a Brahmana a with the daughter of a Vaisya is born (a son) called an Ambashtha, with the daughter of a sudra a Nishada, who is also called Parasava.

column1: kṣatriyāc chūdrakanyāyāṃ krūrācāravihāravān / kṣatraśūdravapur jantur ugro nāma prajāyate //
column2: From a Kshatriya and the daughter of a Sudra springs a being, called Ugra, resembling both a Kshatriya and a Sudra, ferocious in his manners, and delighting in cruelty.

column1: viprasya triṣu varṇeṣu nṛpater varṇayor dvayoḥ / vaiśyasya varṇe caikasmin ṣaḍ ete 'pasadāḥ smṛtāḥ //
column2: Children of a Brahmana by (women of) the three (lower) castes, of a Kshatriya by (wives of) the two (lower) castes, and of a Vaisya by (a wife of) the one caste (below him) are all six called base-born (apasada).

column1: kṣatriyād viprakanyāyāṃ sūto bhavati jātitaḥ / vaiśyān māgadhavaidehau rājaviprāṅganāsutau //
column2: From a Kshatriya by the daughter of a Brahmana is born (a son called) according to his caste (gati) a Suta; from a Vaisya by females of the royal and the Brahmana (castes) spring a Magadha and a Vaideha.

column1: śūdrād āyogavaḥ kṣattā caṇḍālaś cādhamo nṛṇām / vaiśyarājanyaviprāsu jāyante varṇasaṃkarāḥ //
column2: From a Sudra are born an Ayogava, a Kshattri, and a Kandala, the lowest of men, by Vaisya, Kshatriya, and Brahmana) females, (sons who owe their origin to) a confusion of the castes.

column1: ekāntare tv ānulomyād ambaṣṭhograu yathā smṛtau / kṣattṛvaidehakau tadvat prātilomye 'pi janmani //
column2: As an Ambashtha and an Ugra, (begotten) in the direct order on (women) one degree lower (than their husbands) are declared (to be), even so are a Kshattri and a Vaidehaka, though they were born in the inverse order of the castes (from mothers one degree higher than the fathers).

column1: putrā ye 'nantarastrījāḥ krameṇoktā dvijanmanām / tān anantaranāmnas tu mātṛdoṣāt pracakṣate //
column2: Those sons of the twice-born, begotten on wives of the next lower castes, who have been enumerated in due order, they call by the name Anantaras (belonging to the next lower caste), on account of the blemish (inherent) in their mothers.

column1: brāhmaṇād ugrakanyāyām āvṛto nāma jāyate / ābhīro 'mbaṣṭhakanyāyām āyogavyāṃ tu dhigvaṇaḥ //
column2: A Brahmana begets on the daughter of an Ugra an Avrita, on the daughter of an Ambashtha an Abhira, but on a female of the Ayogava (caste) a Dhigvana.

column1: āyogavaś ca kṣattā ca caṇḍālaś cādhamo nṛṇām / prātilomyena jāyante śūdrād apasadās trayaḥ //
column2: From a Sudra spring in the inverse order (by females of the higher castes) three base-born (sons, apasada), an Ayogava, a Kshattri, and a Kandala, the lowest of men;

column1: vaiśyān māgadhavaidehau kṣatriyāt sūta eva tu / pratīpam ete jāyante pare 'py apasadās trayaḥ //
column2: From a Vaisya are born in the inverse order of the castes a Magadha and a Vaideha, but from a Kshatriya a Suta only; these are three other base-born ones (apasada).

column1: jāto niṣādāc chūdrāyāṃ jātyā bhavati pukkasaḥ / śūdrāj jāto niṣādyāṃ tu sa vai kukkuṭakaḥ smṛtaḥ //
column2: The son of a Nishada by a Sudra female becomes a Pukkasa by caste (gati), but the son of a Sudra by a Nishada female is declared to be a Kukkutaka.

column1: kṣattur jātas tathogrāyāṃ śvapāka iti kīrtyate / vaidehakena tv ambaṣṭhyām utpanno veṇa ucyate //
column2: Moreover, the son of by Kshattri by an Ugra female is called a Svapaka; but one begotten by a Vaidehaka on an Ambashtha female is named a Vena.

column1: dvijātayaḥ savarṇāsu janayanty avratāṃs tu yān / tān sāvitrīparibhraṣṭān vrātyān iti vinirdiśet //
column2: Those (sons) whom the twice-born beget on wives of equal caste, but who, not fulfilling their sacred duties, are excluded from the Savitri, one must designate by the appellation Vratyas.

column1: vrātyāt tu jāyate viprāt pāpātmā bhūrjakaṇṭakaḥ / āvantyavāṭadhānau ca puṣpadhaḥ śaikha eva ca //
column2: But from a Vratya (of the) Brahmana (caste) spring the wicked Bhriggakantaka, the Avantya, the Vatadhana, the Pushpadha, and the Saikha.

column1: jhallo mallaś ca rājanyād vrātyān nicchivir eva ca / naṭaś ca karaṇaś caiva khaso draviḍa eva ca //
column2: From a Vratya (of the) Kshatriya (caste), the Ghalla, the Malla, the Likkhivi, the Nata, the Karana, the Khasa, and the Dravida.
