column1: vaiśyāt tu jāyate vrātyāt sudhanvācārya eva ca / kāruṣaś ca vijanmā ca maitraḥ sātvata eva ca //
column2: From a Vratya (of the) Vaisya (caste) are born a Sudhanvan, an Akarya, a Karusha, a Viganman, a Maitra, and a Satvata.

column1: vyabhicāreṇa varṇānām avedyāvedanena ca / svakarmaṇāṃ ca tyāgena jāyante varṇasaṃkarāḥ //
column2: By adultery (committed by persons) of (different) castes, by marriages with women who ought not to be married, and by the neglect of the duties and occupations (prescribed) to each, are produced (sons who owe their origin) to a confusion the castes.

column1: saṃkīrṇayonayo ye tu pratilomānulomajāḥ / anyonyavyatiṣaktāś ca tān pravakṣyāmy aśeṣataḥ //
column2: I will (now) fully enumerate those (sons) of mixed origin, who are born of Anulomas and of Pratilomas, and (thus) are mutually connected.

column1: sūto vaidehakaś caiva caṇḍālaś ca narādhamaḥ / māgadhaḥ tathāyogava eva ca kṣatrajātiś ca //
column2: The Suta, the Vaidehaka, the Kandala, that lowest of mortals, the Magadha, he of the Kshattri caste (gati), and the Ayogava,

column1: ete ṣaṭ sadṛśān varṇāñ janayanti svayoniṣu / mātṛjātyāṃ prasūyante pravārāsu ca yoniṣu //
column2: These six (Pratilomas) beget similar races (varna) on women of their own (caste), they (also) produce (the like) with females of their mother's caste (gati), and with females (of) higher ones.

column1: yathā trayāṇāṃ varṇānāṃ dvayor ātmāsya jāyate / ānantaryāt svayonyāṃ tu tathā bāhyeṣv api kramāt //
column2: As a (Brahmana) begets on (females of) two out of the three (twice-born castes a son similar to) himself, (but inferior) on account of the lower degree (of the mother), and (one equal to himself) on a female of his own race, even so is the order in the case of the excluded (races, vahya).

column1: te cāpi bāhyān subahūṃs tato 'py adhikadūṣitān / parasparasya dāreṣu janayanti vigarhitān //
column2: Those (six mentioned above) also beget, the one on the females of the other, a great many (kinds of) despicable (sons), even more sinful than their (fathers), and excluded (from the Aryan community, vahya).

column1: yathaiva śūdro brāhmaṇyāṃ bāhyaṃ jantuṃ prasūyate / tathā bāhyataraṃ bāhyaś cāturvarṇye prasūyate //
column2: Just as a Sudra begets on a Brahmana female a being excluded (from the Aryan community), even so (a person himself) excluded pro creates with (females of) the four castes (varna, sons) more (worthy of being) excluded (than he himself).

column1: pratikūlaṃ vartamānā bāhyā bāhyatarān punaḥ / hīnā hīnān prasūyante varṇān pañcadaśaiva tu //
column2: But men excluded (by the Aryans, vahya), who approach females of higher rank, beget races (varna) still more worthy to be excluded, low men (hina) still lower races, even fifteen (in number).

column1: prasādhanopacārajñam adāsaṃ dāsajīvanam / sairindhraṃ vāgurāvṛttiṃ sūte dasyur ayogave //
column2: A Dasyu begets on an Ayogava (woman) a Sairandhra, who is skilled in adorning and attending (his master), who, (though) not a slave, lives like a slave, (or) subsists by snaring (animals).

column1: maitreyakaṃ tu vaideho mādhūkaṃ saṃprasūyate / nṝn praśaṃsaty ajasraṃ yo ghaṇṭātāḍo 'ruṇodaye //
column2: A Vaideha produces (with the same) a sweet-voiced Maitreyaka, who, ringing a bell at the appearance of dawn, continually. praises (great) men.

column1: niṣādo mārgavaṃ sūte dāsaṃ naukarmajīvinam / kaivartam iti yaṃ prāhur āryāvartanivāsinaḥ //
column2: A Nishada begets (on the same) a Margava (or) Dasa, who subsists by working as a boatman, (and) whom the inhabitants of Aryavarta call a Kaivarta.

column1: mṛtavastrabhṛtsv nārīṣu garhitānnāśanāsu ca / bhavanty āyogavīṣv ete jātihīnāḥ pṛthak trayaḥ //
column2: Those three base-born ones are severally begot on Ayogava women, who wear the clothes of the dead, are wicked, and eat reprehensible food.

column1: kārāvaro niṣādāt tu carmakāraḥ prasūyate / vaidehikād andhramedau bahirgrāmapratiśrayau // caṇḍālāt pāṇḍusopākas tvaksāravyavahāravān / āhiṇḍiko niṣādena vaidehyām eva jāyate //
column2: From a Nishada springs (by a woman of the Vaideha caste) a Karavara, who works in leather; and from a Vaidehaka (by women of the Karavara and Nishada castes), an Andhra and a Meda, who dwell outside the village. From a Kandala by a Vaideha woman is born a Pandusopaka, who deals in cane; from a Nishada (by the same) an Ahindika.

column1: caṇḍālena tu sopāko mūlavyasanavṛttimān / pukkasyāṃ jāyate pāpaḥ sadā sajjanagarhitaḥ //
column2: But from a Kandala by a Pukkasa woman is born the sinful Sopaka, who lives by the occupations of his sire, and is ever despised by good men.

column1: niṣādastrī tu caṇḍālāt putram antyāvasāyinam / śmaśānagocaraṃ sūte bāhyānām api garhitam //
column2: A Nishada woman bears to a Kandala a son (called) Antyavasayin, employed in burial-grounds, and despised even by those excluded (from the Aryan community).

column1: saṃkare jātayas tv etāḥ pitṛmātṛpradarśitāḥ / prachannā vā prakāśā vā veditavyāḥ svakarmabhiḥ //
column2: These races, (which originate) in a confusion (of the castes and) have been described according to their fathers and mothers, may be known by their occupations, whether they conceal or openly show themselves.

column1: svajātijānantarajāḥ ṣaṭ sutā dvijadharmiṇaḥ / śūdrāṇāṃ tu sadharmāṇaḥ sarve 'padhvaṃsajāḥ smṛtāḥ //
column2: Six sons, begotten (by Aryans) on women of equal and the next lower castes (Anantara), have the duties of twice-born men; but all those born in consequence of a violation (of the law) are, as regards their duties, equal to Sudras.

column1: tapobījaprabhāvais tu te gacchanti yuge yuge / utkarṣaṃ cāpakarṣaṃ ca manuṣyeṣv iha janmataḥ //
column2: By the power of austerities and of the seed (from which they sprang), these (races) obtain here among men more exalted or lower rank in successive births.

column1: śanakais tu kriyālopād imāḥ kṣatriyajātayaḥ / vṛṣalatvaṃ gatā loke brāhmaṇādarśanena ca //
column2: But in consequence of the omission of the sacred rites, and of their not consulting Brahmanas, the following tribes of Kshatriyas have gradually sunk in this world to the condition of Sudras;

column1: pauṇḍrakāś cauḍradraviḍāḥ kāmbojā yavanāḥ śakāḥ / pāradāpahlavāś cīnāḥ kirātā daradāḥ khaśāḥ //
column2: (Viz.) the Paundrakas, the Kodas, the Dravidas, the Kambogas, the Yavanas, the Sakas, the Paradas, the Pahlavas, the Kinas, the Kiratas, and the Daradas.

column1: mukhabāhūrupajjānāṃ yā loke jātayo bahiḥ / mlecchavācaś cāryavācaḥ sarve te dasyavaḥ smṛtāḥ //
column2: All those tribes in this world, which are excluded from (the community of) those born from the mouth, the arms, the thighs, and the feet (of Brahman), are called Dasyus, whether they speak the language of the Mlekkhas (barbarians) or that of the Aryans.

column1: ye dvijānām apasadā ye cāpadhvaṃsajāḥ smṛtāḥ / te ninditair vartayeyur dvijānām eva karmabhiḥ //
column2: Those who have been mentioned as the base-born (offspring, apasada) of Aryans, or as produced in consequence of a violation (of the law, apadhvamsaga), shall subsist by occupations reprehended by the twice-born.

column1: sūtānām aśvasārathyam ambaṣṭhānāṃ cikitsanam / vaidehakānāṃ strīkāryaṃ māgadhānāṃ vaṇikpathaḥ // matsyaghāto niṣādānāṃ tvaṣṭis tv āyogavasya ca / medāndhracuñcumadgūnām āraṇyapaśuhiṃsanam //
column2: To Sutas (belongs) the management of horses and of chariots; to Ambashthas, the art of healing; to Vaidehakas, the service of women; to Magadhas, trade; Killing fish to Nishadas; carpenters' work to the Ayogava; to Medas, Andhras, Kunkus, and Madgus, the slaughter of wild animals;

column1: kṣattrugrapukkasānāṃ tu bilaukovadhabandhanam / dhigvaṇānāṃ carmakāryaṃ veṇānāṃ bhāṇḍavādanam //
column2: To Kshattris, Ugras, and Pukkasas, catching and killing (animals) living in holes; to Dhigvanas, working in leather; to Venas, playing drums.

column1: caityadrumaśmaśāneṣu śaileṣūpavaneṣu ca / vaseyur ete vijñātā vartayantaḥ svakarmabhiḥ //
column2: Near well-known trees and burial-grounds, on mountains and in groves, let these (tribes) dwell, known (by certain marks), and subsisting by their peculiar occupations.

column1: caṇḍālaśvapacānāṃ tu bahir grāmāt pratiśrayaḥ / apapātrāś ca kartavyā dhanam eṣāṃ śvagardabham //
column2: But the dwellings of Kandalas and Svapakas shall be outside the village, they must be made Apapatras, and their wealth (shall be) dogs and donkeys.

column1: vāsāṃsi mṛtacailāni bhinnabhāṇḍeṣu bhojanam / kārṣṇāyasam alaṅkāraḥ parivrajyā ca nityaśaḥ //
column2: Their dress (shall be) the garments of the dead, (they shall eat) their food from broken dishes, black iron (shall be) their ornaments, and they must always wander from place to place.

column1: na taiḥ samayam anvicchet puruṣo dharmam ācaran / vyavahāro mithas teṣāṃ vivāhaḥ sadṛśaiḥ saha //
column2: A man who fulfils a religious duty, shall not seek intercourse with them; their transactions (shall be) among themselves, and their marriages with their equals.

column1: annam eṣāṃ parādhīnaṃ deyaṃ syād bhinnabhājane / rātrau na vicareyus te grāmeṣu nagareṣu ca //
column2: Their food shall be given to them by others (than an Aryan giver) in a broken dish; at night they shall not walk about in villages and in towns.

column1: divā careyuḥ kāryārthaṃ cihnitā rājaśāsanaiḥ / abāndhavaṃ śavaṃ caiva nirhareyur iti sthitiḥ //
column2: By day they may go about for the purpose of their work, distinguished by marks at the king's command, and they shall carry out the corpses (of persons) who have no relatives; that is a settled rule.

column1: vadhyāṃś ca hanyuḥ satataṃ yathāśāstraṃ nṛpājñayā / vadhyavāsāṃsi gṛhṇīyuḥ śayyāś cābharaṇāni ca //
column2: By the king's order they shall always execute the criminals, in accordance with the law, and they shall take for themselves the clothes, the beds, and the ornaments of (such) criminals.

column1: varṇāpetam avijñātaṃ naraṃ kaluṣayonijam / āryarūpam ivānāryaṃ karmabhiḥ svair vibhāvayet //
column2: A man of impure origin, who belongs not to any caste, (varna, but whose character is) not known, who, (though) not an Aryan, has the appearance of an Aryan, one may discover by his acts.

column1: anāryatā niṣṭhuratā krūratā niṣkriyātmatā / puruṣaṃ vyañjayantīha loke kaluṣayonijam //
column2: Behaviour unworthy of an Aryan, harshness, cruelty, and habitual neglect of the prescribed duties betray in this world a man of impure origin.

column1: pitryaṃ vā bhajate śīlaṃ mātur vobhayam eva vā / na kathaṃ cana duryoniḥ prakṛtiṃ svāṃ niyacchati //
column2: A base-born man either resembles in character his father, or his mother, or both; he can never conceal his real nature.

column1: kule mukhye 'pi jātasya yasya syād yonisaṃkaraḥ / saṃśrayaty eva tacchīlaṃ naro 'lpam api vā bahu //
column2: Even if a man, born in a great family, sprang from criminal intercourse, he will certainly possess the faults of his (father), be they small or great.

column1: yatra tv ete paridhvaṃsāj jāyante varṇadūṣakāḥ / rāṣṭrikaiḥ saha tad rāṣṭraṃ kṣipram eva vinaśyati //
column2: But that kingdom in which such bastards, sullying (the purity of) the castes, are born, perishes quickly together with its inhabitants.

column1: brāhmaṇārthe gavārthe vā dehatyāgo 'nupaskṛtaḥ / strībālābhyupapattau ca bāhyānāṃ siddhikāraṇam //
column2: Dying, without the expectation of a reward, for the sake of Brahmanas and of cows, or in the defence of women and children, secures beatitude to those excluded (from the Aryan community, vahya.)

column1: ahiṃsā satyam asteyaṃ śaucam indriyanigrahaḥ / etaṃ sāmāsikaṃ dharmaṃ cāturvarṇye 'bravīn manuḥ //
column2: Abstention from injuring (creatures), veracity, abstention from unlawfully appropriating (the goods of others), purity, and control of the organs, Manu has declared to be the summary of the law for the four castes.

column1: śūdrāyāṃ brāhmaṇāj jātaḥ śreyasā cet prajāyate / aśreyān śreyasīṃ jātiṃ gacchaty ā saptamād yugāt //
column2: If (a female of the caste), sprung from a Brahmana and a Sudra female, bear (children) to one of the highest caste, the inferior (tribe) attains the highest caste within the seventh generation.

column1: śūdro brāhmaṇatām eti brāhmaṇaś caiti śūdratām / kṣatriyāj jātam evaṃ tu vidyād vaiśyāt tathaiva ca //
column2: (Thus) a Sudra attains the rank of a Brahmana, and (in a similar manner) a Brahmana sinks to the level of a Sudra; but know that it is the same with the offspring of a Kshatriya or of a Vaisya.

column1: anāryāyāṃ samutpanno brāhmaṇāt tu yadṛcchayā / brāhmaṇyām apy anāryāt tu śreyastvaṃ kveti ced bhavet //
column2: If (a doubt) should arise, with whom the preeminence (is, whether) with him whom an Aryan by chance begot on a non-Aryan female, or (with the son) of a Brahmana woman by a non-Aryan,

column1: jāto nāryām anāryāyām āryād āryo bhaved guṇaiḥ / jāto 'py anāryād āryāyām anārya iti niścayaḥ //
column2: The decision is as follows: 'He who was begotten by an Aryan on a non-Aryan female, may become (like to) an Aryan by his virtues; he whom an Aryan (mother) bore to a non-Aryan father (is and remains) unlike to an Aryan.'

column1: tāv ubhāv apy asaṃskāryāv iti dharmo vyavasthitaḥ / vaiguṇyāj janmanaḥ pūrva uttaraḥ pratilomataḥ //
column2: The law prescribes that neither of the two shall receive the sacraments, the first (being excluded) on account of the lowness of his origin, the second (because the union of his parents was) against the order of the castes.

column1: subījaṃ caiva sukṣetre jātaṃ saṃpadyate yathā / tathāryāj jāta āryāyāṃ sarvaṃ saṃskāram arhati //
column2: As good seed, springing up in good soil, turns out perfectly well, even so the son of an Aryan by an Aryan woman is worthy of all the sacraments.

column1: bījam eke praśaṃsanti kṣetram anye manīṣiṇaḥ / bījakṣetre tathaivānye tatreyaṃ tu vyavasthitiḥ //
column2: Some sages declare the seed to be more important, and others the field; again others (assert that) the seed and the field (are equally important); but the legal decision on this point is as follows:

column1: akṣetre bījam utsṛṣṭam antaraiva vinaśyati / abījakam api kṣetraṃ kevalaṃ sthaṇḍilaṃ bhavet //
column2: Seed, sown on barren ground, perishes in it; a (fertile) field also, in which no (good) seed (is sown), will remain barren.

column1: yasmād bījaprabhāveṇa tiryagjā ṛṣayo 'bhavan / pūjitāś ca praśastāś ca tasmād bījaṃ praśasyate //
column2: As through the power of the seed (sons) born of animals became sages who are honoured and praised, hence the seed is declared to be more important.

column1: anāryam āryakarmāṇam āryaṃ cānāryakarmiṇam / saṃpradhāryābravīd dhātā na samau nāsamāv iti //
column2: Having considered (the case of) a non-Aryan who acts like an Aryan, and (that of) an Aryan who acts like a non-Aryan, the creator declared, 'Those two are neither equal nor unequal.'

column1: brāhmaṇā brahmayonisthā ye svakarmaṇy avasthitāḥ / te samyag upajīveyuḥ ṣaṭ karmāṇi yathākramam //
column2: Brahmanas who are intent on the means (of gaining union with) Brahman and firm in (discharging) their duties, shall live by duly performing the following six acts, (which are enumerated) in their (proper) order.

column1: adhyāpanam adhyayanaṃ yajanaṃ yājanaṃ tathā / dānaṃ pratigrahaś caiva ṣaṭ karmāṇy agrajanmanaḥ //
column2: Teaching, studying, sacrificing for himself, sacrificing for others, making gifts and receiving them are the six acts (prescribed) for a Brahmana.

column1: ṣaṇṇāṃ tu karmaṇām asya trīṇi karmāṇi jīvikā / yājanādhyāpane caiva viśuddhāc ca pratigrahaḥ //
column2: But among the six acts (ordained) for him three are his means of subsistence, (viz.) sacrificing for others, teaching, and accepting gifts from pure men.

column1: trayo dharmā nivartante brāhmaṇāt kṣatriyaṃ prati / adhyāpanaṃ yājanaṃ ca tṛtīyaś ca pratigrahaḥ //
column2: (Passing) from the Brahmana to the Kshatriya, three acts (incumbent on the former) are forbidden, (viz.) teaching, sacrificing for others, and, thirdly, the acceptance of gifts.

column1: vaiśyaṃ prati tathaivaite nivarterann iti sthitiḥ / na tau prati hi tān dharmān manur āha prajāpatiḥ //
column2: The same are likewise forbidden to a Vaisya, that is a settled rule; for Manu, the lord of creatures (Pragapati), has not prescribed them for (men of) those two (castes).

column1: śastrāstrabhṛttvaṃ kṣatrasya vaṇikpaśukṛṣir viṣaḥ / ājīvanārthaṃ dharmas tu dānam adhyayanaṃ yajiḥ // vedābhyāso brāhmaṇasya kṣatriyasya ca rakṣaṇam / vārtākarmaiva vaiśyasya viśiṣṭāni svakarmasu //
column2: To carry arms for striking and for throwing (is prescribed) for Kshatriyas as a means of subsistence; to trade, (to rear) cattle, and agriculture for Vaisyas; but their duties are liberality, the study of the Veda, and the performance of sacrifices. Among the several occupations the most commendable are, teaching the Veda for a Brahmana, protecting (the people) for a Kshatriya, and trade for a Vaisya.

column1: ajīvaṃs tu yathoktena brāhmaṇaḥ svena karmaṇā / jīvet kṣatriyadharmeṇa sa hy asya praty anantaraḥ //
column2: But a Brahmana, unable to subsist by his peculiar occupations just mentioned, may live according to the law applicable to Kshatriyas; for the latter is next to him in rank.

column1: ubhābhyām apy ajīvaṃs tu kathaṃ syād iti ced bhavet / kṛṣigorakṣam āsthāya jīved vaiśyasya jīvikām //
column2: If it be asked, 'How shall it be, if he cannot maintain himself by either (of these occupations?' the answer is), he may adopt a Vaisya's mode of life, employing himself in agriculture and rearing cattle.

column1: vaiśyavṛttyāpi jīvaṃs tu brāhmaṇaḥ ksatriyo 'pi vā / hiṃsāprāyāṃ parādhīnāṃ kṛṣiṃ yatnena varjayet //
column2: But a Brahmana, or a Kshatriya, living by a Vaisya's mode of subsistence, shall carefully avoid (the pursuit of) agriculture, (which causes) injury to many beings and depends on others.

column1: kṛṣiṃ sādhv iti manyante sā vṛttiḥ sadvigarhitāḥ / bhūmiṃ bhūmiśayāṃś caiva hanti kāṣṭham ayomukham // idaṃ tu vṛttivaikalyāt tyajato dharmanaipuṇaṃ / viṭpaṇyam uddhṛtoddhāraṃ vikreyaṃ vittavardhanam //
column2: (Some) declare that agriculture is something excellent, (but) that means of subsistence is blamed by the virtuous; (for) the wooden (implement) with iron point injuries the earth and (the beings) living in the earth. But he who, through a want of means of subsistence, gives up the strictness with respect to his duties, may sell, in order to increase his wealth, the commodities sold by Vaisyas, making (however) the (following) exceptions.

column1: sarvān rasān apoheta kṛtānnaṃ ca tilaiḥ saha / aśmano lavaṇaṃ caiva paśavo ye ca mānuṣāḥ //
column2: He must avoid (selling) condiments of all sorts, cooked food and sesamum, stones, salt, cattle, and human (beings),

column1: sarvaṃ ca tāntavaṃ raktaṃ śāṇakṣaumāvikāni ca / api cet syur araktāni phalamūle tathauṣadhīḥ //
column2: All dyed cloth, as well as cloth made of hemp, or flax, or wool, even though they be not dyed, fruit, roots, and (medical) herbs

column1: apaḥ śastraṃ viṣaṃ māṃsaṃ somaṃ gandhāṃś ca sarvaśaḥ / kṣīraṃ kṣaudraṃ dadhi ghṛtaṃ tailaṃ madhu guḍaṃ kuśān //
column2: Water, weapons, poison, meat, Soma, and perfumes of all kinds, fresh milk, honey, sour milk, clarified butter, oil, wax, sugar, Kusa-grass;

column1: āraṇyāṃś ca paśūn sarvān daṃṣṭriṇaś ca vayāṃsi ca / madyaṃ nīliṃ ca lākṣāṃ ca sarvāṃś caikaśaphāṃs tathā //
column2: All beasts of the forest, animals with fangs or tusks, birds, spirituous liquor, indigo, lac, and all one-hoofed beasts.

column1: kāmam utpādya kṛṣyāṃ tu svayam eva kṛṣīvalaḥ / vikrīṇīta tilāñ śūdrān dharmārtham acirasthitān //
column2: But he who subsists by agriculture, may at pleasure sell unmixed sesamum grains for sacred purposes, provided he himself has grown them and has not kept them long.

column1: bhojanābhyañjanād dānād yad anyat kurute tilaiḥ / kṛmibhūtaḥ śvaviṣṭhāyāṃ pitṛbhiḥ saha majjati //
column2: If he applies sesamum to any other purpose but food, anointing, and charitable gifts, he will be born (again) as a worm and, together with his ancestors, be plunged into the ordure of dogs.

column1: sadyaḥ patati māṃsena lākṣayā lavaṇena ca / tryaheṇa śūdro bhavati brāhmaṇaḥ kṣīravikrayāt //
column2: By (selling) flesh, salt, and lac a Brahmana at once becomes an outcast; by selling milk he becomes (equal to) a Sudra in three days.

column1: itareṣāṃ tu paṇyānāṃ vikrayād iha kāmataḥ / brāhmaṇaḥ saptarātreṇa vaiśyabhāvaṃ niyacchati //
column2: But by willingly selling in this world other (forbidden) commodities, a Brahmana assumes after seven nights the character of a Vaisya.

column1: rasā rasair nimātavyā na tv eva lavaṇaṃ rasaiḥ / kṛtānnaṃ ca kṛtānnena tilā dhānyena tatsamāḥ //
column2: Condiments may be bartered for condiments, but by no means salt for (other) condiments; cooked food (may be exchanged) for (other kinds of) cooked food, and sesamum seeds for grain in equal quantities.

column1: jīved etena rājanyaḥ sarveṇāpy anayaṃ gataḥ / na tv eva jyāyaṃsīṃ vṛttim abhimanyeta karhi cit //
column2: A Kshatriya who has fallen into distress, may subsist by all these (means); but he must never arrogantly adopt the mode of life (prescribed for his) betters.

column1: yo lobhād adhamo jātyā jīved utkṛṣṭakarmabhiḥ / taṃ rājā nirdhanaṃ kṛtvā kṣipram eva pravāsayet //
column2: A man of low caste who through covetousness lives by the occupations of a higher one, the king shall deprive of his property and banish.

column1: varaṃ svadharmo viguṇo na pārakyaḥ svanuṣṭhitaḥ / paradharmeṇa jīvan hi sadyaḥ patati jātitaḥ //
column2: It is better (to discharge) one's own (appointed) duty incompletely than to perform completely that of another; for he who lives according to the law of another (caste) is instantly excluded from his own.

column1: vaiśyo 'jīvan svadharmeṇa śūdravṛttyāpi vartayet / anācarann akāryāṇi nivarteta ca śaktimān //
column2: A Vaisya who is unable to subsist by his own duties, may even maintain himself by a Sudra's mode of life, avoiding (however) acts forbidden (to him), and he should give it up, when he is able (to do so).

column1: aśaknuvaṃs tu śuśrūṣāṃ śūdraḥ kartuṃ dvijanmanām / putradārātyayaṃ prāpto jīvet kārukakarmabhiḥ //
column2: But a Sudra, being unable to find service with the twice-born and threatened with the loss of his sons and wife (through hunger), may maintain himself by handicrafts.

column1: yaiḥ karmabhiḥ pracaritaiḥ śuśrūṣyante dvijātayaḥ / tāni kārukakarmāṇi śilpāni vividhāni ca //
column2: (Let him follow) those mechanical occupations and those various practical arts by following which the twice-born are (best) served.

column1: vaiśyavṛttim anātiṣṭhan brāhmaṇaḥ sve pathi sthitaḥ / avṛttikarṣitaḥ sīdann imaṃ dharmaṃ samācaret //
column2: A Brahmana who is distressed through a want of means of subsistence and pines (with hunger), (but) unwilling to adopt a Vaisya's mode of life and resolved to follow his own (prescribed) path, may act in the following manner.

column1: sarvataḥ pratigṛhṇīyād brāhmaṇas tv anayaṃ gataḥ / pavitraṃ duṣyatīty etad dharmato nopapadyate //
column2: A Brahmana who has fallen into distress may accept (gifts) from anybody; for according to the law it is not possible (to assert) that anything pure can be sullied.

column1: nādhyāpanād yājanād vā garhitād vā pratigrahāt / doṣo bhavati viprāṇāṃ jvalanāmbusamā hi te //
column2: By teaching, by sacrificing for, and by accepting gifts from despicable (men) Brahmanas (in distress) commit not sin; for they (are as pure) as fire and water.

column1: jīvitātyayam āpanno yo 'nnam atti tatas tataḥ / ākāśam iva paṅkena na sa pāpena lipyate //
column2: He who, when in danger of losing his life, accepts food from any person whatsoever, is no more tainted by sin than the sky by mud.

column1: ajīgartaḥ sutaṃ hantum upāsarpad bubhukṣitaḥ / na cālipyata pāpena kṣutpratīkāram ācaran //
column2: Agigarta, who suffered hunger, approached in order to slay (his own) son, and was not tainted by sin, since he (only) sought a remedy against famishing.

column1: śvamāṃsam icchan ārto 'ttuṃ dharmādharmavicakṣaṇaḥ / prāṇānāṃ parirakṣārthaṃ vāmadevo na liptavān //
column2: Vamadeva, who well knew right and wrong, did not sully himself when, tormented (by hunger), he desired to eat the flesh of a dog in order to save his life.

column1: bharadvājaḥ kṣudhārtas tu saputro vijane vane / bahvīr gāḥ pratijagrāha vṛdhos takṣṇo mahātapāḥ //
column2: Bharadvaga, a performer of great austerities, accepted many cows from the carpenter Bribu, when he was starving together with his sons in a lonely forest.

column1: kṣudhārtaś cāttum abhyāgād viśvāmitraḥ śvajāghanīm / caṇḍālahastād ādāya dharmādharmavicakṣaṇaḥ //
column2: Visvamitra, who well knew what is right or wrong, approached, when he was tormented by hunger, (to eat) the haunch of a dog, receiving it the hands of a Kandala.

column1: pratigrahād yājanād vā tathaivādhyāpanād api / pratigrahaḥ pratyavaraḥ pretya viprasya garhitaḥ //
column2: On (comparing) the acceptance (of gifts from low men), sacrificing (for them), and teaching (them), the acceptance of gifts is the meanest (of those acts) and (most) reprehensible for a Brahmana (on account of its results) in the next life.

column1: yājanādhyāpane nityaṃ kriyete saṃskṛtātmanām / pratigrahas tu kriyate śūdrād apy antyajanmanaḥ //
column2: (For) assisting in sacrifices and teaching are (two acts) always performed for men who have received the sacraments; but the acceptance of gifts takes place even in (case the giver is) a Sudra of the lowest class.

column1: japahomair apaity eno yājanādhyāpanaiḥ kṛtam / pratigrahanimittaṃ tu tyāgena tapasaiva ca //
column2: The guilt incurred by offering sacrifices for teaching (unworthy men) is removed by muttering (sacred texts) and by burnt offerings, but that incurred by accepting gifts (from them) by throwing (the gifts) away and by austerities.

column1: śiloñcham apy ādadīta vipro 'jīvan yatas tataḥ / pratigrahāc chilaḥ śreyāṃs tato 'py uñchaḥ praśasyate // sīdadbhiḥ kupyam icchadbhir dhane vā pṛthivīpatiḥ / yācyaḥ syāt snātakair viprair aditsaṃs tyāgam arhati //
column2: A Brahmana who is unable to maintain himself, should (rather) glean ears or grains from (the field of) any (man); gleaning ears is better than accepting gifts, picking up single grains is declared to be still more laudable. If Brahmanas, who are Snatakas, are pining with hunger, or in want of (utensils made of) common metals, or of other property, they may ask the king for them; if he is not disposed to be liberal, he must be left.

column1: akṛtaṃ ca kṛtāt kṣetrād gaur ajāvikam eva ca / hiraṇyaṃ dhānyam annaṃ ca pūrvaṃ pūrvam adoṣavat //
column2: (The acceptance on an untilled field is less blamable than (that of) a tilled one; (with respect to) cows, goats, sheep, gold, grain, and cooked food, (the acceptance of) each earlier-named (article is less blamable than of the following ones).

column1: sapta vittāgamā dharmyā dāyo lābhaḥ krayo jayaḥ / prayogaḥ karmayogaś ca satpratigraha eva ca //
column2: There are seven lawful modes of acquiring property, (viz.) inheritance, finding or friendly donation, purchase, conquest, lending at interest, the performance of work, and the acceptance of gifts from virtuous men.

column1: vidyā śilpaṃ bhṛtiḥ sevā gorakṣyaṃ vipaṇiḥ kṛṣiḥ / dhṛtir bhaikṣaṃ kusīdaṃ ca daśa jīvanahetavaḥ //
column2: Learning, mechanical arts, work for wages, service, rearing cattle, traffic, agriculture, contentment (with little), alms, and receiving interest on money, are the ten modes of subsistence (permitted to all men in times of distress).

column1: brāhmaṇaḥ kṣatriyo vāpi vṛddhiṃ naiva prayojayet / kāmaṃ tu khalu dharmārthaṃ dadyāt pāpīyase 'lpikām //
column2: Neither a Brahmana, nor a Kshatriya must lend (money at) interest; but at his pleasure (either of them) may, in times of distress when he requires money) for sacred purposes, lend to a very sinful man at a small interest.

column1: caturtham ādadāno 'pi kṣatriyo bhāgam āpadi / prajā rakṣan paraṃ śaktyā kilbiṣāt pratimucyate //
column2: A Kshatriya (king) who, in times of distress, takes even the fourth part (of the crops), is free from guilt, if he protects his subjects to the best of his ability.

column1: svadharmo vijayas tasya nāhave syāt parāṅmukhaḥ / śastreṇa vaiśyān rakṣitvā dharmyam āhārayed balim //
column2: His peculiar duty is conquest, and he must not turn back in danger; having protected the Vaisyas by his weapons, he may cause the legal tax to be collected;

column1: dhānye 'ṣṭamaṃ viśāṃ śulkaṃ viṃśaṃ kārṣāpaṇāvaram / karmopakaraṇāḥ śūdrāḥ kāravaḥ śilpinas tathā //
column2: (Viz.) from Vaisyas one-eighth as the tax on grain, one-twentieth (on the profits on gold and cattle), which amount at least to one Karshapana; Sudras, artisans, and mechanics (shall) benefit (the king) by (doing) work (for him).

column1: śūdras tu vṛttim ākāṅkṣan kṣatram ārādhayed yadi / dhaninaṃ vāpy upārādhya vaiśyaṃ śūdro jijīviṣet //
column2: If a Sudra, (unable to subsist by serving Brahmanas,) seeks a livelihood, he may serve Kshatriyas, or he may also seek to maintain himself by attending on a wealthy Vaisya.

column1: svargārtham ubhayārthaṃ vā viprān ārādhayet tu saḥ / jātabrāhmaṇaśabdasya sā hy asya kṛtakṛtyatā //
column2: But let a (Sudra) serve Brahmanas, either for the sake of heaven, or with a view to both (this life and the next); for he who is called the servant of a Brahmana thereby gains all his ends.

column1: viprasevaiva śūdrasya viśiṣṭaṃ karma kīrtyate / yad ato 'nyad dhi kurute tad bhavaty asya niṣphalam //
column2: The service of Brahmanas alone is declared (to be) an excellent occupation for a Sudra; for whatever else besides this he may perform will bear him no fruit.

column1: prakalpyā tasya tair vṛttiḥ svakuṭumbād yathārhataḥ / śaktiṃ cāvekṣya dākṣyaṃ ca bhṛtyānāṃ ca parigraham //
column2: They must allot to him out of their own family (-property) a suitable maintenance, after considering his ability, his industry, and the number of those whom he is bound to support.

column1: ucchiṣṭam annaṃ dātavyaṃ jīrṇāni vasanāni ca / pulākāś caiva dhānyānāṃ jīrṇāś caiva paricchadāḥ //
column2: The remnants of their food must be given to him, as well as their old clothes, the refuse of their grain, and their old household furniture.

column1: na śūdre pātakaṃ kiṃ cin na ca saṃskāram arhati / nāsyādhikāro dharme 'sti na dharmāt pratiṣedhanam //
column2: A Sudra cannot commit an offence, causing loss of caste (pataka), and he is not worthy to receive the sacraments; he has no right to (fulfil) the sacred law (of the Aryans, yet) there is no prohibition against (his fulfilling certain portions of) the law.

column1: dharmepsavas tu dharmajñāḥ satāṃ vṛttam anuṣṭhitāḥ / mantravarjyaṃ na duṣyanti praśaṃsāṃ prāpnuvanti ca //
column2: (Sudras) who are desirous to gain merit, and know (their) duty, commit no sin, but gain praise, if they imitate the practice of virtuous men without reciting sacred texts.

column1: yathā yathā hi sadvṛttam ātiṣṭhaty anasūyakaḥ / tathā tathemaṃ cāmuṃ ca lokaṃ prāpnoty aninditaḥ //
column2: The more a (Sudra), keeping himself free from envy, imitates the behaviour of the virtuous, the more he gains, without being censured, (exaltation in) this world and the next.

column1: śaktenāpi hi śūdreṇa na kāryo dhanasaṃcayaḥ / śūdro hi dhanam āsādya brāhmaṇān eva bādhate //
column2: No collection of wealth must be made by a Sudra, even though he be able (to do it); for a Sudra who has acquired wealth, gives pain to Brahmanas.

column1: ete caturṇāṃ varṇānām āpaddharmāḥ prakīrtitāḥ / yān samyag anutiṣṭhanto vrajanti paramaṃ gatim //
column2: The duties of the four castes (varna) in times of distress have thus been declared, and if they perform them well, they will reach the most blessed state.

column1: eṣa dharmavidhiḥ kṛtsnaś cāturvarṇyasya kīrtitaḥ / ataḥ paraṃ pravakṣyāmi prāyaścittavidhiṃ śubham //
column2: Thus all the legal rules for the four castes have been proclaimed; I next will promulgate the auspicious rules for penances.

column1: sāntānikaṃ yakṣyamāṇam adhvagaṃ sārvavedasam / gurvarthaṃ pitṛmātrarthaṃ svādhyāyārthy upatāpinaḥ //
column2: Him who wishes (to marry for the sake of having) offspring, him who wishes to perform a sacrifice, a traveller, him who has given away all his property, him who begs for the sake of his teacher, his father, or his mother, a student of the Veda, and a sick man,

column1: na vai tān snātakān vidyād brāhmaṇān dharmabhikṣukān / niḥsvebhyo deyam etebhyo dānaṃ vidyāviśeṣataḥ //
column2: These nine Brahmanas one should consider as Snatakas, begging in order to fulfil the sacred law; to such poor men gifts must be given in proportion to their learning.

column1: etebhyo hi dvijāgryebhyo deyam annaṃ sadakṣiṇam / itarebhyo bahirvedi kṛtānnaṃ deyam ucyate //
column2: To these most excellent among the twice-born, food and presents (of money) must be given; it is declared that food must be given to others outside the sacrificial enclosure.

column1: sarvaratnāni rājā tu yathārhaṃ pratipādayet / brāhmaṇān vedaviduṣo yajñārthaṃ caiva dakṣiṇām //
column2: But a king shall bestow, as is proper, jewels of all sorts, and presents for the sake of sacrifices on Brahmanas learned in the Vedas.

column1: kṛtadāro 'parān dārān bhikṣitvā yo 'dhigacchati / ratimātraṃ phalaṃ tasya dravyadātus tu saṃtatiḥ //
column2: If a man who has a wife weds a second wife, having begged money (to defray the marriage expenses, he obtains) no advantage but sensual enjoyment; but the issue (of his second marriage belongs) to the giver of the money.

column1: dhanāni tu yathāśakti vipreṣu pratipādayet / vedavitsu vivikteṣu pretya svargaṃ samaśnute //
column2: One should give, according to one's ability, wealth to Brahmanas learned in the Veda and living alone; (thus) one obtains after death heavenly bliss.

column1: yasya traivārṣikaṃ bhaktaṃ paryāptaṃ bhṛtyavṛttaye / adhikaṃ vāpi vidyeta sa somaṃ pātum arhati //
column2: He who may possess (a supply of) food sufficient to maintain those dependant on him during three years or more than that, is worthy to drink the Soma-juice.

column1: ataḥ svalpīyasi dravye yaḥ somaṃ pibati dvijaḥ / sa pītasomapūrvo 'pi na tasyāpnoti tatphalam //
column2: But a twice-born man, who, though possessing less than that amount of property, nevertheless drinks the Soma-juice, does not derive any benefit from that (act), though he may have formerly drunk the Soma-juice.

column1: śaktaḥ parajane dātā svajane duḥkhajīvini / madhvāpāto viṣāsvādaḥ sa dharmapratirūpakaḥ //
column2: (If) an opulent man (is) liberal towards strangers, while his family lives in distress, that counterfeit virtue will first make him taste the sweets (of fame, but afterwards) make him swallow the poison (of punishment in hell).

column1: bhṛtyānām uparodhena yat karoty aurdhvadehikam / tad bhavaty asukhodarkaṃ jīvataś ca mṛtasya ca //
column2: If (a man) does anything for the sake of his happiness in another world, to the detriment of those whom he is bound to maintain, that produces evil results for him, both while he lives and when he is dead.

column1: yajñaś cet pratiruddhaḥ syād ekenāṅgena yajvanaḥ / brāhmaṇasya viśeṣena dhārmike sati rājani //
column2: If a sacrifice, (offered) by (any twice-born) sacrificer, (and) especially by a Brahmana, must remain incomplete through (the want of) one requisite, while a righteous king rules,

column1: yo vaiśyaḥ syād bahupaśur hīnakratur asomapaḥ / kuṭumbāt tasya tad dravyam āhared yajñasiddhaye //
column2: That article (required) for the completion of the sacrifice, may be taken (forcibly) from the house of any Vaisya, who possesses a large number of cattle, (but) neither performs the (minor) sacrifices nor drinks the Soma-juice;

column1: āharet trīṇi vā dve vā kāmaṃ śūdrasya veśmanaḥ / na hi śūdrasya yajñeṣu kaś cid asti parigrahaḥ //
column2: (Or) the (sacrificer) may take at his pleasure two or three (articles required for a sacrifice) from the house of a Sudra; for a Sudra has no business with sacrifices.

column1: yo 'nāhitāgniḥ śatagur ayajvā ca sahasraguḥ / tayor api kuṭumbābhyām āhared avicārayan //
column2: If (a man) possessing one hundred cows, kindles not the sacred fire, or one possessing a thousand cows, drinks not the Soma-juice, a (sacrificer) may unhesitatingly take (what he requires) from the houses of those two, even (though they be Brahmanas or Kshatriyas);

column1: ādānanityāc cādātur āhared aprayacchataḥ / tathā yaśo 'sya prathate dharmaś caiva pravardhate //
column2: (Or) he may take (it by force or fraud) from one who always takes and never gives, and who refuses to give it; thus the fame (of the taker) will spread and his merit increase.

column1: tathāaiva saptame bhakte bhaktāni ṣaḍ anaśnatā / aśvastanavidhānena hartavyaṃ hīnakarmaṇaḥ //
column2: Likewise he who has not eaten at (the time of) six meals, may take at (the time of) the seventh meal (food) from a man who neglects his sacred duties, without (however) making a provision for the morrow,

column1: khalāt kṣetrād agārād vā yato vāpy upalabhyate / ākhyātavyaṃ tu tat tasmai pṛcchate yadi pṛcchati //
column2: Either from the threshing-floor, or from a field, or out of the house, or wherever he finds it; but if (the owner) asks him, he must confess to him that (deed and its cause).

column1: brāhmaṇasvaṃ na hartavyaṃ kṣatriyeṇa kadā cana / dasyuniṣkriyayos tu svam ajīvan hartum arhati //
column2: (On such occasions) a Kshatriya must never take the property of a (virtuous Brahmana; but he who is starving may appropriate the possessions of a Dasyu, or of one who neglects his sacred duties.

column1: yo 'sādhubhyo 'rtham ādāya sādhubhyaḥ saṃprayacchati / sa kṛtvā plavam ātmānaṃ saṃtārayati tāv ubhau //
column2: He who takes property from the wicked and bestows it on the virtuous, transforms himself into a boat, and carries both (over the sea of misfortune).

column1: yad dhanaṃ yajñaśīlānāṃ devasvaṃ tad vidur budhāḥ / ayajvanāṃ tu yad vittam āsurasvaṃ tad ucyate //
column2: The property of those who zealously offer sacrifices, the wise call the property of the gods; but the wealth of those who perform no sacrifices is called the property of the Asuras.

column1: na tasmin dhārayed daṇḍaṃ dhārmikaḥ pṛthivīpatiḥ / kṣatriyasya hi bāliśyād brāhmaṇaḥ sīdati kṣudhā //
column2: On him (who, for the reasons stated, appropriates another's possessions), a righteous king shall not inflict punishment; for (in that case) a Brahmana pines with hunger through the Kshatriya's want of care.

column1: tasya bhṛtyajanaṃ jñātvā svakuṭumbān mahīpatiḥ / śrutaśīle ca vijñāya vṛttiṃ dharmyāṃ prakalpayet //
column2: Having ascertained the number of those dependent on such a man, and having fully considered his learning and his conduct, the king shall allow him, out of his own property, a maintenance whereon he may live according to the law;

column1: kalpayitvāsya vṛttiṃ ca rakṣed enaṃ samantataḥ / rājā hi dharmaṣaḍbhāgaṃ tasmāt prāpnoti rakṣitāt //
column2: And after allotting to him a maintenance, the king must protect him in every way; for he obtains from such (a man) whom he protects, the part of his spiritual merit.

column1: na yajñārthaṃ dhanaṃ śūdrād vipro bhikṣeta karhi cit / yajamāno hi bhikṣitvā caṇḍālaḥ pretya jāyate //
column2: A Brahmana shall never beg from a Sudra property for a sacrifice; for a sacrificer, having begged (it from such a man), after death is born (again) as a Kandala.

column1: yājñārtham arthaṃ bhikṣitvā yo na sarvaṃ prayacchati / sa yāti bhāsatāṃ vipraḥ kākatāṃ vā śataṃ samāḥ //
column2: A Brahmana who, having begged any property for a sacrifice, does not use the whole (for that purpose), becomes for a hundred years a (vulture of the kind called) Bhasa, or a crow.

column1: devasvaṃ brāhmaṇasvaṃ vā lobhenopahinasti yaḥ / sa pāpātmā pare loke gṛdhrocchiṣṭena jīvati //
column2: That sinful man, who, through covetousness, seizes the property of the gods, or the property of Brahmanas, feeds in another world on the leavings of vultures.

column1: iṣṭiṃ vaiśvānarīṃ nityaṃ nirvaped abdaparyaye / kḷptānāṃ paśusomānāṃ niṣkṛtyartham asaṃbhave //
column2: In case the prescribed animal and Soma-sacrifices cannot be performed, let him always offer at the change of the year a Vaisvanari Ishti as a penance (for the omission).

column1: āpatkalpena yo dharmaṃ kurute 'nāpadi dvijaḥ / sa nāpnoti phalaṃ tasya paratreti vicāritam //
column2: But a twice-born, who, without being in distress, performs his duties according to the law for times of distress, obtains no reward for them in the next world; that is the opinion (of the sages).

column1: viśvaiś ca devaiḥ sādhyaiś ca brāhmaṇaiś ca maharṣibhiḥ / āpatsu maraṇād bhītair vidheḥ pratinidhiḥ kṛtaḥ //
column2: By the Visve-devas, by the Sadhyas, and by the great sages (of the) Brahmana (caste), who were afraid of perishing in times of distress, a substitute was made for the (principal) rule.

column1: prabhuḥ prathamakalpasya yo 'nukalpena vartate / na sāṃparāyikaṃ tasya durmater vidyate phalam //
column2: That evil-minded man, who, being able (to fulfil) the original law, lives according to the secondary rule, reaps no reward for that after death.

column1: na brāhmaṇo vedayeta kiṃ cid rājani dharmavit / svavīryeṇaiva tāñ śiṣyān mānavān apakāriṇaḥ //
column2: A Brahmana who knows the law need not bring any (offence) to the notice of the king; by his own power alone be can punish those men who injure him.

column1: svavīryād rājavīryāc ca svavīryaṃ balavattaram / tasmāt svenaiva vīryeṇa nigṛhṇīyād arīn dvijaḥ //
column2: His own power is greater than the power of the king; the Brahmana therefore, may punish his foes by his own power alone.

column1: śrutīr atharvāṅgirasīḥ kuryād ity avicārayan / vākśastraṃ vai brāhmaṇasya tena hanyād arīn dvijaḥ //
column2: Let him use without hesitation the sacred texts, revealed by Atharvan and by Angiras; speech, indeed, is the weapon of the Brahmana, with that he may slay his enemies.

column1: kṣatriyo bāhuvīryeṇa tared āpadam ātmanaḥ / dhanena vaiśyaśūdrau tu japahomair dvijottamaḥ //
column2: A Kshatriya shall pass through misfortunes which have befallen him by the strength of his arms, a Vaisya and a Sudra by their wealth, the chief of the twice-born by muttered prayers and burnt-oblations.

column1: vidhātā śāsitā vaktā maitro brāhmaṇa ucyate / tasmai nākuśalaṃ brūyān na śuṣkāṃ giram īrayet //
column2: The Brahmana is declared (to be) the creator (of the world), the punisher, the teacher, (and hence) a benefactor (of all created beings); to him let no man say anything unpropitious, nor use any harsh words.

column1: na vai kanyā na yuvatir nālpavidyo na bāliśaḥ / hotā syād agnihotrasya nārto nāsaṃskṛtas tathā //
column2: Neither a girl, nor a (married) young woman, nor a man of little learning, nor a fool, nor a man in great suffering, nor one uninitiated, shall offer an Agnihotra.

column1: narake hi patanty ete juhvantaḥ sa ca yasya tat / tasmād vaitānakuśalo hotā syād vedapāragaḥ //
column2: For such (persons) offering a burnt-oblation sink into hell, as well as he to whom that (Agnihotra) belongs; hence the person who sacrifices (for another) must be skilled in (the performance of) Vaitana (rites), and know the whole Veda.

column1: prājāpatyam adattvāśvam agnyādheyasya dakṣiṇām / anāhitāgnir bhavati brāhmaṇo vibhave sati //
column2: A Brahmana who, though wealthy, does not give, as fee for the performance of an Agnyadheya, a horse sacred to Pragapati, becomes (equal to one) who has not kindled the sacred fires.

column1: puṇyāny anyāni kurvīta śraddadhāno jitendriyaḥ / na tv alpadakṣiṇair yajñair yajeteha kathaṃ cana //
column2: Let him who has faith and controls his senses perform other meritorious acts, but let him on no account offer sacrifices at which he gives smaller fees (than those prescribed).

column1: indriyāṇi yaśaḥ svargam āyuḥ kīrtiṃ prajāḥ paśūn / hanty alpadakṣiṇo yajñas tasmān nālpadhano yajet //
column2: The organs (of sense and action), honour, (bliss in) heaven, longevity, fame, offspring, and cattle are destroyed by a sacrifice at which (too) small sacrificial fees are given; hence a man of small means should not offer a (Srauta) sacrifice.

column1: agnihotry apavidhyāgnīn brāhmaṇaḥ kāmakārataḥ / cāndrāyaṇaṃ caren māsaṃ vīrahatyāsamaṃ hi tat //
column2: A Brahmana who, being an Agnihotrin, voluntarily neglects the sacred fires, shall perform a lunar penance during one month; for that (offence) is equal to the slaughter of a son.

column1: ye śūdrād adhigamyārtham agnihotram upāsate / ṛtvijas te hi śūdrāṇāṃ brahmavādiṣu garhitāḥ //
column2: Those who, obtaining wealth from Sudras, (and using that) offer an Agnihotra, are priests officiating for Sudras, (and hence) censured among those who recite the Veda.

column1: teṣāṃ satatam ajñānāṃ vṛṣalāgnyupasevinām / padā mastakam ākramya dātā durgāṇi saṃtaret //
column2: Treading with his foot on the heads of those fools who worship a fire (kindled at the expense) of a Sudra, the giver (of the wealth) shall always pass over his miseries (in the next world).

column1: akurvan vihitaṃ karma ninditaṃ ca samācaran / prasaktaś cendriyārtheṣu prāyaścittīyate naraḥ //
column2: A man who omits a prescribed act, or performs a blamable act, or cleaves to sensual enjoyments, must perform a penance.

column1: akāmataḥ kṛte pāpe prāyaścittaṃ vidur budhāḥ / kāmakārakṛte 'py āhur eke śrutinidarśanāt // akāmataḥ kṛtaṃ pāpaṃ vedābhyāsena śudhyati / kāmatas tu kṛtaṃ mohāt prāyaścittaiḥ pṛthagvidhaiḥ //
column2: (All) sages prescribe a penance for a sin unintentionally committed; some declare, on the evidence of the revealed texts, (that it may be performed) even for an intentional (offence). A sin unintentionally committed is expiated by the recitation of Vedic texts, but that which (men) in their folly commit intentionally, by various (special) penances.

column1: prāyaścittīyatāṃ prāpya daivāt pūrvakṛtena vā / na saṃsargaṃ vrajet sadbhiḥ prāyaścitte 'kṛte dvijaḥ //
column2: A twice-born man, having become liable to perform a penance, be it by (the decree of) fate or by (an act) committed in a former life, must not, before the penance has been performed, have intercourse with virtuous men.

column1: iha duścaritaiḥ ke cit ke cit pūrvakṛtais tathā / prāpnuvanti durātmāno narā rūpaviparyayam //
column2: Some wicked men suffer a change of their (natural) appearance in consequence of crimes committed in this life, and some in consequence of those committed in a former (existence).

column1: suvarṇacauraḥ kaunakhyaṃ surāpaḥ śyāvadantatām / brahmahā kṣayarogitvaṃ dauścarmyaṃ gurutalpagaḥ // piśunaḥ pautināsikyaṃ sūcakaḥ pūtivaktratām / dhānyacauro 'ṅgahīnatvam ātiraikyaṃ tu miśrakaḥ //
column2: He who steals the gold (of a Brahmana) has diseased nails; a drinker of (the spirituous liquor called) Sura, black teeth; the slayer of a Brahmana, consumption; the violator of a Guru's bed, a diseased skin; An informer, a foul-smelling nose; a calumniator, a stinking breath; a stealer of grain, deficiency in limbs; he who adulterates (grain), redundant limbs;

column1: annahartāmayāvitvaṃ maukyaṃ vāgapahārakaḥ / vastrāpahārakaḥ śvaitryaṃ paṅgutām aśvahārakaḥ //
column2: A stealer of (cooked) food, dyspepsia; a stealer of the words (of the Veda), dumbness a stealer of clothes, white leprosy; a horse-stealer, lameness.

column1: evaṃ karmaviśeṣeṇa jāyante sadvigarhitāḥ / jaḍamūkāndhabadhirā vikṛtākṛtayas tathā //
column2: Thus in consequence of a remnant of (the guilt of former) crimes, are born idiots, dumb, blind, deaf, and deformed men, who are (all) despised by the virtuous.

column1: caritavyam ato nityaṃ prāyaścittaṃ viśuddhaye / nindyair hi lakṣaṇair yuktā jāyante 'niṣkṛtainasaḥ //
column2: Penances, therefore, must always be performed for the sake of purification, because those whose sins have not been expiated, are born (again) with disgraceful marks.

column1: brahmahatyā surāpānaṃ steyaṃ gurvaṅganāgamaḥ / mahānti pātakāny āhuḥ saṃsargaś cāpi taiḥ saha //
column2: Killing a Brahmana, drinking (the spirituous liquor called) Sura, stealing (the gold of a Brahmana), adultery with a Guru's wife, and associating with such (offenders), they declare (to be) mortal sins (mahapataka).

column1: anṛtaṃ ca samutkarṣe rājagāmi ca paiśunam / guroś cālīkanirbandhaḥ samāni brahmahatyayā //
column2: Falsely attributing to oneself high birth, giving information to the king (regarding a crime), and falsely accusing one's teacher, (are offences) equal to slaying a Brahmana.

column1: brahmojjhatā vedanindā kauṭasākṣyaṃ suhṛdvadhaḥ / garhitānādyayor jagdhiḥ surāpānasamāni ṣaṭ //
column2: Forgetting the Veda, reviling the Vedas, giving false evidence, slaying a friend, eating forbidden food, or (swallowing substances) unfit for food, are six (offences) equal to drinking Sura.

column1: nikṣepasyāpaharaṇaṃ narāśvarajatasya ca / bhūmivajramaṇīnāṃ ca rukmasteyasamaṃ smṛtam //
column2: Stealing a deposit, or men, a horse, and silver, land, diamonds and (other) gems, is declared to be equal to stealing the gold (of a Brahmana).

column1: retaḥsekaḥ svayonīṣu kumārīṣv antyajāsu ca / sakhyuḥ putrasya ca strīṣu gurutalpasamaṃ viduḥ // govadho 'yājyasaṃyājyaṃ pāradāryātmavikrayaḥ / gurumātṛpitṛtyāgaḥ svādhyāyāgnyoḥ sutasya ca //
column2: Carnal intercourse with sisters by the same mother, with (unmarried) maidens, with females of the lowest castes, with the wives of a friend, or of a son, they declare to be equal to the violation of a Guru's bed. Slaying kine, sacrificing for those who are unworthy to sacrifice, adultery, selling oneself, casting off one's teacher, mother, father, or son, giving up the (daily) study of the Veda, and neglecting the (sacred domestic) fire,

column1: parivittitānuje 'nūḍhe parivedanam eva ca / tayor dānaṃ ca kanyāyās tayor eva ca yājanam //
column2: Allowing one's younger brother to marry first, marrying before one's elder brother, giving a daughter to, or sacrificing for, (either brother),

column1: kanyāyā dūṣaṇaṃ caiva vārdhuṣyaṃ vratalopanam / taḍāgārāmadārāṇām apatyasya ca vikrayaḥ //
column2: Defiling a damsel, usury, breaking a vow, selling a tank, a garden, one's wife, or child,

column1: vrātyatā bāndhavatyāgo bhṛtyādhyāpanam eva ca / bhṛtyā cādhyayanādānam apaṇyānāṃ ca vikrayaḥ //
column2: Living as a Vratya, casting off a relative, teaching (the Veda) for wages, learning (the Veda) from a paid teacher, and selling goods which one ought not to sell,

column1: sarvākāreṣv adhīkāro mahāyantrapravartanam / hiṃsauṣadhīnāṃ stryājīvo 'bhicāro mūlakarma ca // indhanārtham aśuṣkāṇāṃ drumāṇām avapātanam / ātmārthaṃ ca kriyārambho ninditānnādanaṃ tathā //
column2: Superintending mines (or factories) of any sort, executing great mechanical works, injuring (living) plants, subsisting on (the earnings of) one's wife, sorcery (by means of sacrifices), and working (magic by means of) roots, (and so forth), Cutting down green trees for firewood, doing acts for one's own advantage only, eating prohibited food,

column1: anāhitāgnitā steyam ṛṇānām anapakriyā / asacchāṣṭrādhigamanaṃ kauśīlavyasya ca kriyā // dhānyakupyapaśusteyaṃ madyapastrīniṣevaṇam / strīśūdraviṭkṣatravadho nāstikyaṃ copapātakam //
column2: Neglecting to kindle the sacred fires, theft, non-payment of (the three) debts, studying bad books, and practising (the arts of) dancing and singing, Stealing grain, base metals, or cattle, intercourse with women who drink spirituous liquor, slaying women, Sudras, Vaisyas, or Kshatriyas, and atheism, (are all) minor offences, causing loss of caste (Upapataka).

column1: brāhmaṇasya rujaḥ kṛtvā ghrātir aghreyamadyayoḥ / jaihmyaṃ ca maithunaṃ puṃsi jātibhraṃśakaraṃ smṛtam //
column2: Giving pain to a Brahmana (by a blow), smelling at things which ought not to be smelt at, or at spirituous liquor, cheating, and an unnatural offence with a man, are declared to cause the loss of caste (Gatibhramsa)

column1: kharāśvoṣṭramṛgebhānām ajāvikavadhas tathā / saṃkarīkaraṇaṃ jñeyaṃ mīnāhimahiṣasya ca //
column2: Killing a donkey, a horse, a camel, a deer, an elephant, a goat, a sheep, a fish, a snake, or a buffalo, must be known to degrade (the offender) to a mixed caste (Samkarikarana).

column1: ninditebhyo dhanādānaṃ vāṇijyaṃ śūdrasevanam / apātrīkaraṇaṃ jñeyam asatyasya ca bhāṣaṇam //
column2: Accepting presents from blamed men, trading, serving Sudras, and speaking a falsehood, make (the offender) unworthy to receive gifts (Apatra).

column1: kṛmikīṭavayohatyā madyānugatabhojanam / phalaidhaḥkusumasteyam adhairyaṃ ca malāvaham //
column2: Killing insects, small or large, or birds, eating anything kept close to spirituous liquors, stealing fruit, firewood, or flowers, (are offences) which make impure (Malavaha).

column1: etāny enāṃsi sarvāṇi yathoktāni pṛthak pṛthak / yair yair vratair apohyante tāni samyaṅ nibodhata //
column2: Learn (now) completely those penances, by means of which all the several offences mentioned (can) be expiated.

column1: brahmahā dvādaśa samāḥ kuṭīṃ kṛtvā vane vaset / bhaikṣāśy ātmaviśuddhyarthaṃ kṛtvā śavaśiro dhvajam //
column2: For his purification the slayer of a Brahmana shall make a hut in the forest and dwell (in it) during twelve years, subsisting on alms and making the skull of a dead man his flag.

column1: lakṣyaṃ śastrabhṛtāṃ vā syād viduṣām icchayātmanaḥ / prāsyed ātmānam agnau vā samiddhe trir avākśirāḥ //
column2: Or let him, of his own free will, become (in a battle) the target of archers who know (his purpose); or he may thrice throw himself headlong into a blazing fire;

column1: yajeta vāśvamedhena svarjitā gosavena vā / abhijidviśvajidbhyāṃ vā trivṛtāgniṣṭutāpi vā //
column2: Or he may offer a horse-sacrifice, a Svargit, a Gosava, an Abhigit, a Visvagit, a Trivrit, or an Agnishtut;

column1: japan vānyatamaṃ vedaṃ yojanānāṃ śataṃ vrajet / brahmahatyāpanodāya mitabhuṅ niyatendriyaḥ //
column2: Or, in order to remove (the guilt of) slaying a Brahmana, he may walk one hundred yoganas, reciting one of the Vedas, eating little, and controlling his organs;

column1: sarvasvaṃ vedaviduṣe brāhmaṇāyopapādayet / dhanaṃ hi jīvanāyālaṃ gṛhaṃ vā saparicchadam //
column2: Or he may present to a Brahmana, learned in the Vedas, whole property, as much wealth as suffices for the maintenance (of the recipient), or a house together with the furniture;

column1: haviṣyabhug vānusaret pratisrotaḥ sarasvatīm / japed vā niyatāhāras trir vai vedasya saṃhitām //
column2: Or, subsisting on sacrificial food, he may walk against the stream along (the whole course of the river) Sarasvati; or, restricting his food (very much), he may mutter thrice the Samhita of a Veda.

column1: kṛtavāpano nivased grāmānte govraje 'pi vā / āśrame vṛkṣamūle vā gobrāhmaṇahite rataḥ //
column2: Having shaved off (all his hair), he may dwell at the extremity of the village, or in a cow-pen, or in a hermitage, or at the root of a tree, taking pleasure in doing good to cows and Brahmanas.

column1: brāhmaṇārthe gavārthe vā sadyaḥ prāṇān parityajet / mucyate brahmahatyāyā goptā gor brāhmaṇasya ca //
column2: He who unhesitatingly abandons life for the sake of Brahmanas or of cows, is freed from (the guilt of) the murder of a Brahmana, and (so is he) who saves (the life of) a cow, or of a Brahmana.

column1: trivāraṃ pratiroddhā vā sarvasvam avajitya vā / viprasya tannimitte vā prāṇālābhe vimucyate //
column2: If either he fights at least three times (against robbers in defence of) a Brahmana's (property), or reconquers the whole property of a Brahmana, or if he loses his life for such a cause, he is freed (from his guilt).

column1: evaṃ dṛḍhavrato nityaṃ brahmacārī samāhitaḥ / samāpte dvādaśe varṣe brahmahatyāṃ vyapohati //
column2: He who thus (remains) always firm in his vow, chaste, and of concentrated mind, removes after the lapse of twelve years (the guilt of) slaying a Brahmana.

column1: śiṣṭvā vā bhūmidevānāṃ naradevasamāgame / svam eno 'vabhṛthasnāto hayamedhe vimucyate //
column2: Or he who, after confessing his crime in an assembly of the gods of the earth (Brahnanas), and the gods of men (Kshatriyas), bathes (with the priests) at the close of a horse-sacrifice, is (also) freed (from guilt).

column1: dharmasya brāhmaṇo mūlam agraṃ rājanya ucyate / tasmāt samāgame teṣām eno vikhyāpya śudhyati //
column2: The Brahmana is declared (to be) the root of the sacred law and the Kshatriya its top; hence he who has confessed his sin before an assembly of such men, becomes pure.

column1: brahmaṇaḥ saṃbhavenaiva devānām api daivatam / pramāṇaṃ caiva lokasya brahmātraiva hi kāraṇam //
column2: By his origin alone a Brahmana is a deity even for the gods, and (his teaching is) authoritative for men, because the Veda is the foundation for that.

column1: teṣāṃ vedavido brūyus trayo 'py enaḥ suniṣkṛtim / sā teṣāṃ pāvanāya syāt pavitrā viduṣāṃ hi vāk //
column2: (If) only three of them who are learned in the Veda proclaim the expiation for offences, that shall purify the (sinners); for the words of learned men are a means of purification.

column1: ato 'nyatamam āsthāya vidhiṃ vipraḥ samāhitaḥ / brahmahatyākṛtaṃ pāpaṃ vyapohaty ātmavattayā //
column2: A Brahmana who, with a concentrated mind, follows any of the (above-mentioned) rules, removes the sin committed by slaying a Brahmana through his self-control.

column1: hatvā garbham avijñātam etad eva vrataṃ caret / rājanyavaiśyau cejānāv ātreyīm eva ca striyam //
column2: For destroying the embryo (of a Brahmana, the sex of which was) unknown, for slaying a Kshatriya or a Vaisya who are (engaged in or) have offered a (Vedic) sacrifice, or a (Brahmana) woman who has bathed after temporary uncleanness (Atreyi), he must perform the same penance,

column1: uktvā caivānṛtaṃ sākṣye pratirudhya guruṃ tathā / apahṛtya ca niḥkṣepaṃ kṛtvā ca strīsuhṛdvadham //
column2: Likewise for giving false evidence (in an important cause), for passionately abusing the teacher, for stealing a deposit, and for killing (his) wife or his friend:

column1: iyaṃ viśuddhir uditā pramāpyākāmato dvijam / kāmato brāhmaṇavadhe niṣkṛtir na vidhīyate //
column2: This expiation has been prescribed for unintentionally killing a Brahmana; but for intentionally slaying a Brahmana no atonement is ordained.

column1: surāṃ pītvā dvijo mohād agnivarṇāṃ surāṃ pibet / tayā sa kāye nirdagdhe mucyate kilbiṣāt tataḥ //
column2: A twice-born man who has (intentionally) drunk, through delusion of mind, (the spirituous liquor called) Sura shall drink that liquor boiling-hot; when his body has been completely scalded by that, he is freed from his guilt;

column1: gomūtram agnivarṇaṃ vā pibed udakam eva vā / payo ghṛtaṃ vā maraṇād gośakṛdrasam eva vā // kaṇān vā bhakṣayed abdaṃ piṇyākaṃ vā sakṛn niśi / surāpānāpanuttyarthaṃ vālavāsā jaṭī dhvajī //
column2: Or he may drink cow's urine, water, milk, clarified butter or (liquid) cowdung boiling-hot, until he dies; Or, in order to remove (the guilt of) drinking Sura, he may eat during a year once (a day) at night grains (of rice) or oilcake, wearing clothes made of cowhair and his own hair in braids and carrying (a wine cup as) a flag.

column1: surā vai malam annānāṃ pāpmā ca malam ucyate / tasmād brāhmaṇarājanyau vaiśyaś ca na surāṃ pibet //
column2: Sura, indeed, is the dirty refuse (mala) of grain, sin also is called dirt (mala); hence a Brahmana, a Kshatriya, and a Vaisya shall not drink Sura.

column1: gauḍī paiṣṭī ca mādhvī ca vijñeyā trividhā surā / yathaivaikā tathā sarvā na pātavyā dvijottamaiḥ //
column2: Sura one must know to be of three kinds, that distilled from molasses (gaudi), that distilled from ground rice, and that distilled from Madhuka-flowers (madhvi); as the one (named above) even so are all (three sorts) forbidden to the chief of the twice-born.

column1: yakṣarakṣaḥpiśācānnaṃ madyaṃ māṃsaṃ surāsavam / tad brāhmaṇena nāttavyaṃ devānām aśnatā haviḥ //
column2: Sura, (all other) intoxicating drinks and decoctions and flesh are the food of the Yakshas, Rakshasas, and Pisakas; a Brahmana who eats (the remnants of) the offerings consecrated to the gods, must not partake of such (substances).

column1: amedhye vā paten matto vaidikaṃ vāpy udāharet / akāryam anyat kuryād vā brāhmaṇo madamohitaḥ //
column2: A Brahmana, stupefied by drunkenness, might fall on something impure, or (improperly) pronounce Vedic (texts), or commit some other act which ought not to be committed.

column1: yasya kāyagataṃ brahma madyenāplāvyate sakṛt / tasya vyapaiti brāhmaṇyaṃ śūdratvaṃ ca sa gacchati //
column2: When the Brahman (the Veda) which dwells in his body is (even) once (only) deluged with spirituous liquor, his Brahmanhood forsakes him and he becomes a Sudra.

column1: eṣā vicitrābhihitā surāpānasya niṣkṛtiḥ / ata ūrdhvaṃ pravakṣyāmi suvarṇasteyaniṣkṛtim //
column2: The various expiations for drinking (the spirituous liquors called) Sura have thus been explained; I will next proclaim the atonement for stealing the gold (of a Brahmana).

column1: suvarṇasteyakṛd vipro rājānam abhigamya tu / svakarma khyāpayan brūyān māṃ bhavān anuśāstv iti // gṛhītvā musalaṃ rājā sakṛd dhanyāt tu taṃ svayam / vadhena śudhyati steno brāhmaṇas tapasaiva tu // tapasāpanunutsus tu suvarṇasteyajaṃ malam / cīravāsā dvijo 'raṇye cared brahmahaṇo vratam //
column2: A Brahmana who has stolen the gold (of a Brahmana) shall go to the king and, confessing his deed, say, 'Lord, punish me!' Taking (from him) the club (which he must carry), the king himself shall strike him once, by his death the thief becomes pure; or a Brahmana (may purify himself) by austerities. He who desires to remove by austerities the guilt of stealing the gold (of a Brahmana), shall perform the penance (prescribed) for the slayer of a Brahmana, (living) in a forest and dressed in (garments) made of bark.

column1: etair vratair apoheta pāpaṃ steyakṛtaṃ dvijaḥ / gurustrīgamanīyaṃ tu vratair ebhir apānudet //
column2: By these penances a twice-born man may remove the guilt incurred by a theft (of gold); but he may atone for connexion with a Guru's wife by the following penances.

column1: gurutalpy abhibhāṣyainas tapte svapyād ayomaye / sūrmīṃ jvalantīṃ svāśliṣyen mṛtyunā sa viśudhyati //
column2: He who has violated his Guru's bed, shall, after confessing his crime, extend himself on a heated iron bed, or embrace the red-hot image (of a woman); by dying he becomes pure;

column1: svayaṃ vā śiṣṇavṛṣaṇāv utkṛtyādhāya cāñjalau / nairṛtīṃ diśam ātiṣṭhed ā nipātād ajihmagaḥ //
column2: Or, having himself cut off his organ and his testicles and having taken them in his joined hands, he may walk straight towards the region of Nirriti (the south-west), until he falls down (dead);

column1: khaṭvāṅgī cīravāsā vā śmaśrulo vijane vane / prājāpatyaṃ caret kṛcchram abdam ekaṃ samāhitaḥ //
column2: Or, carrying the foot of a bedstead, dressed in (garments of) bark and allowing his beard to grow, he may, with a concentrated mind, perform during a whole year the Krikkhra (or hard, penance), revealed by Pragapati, in a lonely forest;

column1: cāndrāyaṇaṃ vā trīn māsān abhyasyen niyatendriyaḥ / haviṣyeṇa yavāgvā vā gurutalpāpanuttaye //
column2: Or, controlling his organs, he may during three months continuously perform the lunar penance, (subsisting) on sacrificial food or barley-gruel, in order to remove (the guilt of) violating a Guru's bed.

column1: etair vratair apoheyur mahāpātakino malam / upapātakinas tv evam ebhir nānāvidhair vrataiḥ //
column2: By means of these penances men who have committed mortal sins (Mahapataka) may remove their guilt, but those who committed minor offences, causing loss of caste, (Upapataka, can do it) by the various following penances.

column1: upapātakasaṃyukto goghno māsaṃ yavān pibet / kṛtavāpo vased goṣṭhe carmaṇā tena saṃvṛtaḥ //
column2: He who has committed a minor offence by slaying a cow (or bull) shall drink during (the first) month (a decoction of) barley-grains; having shaved all his hair, and covering himself with the hide (of the slain cow), he must live in a cow-house.

column1: caturthakālam aśnīyād akṣāralavaṇaṃ mitam / gomūtreṇācaret snānaṃ dvau māsau niyatendriyaḥ //
column2: During the two (following) months he shall eat a small (quantity of food) without any factitious salt at every fourth meal-time, and shall bathe in the urine of cows, keeping his organs under control.

column1: divānugacched gās tās tu tiṣṭhann ūrdhvaṃ rajaḥ pibet / śuśrūṣitvā namaskṛtya rātrau vīrāsanaṃ vaset //
column2: During the day he shall follow the cows and, standing upright, inhale the dust (raised by their hoofs); at night, after serving and worshipping them, he shall remain in the (posture, called) virasana.

column1: tiṣṭhantīṣv anutiṣṭhet tu vrajantīṣv apy anuvrajet / āsīnāsu tathāsīno niyato vītamatsaraḥ //
column2: Controlling himself and free from anger, he must stand when they stand, follow them when they walk, and seat himself when they lie down.

column1: āturām abhiśastāṃ vā cauravyāghrādibhir bhayaiḥ / patitāṃ paṅkalagnaṃ vā sarvopāyair vimocayet //
column2: (When a cow is) sick, or is threatened by danger from thieves, tigers, and the like, or falls, or sticks in a morass, he must relieve her by all possible means:

column1: uṣṇe varṣati śīte vā mārute vāti vā bhṛśam / na kurvītātmanas trāṇaṃ gor akṛtvā tu śaktitaḥ //
column2: In heat, in rain, or in cold, or when the wind blows violently, he must not seek to shelter himself, without (first) sheltering the cows according to his ability.

column1: ātmano yadi vānyeṣāṃ gṛhe kṣetre 'tha vā khale / bhakṣayantīṃ na kathayet pibantaṃ caiva vatsakam //
column2: Let him not say (a word), if a cow eats (anything) in his own or another's house or field or on the threshing-floor, or if a calf drinks (milk).

column1: anena vidhinā yas tu goghno gām anugacchati / sa gohatyākṛtaṃ pāpaṃ tribhir māsair vyapohati //
column2: The slayer of a cow who serves cows in this manner, removes after three months the guilt which he incurred by killing a cow.

column1: vṛṣabhaikādaśā gāś ca dadyāt sucaritavrataḥ / avidyamāne sarvasvaṃ vedavidbhyo nivedayet //
column2: But after he has fully performed the penance, he must give to (Brahmanas) learned in the Veda ten cows and a bull, (or) if he does not possess (so much property) he must offer to them all he has.

column1: etad eva vrataṃ kuryur upapātakino dvijāḥ / avakīrṇivarjyaṃ śuddhyarthaṃ cāndrāyaṇam athāpi vā //
column2: Twice-born men who have committed (other) minor offences (Upapataka), except a student who has broken his vow (Avakirnin), may perform, in order to purify themselves, the same penance or also a lunar penance.

column1: avakīrṇī tu kāṇena gardabhena catuṣpathe / pākayajñavidhānena yajeta nirṛtiṃ niśi // hutvāgnau vidhivad dhomān antataś ca samety ṛcā / vātendraguruvahnīnāṃ juhuyāt sarpiṣāhutīḥ //
column2: But a student who has broken his vow shall offer at night on a crossway to Nirriti a one-eyed ass, according to the rule of the Pakayagnas. Having offered according to the rule oblations in the fire, he shall finally offer (four) oblations of clarified butter to Vata, to Indra, to the teacher (of the gods, Brihaspati) and to Agni, reciting the Rik verse 'May the Maruts grant me,' &c.

column1: kāmato retasaḥ sekaṃ vratasthasya dvijanmanaḥ / atikramaṃ vratasyāhur dharmajñā brahmavādinaḥ //
column2: Those who know the Veda declare that a voluntary effusion of semen by a twice-born (youth) who fulfils the vow (of studentship constitutes) a breach of that vow.

column1: mārutaṃ puruhūtaṃ ca guruṃ pāvakam eva ca / caturo vratino 'bhyeti brāhmaṃ tejo 'vakīrṇinaḥ //
column2: The divine light which the Veda imparts to the student, enters, if he breaks his vow, the Maruts, Puruhuta (Indra), the teacher (of the gods, Brihaspati) and Pavaka (Fire).

column1: etasminn enasi prāpte vasitvā gardabhājinam / saptāgārāṃś cared bhaikṣaṃ svakarma parikīrtayan //
column2: When this sin has been committed, he shall go begging to seven houses, dressed in the hide of the (sacrificed) ass, proclaiming his deed.

column1: tebhyo labdhena bhaikṣeṇa vartayann ekakālikam / upaspṛśaṃs triṣavaṇaṃ tv abdena sa viśudhyati //
column2: Subsisting on a single (daily meal that consists) of the alms obtained there and bathing at (the time of) the three savanas (morning, noon, and evening), he becomes pure after (the lapse of) one year.

column1: jātibhraṃśakaraṃ karma kṛtvānyatamam icchayā / caret sāṃtapanaṃ kṛcchraṃ prājāpatyam anicchayā //
column2: For committing with intent any of the deeds which cause loss of caste (Gatibhramsakara), (the offender) shall perform a Samtapana Krikkhra; (for doing it) unintentionally, (the Krikkhra) revealed by Pragapati.

column1: saṃkarāpātrakṛtyāsu māsaṃ śodhanam aindavam / malinīkaraṇīyeṣu taptaḥ syād yāvakais tryaham //
column2: As atonement for deeds which degrade to a mixed caste (Samkara), and for those which make a man unworthy to receive gifts (Apatra), (he shall perform) the lunar (penance) during a month; for (acts) which render impure (Malinikaraniya) he shall scald himself during three days with (hot) barley-gruel.

column1: turīyo brahmahatyāyāḥ kṣatriyasya vadhe smṛtaḥ / vaiśye 'ṣṭamāṃśo vṛttasthe śūdre jñeyas tu ṣoḍaśaḥ //
column2: One fourth (of the penance) for the murder of a Brahmana is prescribed (as expiation) for (intentionally) killing a Kshatriya, one-eighth for killing a Vaisya; know that it is one-sixteenth for killing a virtuous Sudra.

column1: akāmatas tu rājanyaṃ vinipātya dvijottamaḥ / vṛṣabhaikasahasrā gā dadyāt sucaritavrataḥ //
column2: But if a Brahmana unintentionally kills a Kshatriya, he shall give, in order to purify himself, one thousand cows and a bull;

column1: tryabdaṃ cared vā niyato jaṭī brahmahaṇo vratam / vasan dūratare grāmād vṛkṣamūlaniketanaḥ //
column2: Or he may perform the penance prescribed for the murderer of a Brahmana during three years, controlling himself, wearing his hair in braids, staying far away from the village, and dwelling at the root of a tree.

column1: etad eva cared abdaṃ prāyaścittaṃ dvijottamaḥ / pramāpya vaiśyaṃ vṛttasthaṃ dadyāc caikaśataṃ gavām // etad eva vrataṃ kṛtsnaṃ ṣaṇmāsāñ śūdrahā caret / vṛṣabhaikādaśā vāpi dadyād viprāya gāḥ sitāḥ //
column2: A Brahmana who has slain a virtuous Vaisya, shall perform the same penance during one year, or he may give one hundred cows and one (bull). He who has slain a Sudra, shall perform that whole penance during six months, or he may also give ten white cows and one bull to a Brahmana.

column1: mārjāranakulau hatvā cāṣaṃ maṇḍūkam eva ca / śvagodholūkakākāṃś ca śūdrahatyāvrataṃ caret //
column2: Having killed a cat, an ichneumon, a blue jay, a frog, a dog, an iguana, an owl, or a crow, he shall perform the penance for the murder of a Sudra;

column1: payaḥ pibet trirātraṃ vā yojanaṃ vādhvano vrajet / upaspṛśet sravantyāṃ vā sūktaṃ vābdaivataṃ japet //
column2: Or he may drink milk during three days, or walk one hundred yoganas, or bathe in a river, or mutter the hymn addressed to the Waters.

column1: abhriṃ kārṣṇāyasīṃ dadyāt sarpaṃ hatvā dvijottamaḥ / palālabhārakaṃ ṣaṇḍhe saisakaṃ caikamāṣakam //
column2: For killing a snake, a Brahmana shall give a spade of black iron, for a eunuch a load of straw and a masha of lead;

column1: ghṛtakumbhaṃ varāhe tu tiladroṇaṃ tu tittirau / śuke dvihāyanaṃ vatsaṃ krauñcaṃ hatvā trihāyanam //
column2: For a boar a pot of clarified butter, for a partridge a drona of sesamum-grains, for a parrot a calf two years old, for a crane (a calf) three years old.

column1: hatvā haṃsaṃ balākāṃ ca bakaṃ barhiṇam eva ca / vānaraṃ śyenabhāsau ca sparśayed brāhmaṇāya gām //
column2: If he has killed a Hamsa, a Balaka, a heron, a peacock, a monkey, a falcon, or a Bhasa, he shall give a cow to a Brahmana.

column1: vāso dadyād dhayaṃ hatvā pañca nīlān vṛṣān gajam / ajameṣāv anaḍvāhaṃ kharaṃ hatvaikahāyanam //
column2: For killing a horse, he shall give a garment, for (killing) an elephant, five black bulls, for (killing) a goat, or a sheep, a draught-ox, for killing a donkey, (a calf) one year old;

column1: kravyādāṃs tu mṛgān hatvā dhenuṃ dadyāt payasvinīm / akravyādān vatsatarīm uṣṭraṃ hatvā tu kṛṣṇalam //
column2: But for killing carnivorous wild beasts, he shall give a milch-cow, for (killing) wild beasts that are not carnivorous, a heifer, for killing a camel, one krishnala.

column1: jīnakārmukabastāvīn pṛthag dadyād viśuddhaye / caturṇām api varṇānāṃ nārīr hatvānavasthitāḥ //
column2: For killing adulterous women of the four castes, he must give, in order to purify himself, respectively a leathern bag, a bow, a goat, or a sheep.

column1: dānena vadhanirṇekaṃ sarpādīnām aśaknuvan / ekaikaśaś caret kṛcchraṃ dvijaḥ pāpāpanuttaye //
column2: A twice-born man, who is unable to atone by gifts for the slaughter of a serpent and the other (creatures mentioned), shall perform for each of them, a Krikkhra (penance) in order to remove his guilt.

column1: asthimatāṃ tu sattvānāṃ sahasrasya pramāpaṇe / pūrṇe cānasy anasthnāṃ tu śūdrahatyāvrataṃ caret //
column2: But for destroying one thousand (small) animals that have bones, or a whole cart-load of boneless (animals), he shall perform the penance (prescribed) for the murder of a Sudra.

column1: kiṃ cid eva tu viprāya dadyād asthimatāṃ vadhe / anasthnāṃ caiva hiṃsāyāṃ prāṇāyāmena śudhyati //
column2: But for killing (small) animals which have bones, he should give some trifle to a Brahmana; if he injures boneless (animals), he becomes pure by a suppressing his breath (pranayama).

column1: phaladānāṃ tu vṛkṣāṇāṃ chedane japyam ṛkśatam / gulmavallīlatānāṃ ca puṣpitānāṃ ca vīrudhām //
column2: For cutting fruit-trees, shrubs, creepers, lianas, or flowering plants, one hundred Rikas must be muttered.

column1: annādyajānāṃ sattvānāṃ rasajānāṃ ca sarvaśaḥ / phalapuṣpodbhavānāṃ ca ghṛtaprāśo viśodhanam //
column2: (For destroying) any kind of creature, bred in food, in condiments, in fruit, or in flowers, the expiation is to eat clarified butter.

column1: kṛṣṭajānām oṣadhīnāṃ jātānāṃ ca svayaṃ vane / vṛthālambhe 'nugacched gāṃ dinam ekaṃ payovrataḥ //
column2: If a man destroys for no good purpose plants produced by cultivation, or such as spontaneously spring up in the forest, he shall attend a cow during one day, subsisting on milk alone.

column1: etair vratair apohyaṃ syād eno hiṃsāsamudbhavam / jñānājñānakṛtaṃ kṛtsnaṃ śṛṇutānādyabhakṣaṇe //
column2: The guilt incurred intentionally or unintentionally by injuring (created beings) can be removed by means of these penances; hear (now, how) all (sins) committed by partaking of forbidden food (or drink, can be expiated).

column1: ajñānād vāruṇīṃ pītvā saṃskāreṇaiva śudhyati / matipūrvam anirdeśyaṃ prāṇāntikam iti sthitiḥ //
column2: He who drinks unintentionally (the spirituous liquor, called) Varuni, becomes pure by being initiated (again); (even for drinking it) intentionally (a penance) destructive to life must not be imposed; that is a settled rule.

column1: apaḥ surābhājanasthā madyabhāṇḍasthitās tathā / pañcarātraṃ pibet pītvā śaṅkhapuṣpīśṛtaṃ payaḥ //
column2: He who has drunk water which has stood in a vessel used for keeping (the spirituous liquor, called) Sura, or other intoxicating drinks, shall drink during five (days and) nights (nothing but) milk in which the Sankhapushpi (plant) has been boiled.

column1: spṛṣṭva dattvā ca madirāṃ vidhivat pratigṛhya ca / śūdrocchiṣṭāś ca pītvāpaḥ kuśavāri pibet tryaham // brāhmaṇas tu surāpasya gandham āghrāya somapaḥ / prāṇān apsu trir āyamya ghṛtaṃ prāśya viśudhyati // ajñānāt prāśya viṇmūtraṃ surāsaṃspṛṣṭam eva ca / punaḥ saṃskāram arhanti trayo varṇā dvijātayaḥ //
column2: He who has touched spirituous liquor, has given it away, or received it in accordance with the rule, or has drunk water left by a Sudra, shall drink during three days water in which Kusa-grass has been boiled. But when a Brahmana who has partaken of Soma-juice, has smelt the odour exhaled by a drinker of Sura, he becomes pure by thrice suppressing his breath in water, and eating clarified butter. (Men of) the three twice-born castes who have unintentionally swallowed ordure or urine, or anything that has touched Sura, must be initiated again.

column1: vapanaṃ mekhalā daṇḍo bhaikṣacaryā vratāni ca / nivartante dvijātīnāṃ punaḥsaṃskārakarmaṇi //
column2: The tonsure, (wearing) the sacred girdle, (carrying) a staff, going to beg, and the vows (incumbent on a student), are omitted on the second initiation of twice-born men.

column1: abhojyānāṃ tu bhuktvānnaṃ strīśūdrocchiṣṭam eva ca / jagdhvā māṃsam abhakṣyaṃ ca saptarātraṃ yavān pibet //
column2: But he who has eaten the food of men, whose food must not be eaten, or the leavings of women and Sudras, or forbidden flesh, shall drink barley (-gruel) during seven (days and) nights.

column1: śuktāni ca kaṣāyāṃś ca pītvā medhyāny api dvijaḥ / tāvad bhavaty aprayato yāvat tan na vrajaty adhaḥ //
column2: A twice-born man who has drunk (fluids that have turned) sour, or astringent decoctions, becomes, though (these substances may) not (be specially) forbidden, impure until they have been digested.

column1: viḍvarāhakharoṣṭrāṇāṃ gomāyoḥ kapikākayoḥ / prāśya mūtrapurīṣāṇi dvijaś cāndrāyaṇaṃ caret //
column2: A twice-born man, who has swallowed the urine or ordure of a village pig, of a donkey, of a camel, of a jackal, of a monkey, or of a crow, shall perform a lunar penance.

column1: śuṣkāṇi bhuktvā māṃsāni bhaumāni kavakāni ca / ajñātaṃ caiva sūnāstham etad eva vrataṃ caret //
column2: He who has eaten dried meat, mushrooms growing on the ground, or (meat, the nature of) which is unknown, (or) such as had been kept in a slaughter-house, shall perform the same penance.

column1: kravyādasūkaroṣṭrāṇāṃ kukkuṭānāṃ ca bhakṣaṇe / narakākakharāṇāṃ ca taptakṛcchraṃ viśodhanam //
column2: The atonement for partaking of (the meat of) carnivorous animals, of pigs, of camels, of cocks, of crows, of donkeys, and of human flesh, is a Tapta Krikkhra (penance).

column1: māsikānnaṃ tu yo 'śnīyād asamāvartako dvijaḥ / sa trīṇy ahāny upavased ekāhaṃ codake vaset //
column2: If a twice-born man, who has not returned (home from his teacher's house), eats food, given at a monthly (Sraddha,) he shall fast during three days and pass one day (standing) in water.

column1: brahmacārī tu yo 'śnīyān madhu māṃsaṃ kathaṃ cana / sa kṛtvā prākṛtaṃ kṛcchraṃ vrataśeṣaṃ samāpayet //
column2: But a student who on any occasion eats honey or meat, shall perform an ordinary Krikkhra (penance), and afterwards complete his vow (of studentship).

column1: biḍālakākākhūcchiṣṭaṃ jagdhvā śvanakulasya ca / keśakīṭāvapannaṃ ca pibed brahmasuvarcalām //
column2: He who eats what is left by a cat, by a crow, by a mouse (or rat), by a dog, or by an ichneumon, or (food) into which a hair or an insect has fallen, shall drink (a decoction of) the Brahmasuvarkala (plant).

column1: abhojyam annaṃ nāttavyam ātmanaḥ śuddhim icchatā / ajñānabhuktaṃ tūttāryaṃ śodhyaṃ vāpy āśu śodhanaiḥ //
column2: He who desires to be pure, must not eat forbidden food, and must vomit up such as he has eaten unintentionally, or quickly atone for it by (various) means of purification.

column1: eṣo 'nādyādanasyokto vratānāṃ vividho vidhiḥ / steyadoṣāpahartṝṇāṃ vratānāṃ śrūyatāṃ vidhiḥ //
column2: The various rules respecting penances for eating forbidden food have been thus declared; hear now the law of those penances which remove the guilt of theft.

column1: dhānyānnadhanacauryāṇi kṛtvā kāmād dvijottamaḥ / svajātīyagṛhād eva kṛcchrābdena viśudhyati //
column2: The chief of the twice-born, having voluntarily stolen (valuable) property, grain, or cooked food, from the house of a caste-fellow, is purified by performing Krikkhra (penances) during a whole year.

column1: manuṣyāṇāṃ tu haraṇe strīṇāṃ kṣetragṛhasya ca / kūpavāpījalānāṃ ca śuddhiś cāndrāyaṇaṃ smṛtam //
